A MAN OF HIS DAY\r\n\r\nAs the Milvains sat down to breakfast the clock of Wattleborough parish\r\nchurch struck eight; it was two miles away, but the strokes were borne\r\nvery distinctly on the west wind this autumn morning. Jasper, listening\r\nbefore he cracked an egg, remarked with cheerfulness:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a man being hanged in London at this moment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely it isn\xe2\x80\x99t necessary to let us know that,\xe2\x80\x99 said his sister Maud,\r\ncoldly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And in such a tone, too!\xe2\x80\x99 protested his sister Dora.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who is it?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mrs Milvain, looking at her son with pained\r\nforehead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. It happened to catch my eye in the paper yesterday that\r\nsomeone was to be hanged at Newgate this morning. There\xe2\x80\x99s a certain\r\nsatisfaction in reflecting that it is not oneself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s your selfish way of looking at things,\xe2\x80\x99 said Maud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Jasper, \xe2\x80\x98seeing that the fact came into my head, what\r\nbetter use could I make of it? I could curse the brutality of an age\r\nthat sanctioned such things; or I could grow doleful over the misery of\r\nthe poor fellow. But those emotions would be as little profitable to\r\nothers as to myself. It just happened that I saw the thing in a light of\r\nconsolation. Things are bad with me, but not so bad as THAT. I might be\r\ngoing out between Jack Ketch and the Chaplain to be hanged; instead of\r\nthat, I am eating a really fresh egg, and very excellent buttered toast,\r\nwith coffee as good as can be reasonably expected in this part of the\r\nworld.--(Do try boiling the milk, mother.)--The tone in which I spoke\r\nwas spontaneous; being so, it needs no justification.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe was a young man of five-and-twenty, well built, though a trifle\r\nmeagre, and of pale complexion. He had hair that was very nearly black,\r\nand a clean-shaven face, best described, perhaps, as of bureaucratic\r\ntype. The clothes he wore were of expensive material, but had seen a\r\ngood deal of service. His stand-up collar curled over at the corners,\r\nand his necktie was lilac-sprigged.\r\n\r\nOf the two sisters, Dora, aged twenty, was the more like him in visage,\r\nbut she spoke with a gentleness which seemed to indicate a different\r\ncharacter. Maud, who was twenty-two, had bold, handsome features, and\r\nvery beautiful hair of russet tinge; hers was not a face that readily\r\nsmiled. Their mother had the look and manners of an invalid, though she\r\nsat at table in the ordinary way. All were dressed as ladies, though\r\nvery simply. The room, which looked upon a small patch of garden, was\r\nfurnished with old-fashioned comfort, only one or two objects suggesting\r\nthe decorative spirit of 1882.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A man who comes to be hanged,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Jasper, impartially, \xe2\x80\x98has\r\nthe satisfaction of knowing that he has brought society to its last\r\nresource. He is a man of such fatal importance that nothing will serve\r\nagainst him but the supreme effort of law. In a way, you know, that is\r\nsuccess.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In a way,\xe2\x80\x99 repeated Maud, scornfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Suppose we talk of something else,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Dora, who seemed to fear\r\na conflict between her sister and Jasper.\r\n\r\nAlmost at the same moment a diversion was afforded by the arrival of the\r\npost. There was a letter for Mrs Milvain, a letter and newspaper for\r\nher son. Whilst the girls and their mother talked of unimportant news\r\ncommunicated by the one correspondent, Jasper read the missive addressed\r\nto himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is from Reardon,\xe2\x80\x99 he remarked to the younger girl. \xe2\x80\x98Things are\r\ngoing badly with him. He is just the kind of fellow to end by poisoning\r\nor shooting himself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But why?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t get anything done; and begins to be sore troubled on his wife\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naccount.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is he ill?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Overworked, I suppose. But it\xe2\x80\x99s just what I foresaw. He isn\xe2\x80\x99t the\r\nkind of man to keep up literary production as a paying business. In\r\nfavourable circumstances he might write a fairly good book once every\r\ntwo or three years. The failure of his last depressed him, and now he\r\nis struggling hopelessly to get another done before the winter season.\r\nThose people will come to grief.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The enjoyment with which he anticipates it!\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Maud, looking at\r\nher mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s true I envied the fellow, because he\r\npersuaded a handsome girl to believe in him and share his risks, but I\r\nshall be very sorry if he goes to the--to the dogs. He\xe2\x80\x99s my one serious\r\nfriend. But it irritates me to see a man making such large demands upon\r\nfortune. One must be more modest--as I am. Because one book had a sort\r\nof success he imagined his struggles were over. He got a hundred\r\npounds for \xe2\x80\x9cOn Neutral Ground,\xe2\x80\x9d and at once counted on a continuance\r\nof payments in geometrical proportion. I hinted to him that he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nkeep it up, and he smiled with tolerance, no doubt thinking \xe2\x80\x9cHe judges\r\nme by himself.\xe2\x80\x9d But I didn\xe2\x80\x99t do anything of the kind.--(Toast, please,\r\nDora.)--I\xe2\x80\x99m a stronger man than Reardon; I can keep my eyes open, and\r\nwait.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is his wife the kind of person to grumble?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mrs Milvain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, yes, I suspect that she is. The girl wasn\xe2\x80\x99t content to go into\r\nmodest rooms--they must furnish a flat. I rather wonder he didn\xe2\x80\x99t start\r\na carriage for her. Well, his next book brought only another hundred,\r\nand now, even if he finishes this one, it\xe2\x80\x99s very doubtful if he\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\nas much. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Optimist\xe2\x80\x9d was practically a failure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Yule may leave them some money,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dora.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. But he may live another ten years, and he would see them both in\r\nMarylebone Workhouse before he advanced sixpence, or I\xe2\x80\x99m much mistaken\r\nin him. Her mother has only just enough to live upon; can\xe2\x80\x99t possibly\r\nhelp them. Her brother wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t give or lend twopence halfpenny.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Has Mr Reardon no relatives!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never heard him make mention of a single one. No, he has done the\r\nfatal thing. A man in his position, if he marry at all, must take\r\neither a work-girl or an heiress, and in many ways the work-girl is\r\npreferable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can you say that?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Dora. \xe2\x80\x98You never cease talking about the\r\nadvantages of money.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean that for ME the work-girl would be preferable; by\r\nno means; but for a man like Reardon. He is absurd enough to be\r\nconscientious, likes to be called an \xe2\x80\x9cartist,\xe2\x80\x9d and so on. He might\r\npossibly earn a hundred and fifty a year if his mind were at rest, and\r\nthat would be enough if he had married a decent little dressmaker. He\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t desire superfluities, and the quality of his work would be its\r\nown reward. As it is, he\xe2\x80\x99s ruined.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I repeat,\xe2\x80\x99 said Maud, \xe2\x80\x98that you enjoy the prospect.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing of the kind. If I seem to speak exultantly it\xe2\x80\x99s only because\r\nmy intellect enjoys the clear perception of a fact.--A little marmalade,\r\nDora; the home-made, please.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But this is very sad, Jasper,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Milvain, in her half-absent\r\nway. \xe2\x80\x98I suppose they can\xe2\x80\x99t even go for a holiday?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite out of the question.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not even if you invited them to come here for a week?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, mother,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Maud, \xe2\x80\x98THAT\xe2\x80\x99S impossible, you know very well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought we might make an effort, dear. A holiday might mean\r\neverything to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no,\xe2\x80\x99 fell from Jasper, thoughtfully. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think you\xe2\x80\x99d get\r\nalong very well with Mrs Reardon; and then, if her uncle is coming to Mr\r\nYule\xe2\x80\x99s, you know, that would be awkward.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose it would; though those people would only stay a day or two,\r\nMiss Harrow said.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why can\xe2\x80\x99t Mr Yule make them friends, those two lots of people?\xe2\x80\x99 asked\r\nDora. \xe2\x80\x98You say he\xe2\x80\x99s on good terms with both.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose he thinks it\xe2\x80\x99s no business of his.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper mused over the letter from his friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ten years hence,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98if Reardon is still alive, I shall be\r\nlending him five-pound notes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA smile of irony rose to Maud\xe2\x80\x99s lips. Dora laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure! To be sure!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed their brother. \xe2\x80\x98You have no faith.\r\nBut just understand the difference between a man like Reardon and a man\r\nlike me. He is the old type of unpractical artist; I am the literary man\r\nof 1882. He won\xe2\x80\x99t make concessions, or rather, he can\xe2\x80\x99t make them;\r\nhe can\xe2\x80\x99t supply the market. I--well, you may say that at present I\r\ndo nothing; but that\xe2\x80\x99s a great mistake, I am learning my business.\r\nLiterature nowadays is a trade. Putting aside men of genius, who may\r\nsucceed by mere cosmic force, your successful man of letters is your\r\nskilful tradesman. He thinks first and foremost of the markets; when one\r\nkind of goods begins to go off slackly, he is ready with something new\r\nand appetising. He knows perfectly all the possible sources of income.\r\nWhatever he has to sell he\xe2\x80\x99ll get payment for it from all sorts of\r\nvarious quarters; none of your unpractical selling for a lump sum to a\r\nmiddleman who will make six distinct profits. Now, look you: if I had\r\nbeen in Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s place, I\xe2\x80\x99d have made four hundred at least out of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Optimist\xe2\x80\x9d; I should have gone shrewdly to work with magazines and\r\nnewspapers and foreign publishers, and--all sorts of people. Reardon\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t do that kind of thing, he\xe2\x80\x99s behind his age; he sells a manuscript\r\nas if he lived in Sam Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s Grub Street. But our Grub Street of\r\nto-day is quite a different place: it is supplied with telegraphic\r\ncommunication, it knows what literary fare is in demand in every part of\r\nthe world, its inhabitants are men of business, however seedy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It sounds ignoble,\xe2\x80\x99 said Maud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have nothing to do with that, my dear girl. Now, as I tell you, I am\r\nslowly, but surely, learning the business. My line won\xe2\x80\x99t be novels;\r\nI have failed in that direction, I\xe2\x80\x99m not cut out for the work. It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\npity, of course; there\xe2\x80\x99s a great deal of money in it. But I have plenty\r\nof scope. In ten years, I repeat, I shall be making my thousand a year.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t remember that you stated the exact sum before,\xe2\x80\x99 Maud observed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let it pass. And to those who have shall be given. When I have a decent\r\nincome of my own, I shall marry a woman with an income somewhat larger,\r\nso that casualties may be provided for.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora exclaimed, laughing:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would amuse me very much if the Reardons got a lot of money at Mr\r\nYule\xe2\x80\x99s death--and that can\xe2\x80\x99t be ten years off, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t see that there\xe2\x80\x99s any chance of their getting much,\xe2\x80\x99 replied\r\nJasper, meditatively. \xe2\x80\x98Mrs Reardon is only his niece. The man\xe2\x80\x99s brother\r\nand sister will have the first helping, I suppose. And then, if it comes\r\nto the second generation, the literary Yule has a daughter, and by her\r\nbeing invited here I should think she\xe2\x80\x99s the favourite niece. No, no;\r\ndepend upon it they won\xe2\x80\x99t get anything at all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHaving finished his breakfast, he leaned back and began to unfold the\r\nLondon paper that had come by post.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Had Mr Reardon any hopes of that kind at the time of his marriage, do\r\nyou think?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired Mrs Milvain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Reardon? Good heavens, no! Would he were capable of such forethought!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn a few minutes Jasper was left alone in the room. When the servant\r\ncame to clear the table he strolled slowly away, humming a tune.\r\n\r\nThe house was pleasantly situated by the roadside in a little village\r\nnamed Finden. Opposite stood the church, a plain, low, square-towered\r\nbuilding. As it was cattle-market to-day in the town of Wattleborough,\r\ndroves of beasts and sheep occasionally went by, or the rattle of a\r\ngrazier\xe2\x80\x99s cart sounded for a moment. On ordinary days the road saw few\r\nvehicles, and pedestrians were rare.\r\n\r\nMrs Milvain and her daughters had lived here for the last seven years,\r\nsince the death of the father, who was a veterinary surgeon. The widow\r\nenjoyed an annuity of two hundred and forty pounds, terminable with her\r\nlife; the children had nothing of their own. Maud acted irregularly as\r\na teacher of music; Dora had an engagement as visiting governess in a\r\nWattleborough family. Twice a year, as a rule, Jasper came down from\r\nLondon to spend a fortnight with them; to-day marked the middle of his\r\nautumn visit, and the strained relations between him and his sisters\r\nwhich invariably made the second week rather trying for all in the house\r\nhad already become noticeable.\r\n\r\nIn the course of the morning Jasper had half an hour\xe2\x80\x99s private talk\r\nwith his mother, after which he set off to roam in the sunshine. Shortly\r\nafter he had left the house, Maud, her domestic duties dismissed for the\r\ntime, came into the parlour where Mrs Milvain was reclining on the sofa.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Jasper wants more money,\xe2\x80\x99 said the mother, when Maud had sat in\r\nmeditation for a few minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course. I knew that. I hope you told him he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what to say,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Mrs Milvain, in a feeble\r\ntone of worry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you must leave the matter to me, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. There\xe2\x80\x99s no money for\r\nhim, and there\xe2\x80\x99s an end of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMaud set her features in sullen determination. There was a brief\r\nsilence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s he to do, Maud?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To do? How do other people do? What do Dora and I do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t earn enough for your support, my dear.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, well!\xe2\x80\x99 broke from the girl. \xe2\x80\x98Of course, if you grudge us our food\r\nand lodging--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be so quick-tempered. You know very well I am far from grudging\r\nyou anything, dear. But I only meant to say that Jasper does earn\r\nsomething, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a disgraceful thing that he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t earn as much as he needs. We\r\nare sacrificed to him, as we always have been. Why should we be pinching\r\nand stinting to keep him in idleness?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you really can\xe2\x80\x99t call it idleness, Maud. He is studying his\r\nprofession.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pray call it trade; he prefers it. How do I know that he\xe2\x80\x99s studying\r\nanything? What does he mean by \xe2\x80\x9cstudying\xe2\x80\x9d? And to hear him speak\r\nscornfully of his friend Mr Reardon, who seems to work hard all through\r\nthe year! It\xe2\x80\x99s disgusting, mother. At this rate he will never earn his\r\nown living. Who hasn\xe2\x80\x99t seen or heard of such men? If we had another\r\nhundred a year, I would say nothing. But we can\xe2\x80\x99t live on what he leaves\r\nus, and I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to let you try. I shall tell Jasper plainly that\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s got to work for his own support.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnother silence, and a longer one. Mrs Milvain furtively wiped a tear\r\nfrom her cheek.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It seems very cruel to refuse,\xe2\x80\x99 she said at length, \xe2\x80\x98when another year\r\nmay give him the opportunity he\xe2\x80\x99s waiting for.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Opportunity? What does he mean by his opportunity?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He says that it always comes, if a man knows how to wait.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And the people who support him may starve meanwhile! Now just think\r\na bit, mother. Suppose anything were to happen to you, what becomes of\r\nDora and me? And what becomes of Jasper, too? It\xe2\x80\x99s the truest kindness\r\nto him to compel him to earn a living. He gets more and more incapable\r\nof it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You can\xe2\x80\x99t say that, Maud. He earns a little more each year. But for\r\nthat, I should have my doubts. He has made thirty pounds already this\r\nyear, and he only made about twenty-five the whole of last. We must\r\nbe fair to him, you know. I can\xe2\x80\x99t help feeling that he knows what he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nabout. And if he does succeed, he\xe2\x80\x99ll pay us all back.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMaud began to gnaw her fingers, a disagreeable habit she had in privacy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then why doesn\xe2\x80\x99t he live more economically?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really don\xe2\x80\x99t see how he can live on less than a hundred and fifty a\r\nyear. London, you know--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The cheapest place in the world.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense, Maud!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I know what I\xe2\x80\x99m saying. I\xe2\x80\x99ve read quite enough about such things.\r\nHe might live very well indeed on thirty shillings a week, even buying\r\nhis clothes out of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But he has told us so often that it\xe2\x80\x99s no use to him to live like that.\r\nHe is obliged to go to places where he must spend a little, or he makes\r\nno progress.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, all I can say is,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the girl impatiently, \xe2\x80\x98it\xe2\x80\x99s very\r\nlucky for him that he\xe2\x80\x99s got a mother who willingly sacrifices her\r\ndaughters to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s how you always break out. You don\xe2\x80\x99t care what unkindness you\r\nsay!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a simple truth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dora never speaks like that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because she\xe2\x80\x99s afraid to be honest.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, because she has too much love for her mother. I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear to talk\r\nto you, Maud. The older I get, and the weaker I get, the more unfeeling\r\nyou are to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nScenes of this kind were no uncommon thing. The clash of tempers lasted\r\nfor several minutes, then Maud flung out of the room. An hour later, at\r\ndinner-time, she was rather more caustic in her remarks than usual, but\r\nthis was the only sign that remained of the stormy mood.\r\n\r\nJasper renewed the breakfast-table conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Look here,\xe2\x80\x99 he began, \xe2\x80\x98why don\xe2\x80\x99t you girls write something? I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nconvinced you could make money if you tried. There\xe2\x80\x99s a tremendous sale\r\nfor religious stories; why not patch one together? I am quite serious.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you do it yourself,\xe2\x80\x99 retorted Maud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t manage stories, as I have told you; but I think you could. In\r\nyour place, I\xe2\x80\x99d make a speciality of Sunday-school prize-books; you\r\nknow the kind of thing I mean. They sell like hot cakes. And there\xe2\x80\x99s so\r\ndeuced little enterprise in the business. If you\xe2\x80\x99d give your mind to it,\r\nyou might make hundreds a year.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Better say \xe2\x80\x9cabandon your mind to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, there you are! You\xe2\x80\x99re a sharp enough girl. You can quote as well\r\nas anyone I know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And please, why am I to take up an inferior kind of work?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Inferior? Oh, if you can be a George Eliot, begin at the earliest\r\nopportunity. I merely suggested what seemed practicable.\r\nBut I don\xe2\x80\x99t think you have genius, Maud. People have got that ancient\r\nprejudice so firmly rooted in their heads--that one mustn\xe2\x80\x99t write save\r\nat the dictation of the Holy Spirit. I tell you, writing is a business.\r\nGet together half-a-dozen fair specimens of the Sunday-school prize;\r\nstudy them; discover the essential points of such composition; hit upon\r\nnew attractions; then go to work methodically, so many pages a day.\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s no question of the divine afflatus; that belongs to another\r\nsphere of life. We talk of literature as a trade, not of Homer, Dante,\r\nand Shakespeare. If I could only get that into poor Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s head. He\r\nthinks me a gross beast, often enough. What the devil--I mean what on\r\nearth is there in typography to make everything it deals with sacred?\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t advocate the propagation of vicious literature; I speak only of\r\ngood, coarse, marketable stuff for the world\xe2\x80\x99s vulgar. You just give it\r\na thought, Maud; talk it over with Dora.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe resumed presently:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I maintain that we people of brains are justified in supplying the mob\r\nwith the food it likes. We are not geniuses, and if we sit down in a\r\nspirit of long-eared gravity we shall produce only commonplace stuff.\r\nLet us use our wits to earn money, and make the best we can of our\r\nlives. If only I had the skill, I would produce novels out-trashing the\r\ntrashiest that ever sold fifty thousand copies. But it needs skill, mind\r\nyou: and to deny it is a gross error of the literary pedants. To\r\nplease the vulgar you must, one way or another, incarnate the genius\r\nof vulgarity. For my own part, I shan\xe2\x80\x99t be able to address the bulkiest\r\nmultitude; my talent doesn\xe2\x80\x99t lend itself to that form. I shall write for\r\nthe upper middle-class of intellect, the people who like to feel\r\nthat what they are reading has some special cleverness, but who can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndistinguish between stones and paste. That\xe2\x80\x99s why I\xe2\x80\x99m so slow in warming\r\nto the work. Every month I feel surer of myself, however.\r\n\r\nThat last thing of mine in The West End distinctly hit the mark; it\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t too flashy, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t too solid. I heard fellows speak of it in\r\nthe train.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Milvain kept glancing at Maud, with eyes which desired her attention\r\nto these utterances. None the less, half an hour after dinner, Jasper\r\nfound himself encountered by his sister in the garden, on her face a\r\nlook which warned him of what was coming.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I want you to tell me something, Jasper. How much longer shall you look\r\nto mother for support? I mean it literally; let me have an idea of how\r\nmuch longer it will be.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe looked away and reflected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To leave a margin,\xe2\x80\x99 was his reply, \xe2\x80\x98let us say twelve months.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Better say your favourite \xe2\x80\x9cten years\xe2\x80\x9d at once.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. I speak by the card. In twelve months\xe2\x80\x99 time, if not before, I shall\r\nbegin to pay my debts. My dear girl, I have the honour to be a tolerably\r\nlong-headed individual. I know what I\xe2\x80\x99m about.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And let us suppose mother were to die within half a year?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should make shift to do very well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You? And please--what of Dora and me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would write Sunday-school prizes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMaud turned away and left him.\r\n\r\nHe knocked the dust out of the pipe he had been smoking, and again set\r\noff for a stroll along the lanes. On his countenance was just a trace\r\nof solicitude, but for the most part he wore a thoughtful smile. Now\r\nand then he stroked his smoothly-shaven jaws with thumb and fingers.\r\nOccasionally he became observant of wayside details--of the colour of a\r\nmaple leaf, the shape of a tall thistle, the consistency of a fungus. At\r\nthe few people who passed he looked keenly, surveying them from head to\r\nfoot.\r\n\r\nOn turning, at the limit of his walk, he found himself almost face to\r\nface with two persons, who were coming along in silent companionship;\r\ntheir appearance interested him. The one was a man of fifty, grizzled,\r\nhard featured, slightly bowed in the shoulders; he wore a grey felt hat\r\nwith a broad brim and a decent suit of broadcloth. With him was a girl\r\nof perhaps two-and-twenty, in a slate-coloured dress with very little\r\nornament, and a yellow straw hat of the shape originally appropriated to\r\nmales; her dark hair was cut short, and lay in innumerable crisp curls.\r\nFather and daughter, obviously. The girl, to a casual eye, was neither\r\npretty nor beautiful, but she had a grave and impressive face, with a\r\ncomplexion of ivory tone; her walk was gracefully modest, and she seemed\r\nto be enjoying the country air.\r\n\r\nJasper mused concerning them. When he had walked a few yards, he looked\r\nback; at the same moment the unknown man also turned his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where the deuce have I seen them--him and the girl too?\xe2\x80\x99 Milvain asked\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\nAnd before he reached home the recollection he sought flashed upon his\r\nmind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The Museum Reading-room, of course!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II. THE HOUSE OF YULE\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper, as he entered the room where his mother and Maud\r\nwere busy with plain needlework, \xe2\x80\x98I must have met Alfred Yule and his\r\ndaughter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How did you recognise them?\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Milvain inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I passed an old buffer and a pale-faced girl whom I know by sight at\r\nthe British Museum. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t near Yule\xe2\x80\x99s house, but they were taking a\r\nwalk.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They may have come already. When Miss Harrow was here last, she said\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cin about a fortnight.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No mistaking them for people of these parts, even if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nremembered their faces. Both of them are obvious dwellers in the valley\r\nof the shadow of books.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is Miss Yule such a fright then?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Maud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A fright! Not at all. A good example of the modern literary girl. I\r\nsuppose you have the oddest old-fashioned ideas of such people. No,\r\nI rather like the look of her. Simpatica, I should think, as that ass\r\nWhelpdale would say. A very delicate, pure complexion, though morbid;\r\nnice eyes; figure not spoilt yet. But of course I may be wrong about\r\ntheir identity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nLater in the afternoon Jasper\xe2\x80\x99s conjecture was rendered a certainty.\r\nMaud had walked to Wattleborough, where she would meet Dora on the\r\nlatter\xe2\x80\x99s return from her teaching, and Mrs Milvain sat alone, in a\r\nmood of depression; there was a ring at the door-bell, and the servant\r\nadmitted Miss Harrow.\r\n\r\nThis lady acted as housekeeper to Mr John Yule, a wealthy resident in\r\nthis neighbourhood; she was the sister of his deceased wife--a thin,\r\nsoft-speaking, kindly woman of forty-five. The greater part of her life\r\nshe had spent as a governess; her position now was more agreeable, and\r\nthe removal of her anxiety about the future had developed qualities of\r\ncheerfulness which formerly no one would have suspected her to possess.\r\nThe acquaintance between Mrs Milvain and her was only of twelve months\xe2\x80\x99\r\nstanding; prior to that, Mr Yule had inhabited a house at the end of\r\nWattleborough remote from Finden.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Our London visitors came yesterday,\xe2\x80\x99 she began by saying.\r\n\r\nMrs Milvain mentioned her son\xe2\x80\x99s encounter an hour or two ago.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No doubt it was they,\xe2\x80\x99 said the visitor. \xe2\x80\x98Mrs Yule hasn\xe2\x80\x99t come; I\r\nhardly expected she would, you know. So very unfortunate when there are\r\ndifficulties of that kind, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe smiled confidentially.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The poor girl must feel it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Milvain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid she does. Of course it narrows the circle of her friends at\r\nhome. She\xe2\x80\x99s a sweet girl, and I should so like you to meet her. Do come\r\nand have tea with us to-morrow afternoon, will you? Or would it be too\r\nmuch for you just now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you let the girls call? And then perhaps Miss Yule will be so good\r\nas to come and see me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wonder whether Mr Milvain would like to meet her father? I have\r\nthought that perhaps it might be some advantage to him. Alfred is so\r\nclosely connected with literary people, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feel sure he would be glad,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Mrs Milvain. \xe2\x80\x98But--what of\r\nJasper\xe2\x80\x99s friendship with Mrs Edmund Yule and the Reardons? Mightn\xe2\x80\x99t it\r\nbe a little awkward?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think so, unless he himself felt it so. There would be no\r\nneed to mention that, I should say. And, really, it would be so much\r\nbetter if those estrangements came to an end. John makes no scruple of\r\nspeaking freely about everyone, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t think Alfred regards Mrs\r\nEdmund with any serious unkindness. If Mr Milvain would walk over with\r\nthe young ladies to-morrow, it would be very pleasant.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I think I may promise that he will. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t know where he\r\nis at this moment. We don\xe2\x80\x99t see very much of him, except at meals.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He won\xe2\x80\x99t be with you much longer, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps a week.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBefore Miss Harrow\xe2\x80\x99s departure Maud and Dora reached home. They were\r\ncurious to see the young lady from the valley of the shadow of books,\r\nand gladly accepted the invitation offered them.\r\n\r\nThey set out on the following afternoon in their brother\xe2\x80\x99s company. It\r\nwas only a quarter of an hour\xe2\x80\x99s walk to Mr Yule\xe2\x80\x99s habitation, a small\r\nhouse in a large garden. Jasper was coming hither for the first time;\r\nhis sisters now and then visited Miss Harrow, but very rarely saw Mr\r\nYule himself who made no secret of the fact that he cared little for\r\nfemale society. In Wattleborough and the neighbourhood opinions varied\r\ngreatly as to this gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s character, but women seldom spoke\r\nvery favourably of him. Miss Harrow was reticent concerning her\r\nbrother-in-law; no one, however, had any reason to believe that she\r\nfound life under his roof disagreeable. That she lived with him at all\r\nwas of course occasionally matter for comment, certain Wattleborough\r\nladies having their doubts regarding the position of a deceased wife\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsister under such circumstances; but no one was seriously exercised\r\nabout the relations between this sober lady of forty-five and a man of\r\nsixty-three in broken health.\r\n\r\nA word of the family history.\r\n\r\nJohn, Alfred, and Edmund Yule were the sons of a Wattleborough\r\nstationer. Each was well educated, up to the age of seventeen, at the\r\ntown\xe2\x80\x99s grammar school. The eldest, who was a hot-headed lad, but showed\r\ncapacities for business, worked at first with his father, endeavouring\r\nto add a bookselling department to the trade in stationery; but the life\r\nof home was not much to his taste, and at one-and-twenty he obtained a\r\nclerk\xe2\x80\x99s place in the office of a London newspaper. Three years after,\r\nhis father died, and the small patrimony which fell to him he used\r\nin making himself practically acquainted with the details of paper\r\nmanufacture, his aim being to establish himself in partnership with an\r\nacquaintance who had started a small paper-mill in Hertfordshire.\r\n\r\nHis speculation succeeded, and as years went on he became a thriving\r\nmanufacturer. His brother Alfred, in the meantime, had drifted from work\r\nat a London bookseller\xe2\x80\x99s into the modern Grub Street, his adventures in\r\nwhich region will concern us hereafter.\r\n\r\nEdmund carried on the Wattleborough business, but with small success.\r\nBetween him and his eldest brother existed a good deal of affection,\r\nand in the end John offered him a share in his flourishing paper works;\r\nwhereupon Edmund married, deeming himself well established for life. But\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s temper was a difficult one; Edmund and he quarrelled, parted; and\r\nwhen the younger died, aged about forty, he left but moderate provision\r\nfor his widow and two children.\r\n\r\nOnly when he had reached middle age did John marry; the experiment\r\ncould not be called successful, and Mrs Yule died three years later,\r\nchildless.\r\n\r\nAt fifty-four John Yule retired from active business; he came back to\r\nthe scenes of his early life, and began to take an important part in the\r\nmunicipal affairs of Wattleborough. He was then a remarkably robust man,\r\nfond of out-of-door exercise; he made it one of his chief efforts to\r\nencourage the local Volunteer movement, the cricket and football clubs,\r\npublic sports of every kind, showing no sympathy whatever with those\r\npersons who wished to establish free libraries, lectures, and the like.\r\nAt his own expense he built for the Volunteers a handsome drill-shed;\r\nhe founded a public gymnasium; and finally he allowed it to be rumoured\r\nthat he was going to present the town with a park. But by presuming too\r\nfar upon the bodily vigour which prompted these activities, he passed of\r\na sudden into the state of a confirmed invalid. On an autumn expedition\r\nin the Hebrides he slept one night under the open sky, with the result\r\nthat he had an all but fatal attack of rheumatic fever. After that,\r\nthough the direction of his interests was unchanged, he could no longer\r\nset the example to Wattleborough youth of muscular manliness. The\r\ninfliction did not improve his temper; for the next year or two he was\r\nconstantly at warfare with one or other of his colleagues and friends,\r\nill brooking that the familiar control of various local interests should\r\nfall out of his hands. But before long he appeared to resign himself\r\nto his fate, and at present Wattleborough saw little of him. It seemed\r\nlikely that he might still found the park which was to bear his name;\r\nbut perhaps it would only be done in consequence of directions in his\r\nwill. It was believed that he could not live much longer.\r\n\r\nWith his kinsfolk he held very little communication. Alfred Yule, a\r\nbattered man of letters, had visited Wattleborough only twice (including\r\nthe present occasion) since John\xe2\x80\x99s return hither. Mrs Edmund Yule, with\r\nher daughter--now Mrs Reardon--had been only once, three years ago.\r\nThese two families, as you have heard, were not on terms of amity with\r\neach other, owing to difficulties between Mrs Alfred and Mrs Edmund; but\r\nJohn seemed to regard both impartially. Perhaps the only real warmth of\r\nfeeling he had ever known was bestowed upon Edmund, and Miss Harrow had\r\nremarked that he spoke with somewhat more interest of Edmund\xe2\x80\x99s daughter,\r\nAmy, than of Alfred\xe2\x80\x99s daughter, Marian. But it was doubtful whether the\r\nsudden disappearance from the earth of all his relatives would greatly\r\nhave troubled him. He lived a life of curious self-absorption, reading\r\nnewspapers (little else), and talking with old friends who had stuck to\r\nhim in spite of his irascibility.\r\n\r\nMiss Harrow received her visitors in a small and soberly furnished\r\ndrawing-room. She was nervous, probably because of Jasper Milvain, whom\r\nshe had met but once--last spring--and who on that occasion had struck\r\nher as an alarmingly modern young man. In the shadow of a window-curtain\r\nsat a slight, simply-dressed girl, whose short curly hair and thoughtful\r\ncountenance Jasper again recognised. When it was his turn to be\r\npresented to Miss Yule, he saw that she doubted for an instant whether\r\nor not to give her hand; yet she decided to do so, and there was\r\nsomething very pleasant to him in its warm softness. She smiled with a\r\nslight embarrassment, meeting his look only for a second.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have seen you several times, Miss Yule,\xe2\x80\x99 he said in a friendly way,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98though without knowing your name. It was under the great dome.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe laughed, readily understanding his phrase.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am there very often,\xe2\x80\x99 was her reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What great dome?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Miss Harrow, with surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That of the British Museum Reading-room,\xe2\x80\x99 explained Jasper; \xe2\x80\x98known to\r\nsome of us as the valley of the shadow of books. People who often work\r\nthere necessarily get to know each other by sight.\r\n\r\nIn the same way I knew Miss Yule\xe2\x80\x99s father when I happened to pass him in\r\nthe road yesterday.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe three girls began to converse together, perforce of trivialities.\r\nMarian Yule spoke in rather slow tones, thoughtfully, gently; she had\r\nlinked her fingers, and laid her hands, palms downwards, upon her lap--a\r\nnervous action. Her accent was pure, unpretentious; and she used none of\r\nthe fashionable turns of speech which would have suggested the habit of\r\nintercourse with distinctly metropolitan society.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must wonder how we exist in this out-of-the-way place,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked\r\nMaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rather, I envy you,\xe2\x80\x99 Marian answered, with a slight emphasis.\r\n\r\nThe door opened, and Alfred Yule presented himself. He was tall, and his\r\nhead seemed a disproportionate culmination to his meagre body, it was so\r\nlarge and massively featured. Intellect and uncertainty of temper were\r\nequally marked upon his visage; his brows were knitted in a permanent\r\nexpression of severity. He had thin, smooth hair, grizzled whiskers, a\r\nshaven chin. In the multitudinous wrinkles of his face lay a history of\r\nlaborious and stormy life; one readily divined in him a struggling and\r\nembittered man. Though he looked older than his years, he had by no\r\nmeans the appearance of being beyond the ripeness of his mental vigour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It pleases me to meet you, Mr Milvain,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, as he stretched out\r\nhis bony hand. \xe2\x80\x98Your name reminds me of a paper in The Wayside a month\r\nor two ago, which you will perhaps allow a veteran to say was not ill\r\ndone.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am grateful to you for noticing it,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jasper.\r\n\r\nThere was positively a touch of visible warmth upon his cheek. The\r\nallusion had come so unexpectedly that it caused him keen pleasure.\r\n\r\nMr Yule seated himself awkwardly, crossed his legs, and began to stroke\r\nthe back of his left hand, which lay on his knee. He seemed to have\r\nnothing more to say at present, and allowed Miss Harrow and the girls to\r\nsupport conversation. Jasper listened with a smile for a minute or two,\r\nthen he addressed the veteran.\xe2\x80\x99Have you seen The Study this week, Mr\r\nYule?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you notice that it contains a very favourable review of a novel\r\nwhich was tremendously abused in the same columns three weeks ago?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Yule started, but Jasper could perceive at once that his emotion was\r\nnot disagreeable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t say so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. The novel is Miss Hawk\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cOn the Boards.\xe2\x80\x9d How will the editor get\r\nout of this?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98H\xe2\x80\x99m! Of course Mr Fadge is not immediately responsible; but it\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\nunpleasant for him, decidedly unpleasant.\xe2\x80\x99 He smiled grimly. \xe2\x80\x98You hear\r\nthis, Marian?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How is it explained, father?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98May be accident, of course; but--well, there\xe2\x80\x99s no knowing. I think\r\nit very likely this will be the end of Mr Fadge\xe2\x80\x99s tenure of office.\r\nRackett, the proprietor, only wants a plausible excuse for making a\r\nchange. The paper has been going downhill for the last year; I know of\r\ntwo publishing houses who have withdrawn their advertising from it, and\r\nwho never send their books for review. Everyone foresaw that kind of\r\nthing from the day Mr Fadge became editor. The tone of his paragraphs\r\nhas been detestable. Two reviews of the same novel, eh? And\r\ndiametrically opposed? Ha! Ha!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nGradually he had passed from quiet appreciation of the joke to\r\nundisguised mirth and pleasure. His utterance of the name \xe2\x80\x98Mr Fadge\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsufficiently intimated that he had some cause of personal discontent\r\nwith the editor of The Study.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The author,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Milvain, \xe2\x80\x98ought to make a good thing out of\r\nthis.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will, no doubt. Ought to write at once to the papers, calling attention\r\nto this sample of critical impartiality. Ha! ha!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe rose and went to the window, where for several minutes he stood\r\ngazing at vacancy, the same grim smile still on his face. Jasper in the\r\nmeantime amused the ladies (his sisters had heard him on the subject\r\nalready) with a description of the two antagonistic notices. But he\r\ndid not trust himself to express so freely as he had done at home his\r\nopinion of reviewing in general; it was more than probable that both\r\nYule and his daughter did a good deal of such work.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Suppose we go into the garden,\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Miss Harrow, presently. \xe2\x80\x98It\r\nseems a shame to sit indoors on such a lovely afternoon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHitherto there had been no mention of the master of the house. But Mr\r\nYule now remarked to Jasper:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My brother would be glad if you would come and have a word with him. He\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t quite well enough to leave his room to-day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSo, as the ladies went gardenwards, Jasper followed the man of letters\r\nupstairs to a room on the first floor. Here, in a deep cane chair, which\r\nwas placed by the open window, sat John Yule. He was completely dressed,\r\nsave that instead of coat he wore a dressing-gown. The facial\r\nlikeness between him and his brother was very strong, but John\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwould universally have been judged the finer countenance; illness\r\nnotwithstanding, he had a complexion which contrasted in its pure colour\r\nwith Alfred\xe2\x80\x99s parchmenty skin, and there was more finish about his\r\nfeatures. His abundant hair was reddish, his long moustache and trimmed\r\nbeard a lighter shade of the same hue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So you too are in league with the doctors,\xe2\x80\x99 was his bluff greeting,\r\nas he held a hand to the young man and inspected him with a look of\r\nslighting good-nature.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, that certainly is one way of regarding the literary profession,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nadmitted Jasper, who had heard enough of John\xe2\x80\x99s way of thinking to\r\nunderstand the remark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A young fellow with all the world before him, too. Hang it, Mr Milvain,\r\nis there no less pernicious work you can turn your hand to?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid not, Mr Yule. After all, you know, you must be held in a\r\nmeasure responsible for my depravity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I understand that you have devoted most of your life to the making\r\nof paper. If that article were not so cheap and so abundant, people\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have so much temptation to scribble.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAlfred Yule uttered a short laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you are cornered, John.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish,\xe2\x80\x99 answered John, \xe2\x80\x98that you were both condemned to write on such\r\npaper as I chiefly made; it was a special kind of whitey-brown, used by\r\nshopkeepers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe chuckled inwardly, and at the same time reached out for a box of\r\ncigarettes on a table near him. His brother and Jasper each took one as\r\nhe offered them, and began to smoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would like to see literary production come entirely to an end?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Milvain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should like to see the business of literature abolished.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a distinction, of course. But, on the whole, I should say that\r\neven the business serves a good purpose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What purpose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It helps to spread civilisation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Civilisation!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed John, scornfully. \xe2\x80\x98What do you mean by\r\ncivilisation? Do you call it civilising men to make them weak, flabby\r\ncreatures, with ruined eyes and dyspeptic stomachs? Who is it that\r\nreads most of the stuff that\xe2\x80\x99s poured out daily by the ton from the\r\nprinting-press? Just the men and women who ought to spend their leisure\r\nhours in open-air exercise; the people who earn their bread by sedentary\r\npursuits, and who need to live as soon as they are free from the desk\r\nor the counter, not to moon over small print. Your Board schools, your\r\npopular press, your spread of education! Machinery for ruining the\r\ncountry, that\xe2\x80\x99s what I call it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have done a good deal, I think, to counteract those influences in\r\nWattleborough.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope so; and if only I had kept the use of my limbs I\xe2\x80\x99d have done a\r\ngood deal more. I have an idea of offering substantial prizes to men\r\nand women engaged in sedentary work who take an oath to abstain from all\r\nreading, and keep it for a certain number of years. There\xe2\x80\x99s a good deal\r\nmore need for that than for abstinence from strong liquor. If I could\r\nhave had my way I would have revived prize-fighting.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis brother laughed with contemptuous impatience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would doubtless like to see military conscription introduced into\r\nEngland?\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course I should! You talk of civilising; there\xe2\x80\x99s no such way of\r\ncivilising the masses of the people as by fixed military service. Before\r\nmental training must come training of the body. Go about the Continent,\r\nand see the effect of military service on loutish peasants and the\r\nlowest classes of town population. Do you know why it isn\xe2\x80\x99t even more\r\nsuccessful? Because the damnable education movement interferes. If\r\nGermany would shut up her schools and universities for the next quarter\r\nof a century and go ahead like blazes with military training there\xe2\x80\x99d be\r\na nation such as the world has never seen. After that, they might begin\r\na little book-teaching again--say an hour and a half a day for everyone\r\nabove nine years old. Do you suppose, Mr Milvain, that society is going\r\nto be reformed by you people who write for money? Why, you are the very\r\nfirst class that will be swept from the face of the earth as soon as the\r\nreformation really begins!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAlfred puffed at his cigarette. His thoughts were occupied with Mr\r\nFadge and The Study. He was considering whether he could aid in bringing\r\npublic contempt upon that literary organ and its editor. Milvain\r\nlistened to the elder man\xe2\x80\x99s diatribe with much amusement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You, now,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued John, \xe2\x80\x98what do you write about?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing in particular. I make a salable page or two out of whatever\r\nstrikes my fancy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Exactly! You don\xe2\x80\x99t even pretend that you\xe2\x80\x99ve got anything to say. You\r\nlive by inducing people to give themselves mental indigestion--and\r\nbodily, too, for that matter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know, Mr Yule, that you have suggested a capital idea to me? If\r\nI were to take up your views, I think it isn\xe2\x80\x99t at all unlikely that\r\nI might make a good thing of writing against writing. It should be my\r\nliterary specialty to rail against literature. The reading public should\r\npay me for telling them that they oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to read. I must think it\r\nover.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Carlyle has anticipated you,\xe2\x80\x99 threw in Alfred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, but in an antiquated way. I would base my polemic on the newest\r\nphilosophy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe developed the idea facetiously, whilst John regarded him as he might\r\nhave watched a performing monkey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There again! your new philosophy!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the invalid. \xe2\x80\x98Why, it\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t even wholesome stuff, the kind of reading that most of you\r\nforce on the public. Now there\xe2\x80\x99s the man who has married one of my\r\nnieces--poor lass! Reardon, his name is. You know him, I dare say.\r\nJust for curiosity I had a look at one of his books; it was called \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nOptimist.\xe2\x80\x9d Of all the morbid trash I ever saw, that beat everything. I\r\nthought of writing him a letter, advising a couple of anti-bilious pills\r\nbefore bedtime for a few weeks.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper glanced at Alfred Yule, who wore a look of indifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That man deserves penal servitude in my opinion,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued John. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nnot sure that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t my duty to offer him a couple of hundred a year\r\non condition that he writes no more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMilvain, with a clear vision of his friend in London, burst into\r\nlaughter. But at that point Alfred rose from his chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall we rejoin the ladies?\xe2\x80\x99 he said, with a certain pedantry\r\nof phrase and manner which often characterised him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Think over your ways whilst you\xe2\x80\x99re still young,\xe2\x80\x99 said John as he shook\r\nhands with his visitor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your brother speaks quite seriously, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper remarked when\r\nhe was in the garden with Alfred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think so. It\xe2\x80\x99s amusing now and then, but gets rather tiresome when\r\nyou hear it often. By-the-bye, you are not personally acquainted with Mr\r\nFadge?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t even know his name until you mentioned it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The most malicious man in the literary world. There\xe2\x80\x99s no\r\nuncharitableness in feeling a certain pleasure when he gets into a\r\nscrape. I could tell you incredible stories about him; but that kind of\r\nthing is probably as little to your taste as it is to mine.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMiss Harrow and her companions, having caught sight of the pair, came\r\ntowards them. Tea was to be brought out into the garden.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So you can sit with us and smoke, if you like,\xe2\x80\x99 said Miss Harrow to\r\nAlfred. \xe2\x80\x98You are never quite at your ease, I think, without a pipe.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut the man of letters was too preoccupied for society. In a few minutes\r\nhe begged that the ladies would excuse his withdrawing; he had two or\r\nthree letters to write before post-time, which was early at Finden.\r\n\r\nJasper, relieved by the veteran\xe2\x80\x99s departure, began at once to make\r\nhimself very agreeable company. When he chose to lay aside the topic of\r\nhis own difficulties and ambitions, he could converse with a spontaneous\r\ngaiety which readily won the good-will of listeners. Naturally\r\nhe addressed himself very often to Marian Yule, whose attention\r\ncomplimented him. She said little, and evidently was at no time a free\r\ntalker, but the smile on her face indicated a mood of quiet enjoyment.\r\nWhen her eyes wandered, it was to rest on the beauties of the garden,\r\nthe moving patches of golden sunshine, the forms of gleaming cloud.\r\nJasper liked to observe her as she turned her head: there seemed to him\r\na particular grace in the movement; her head and neck were admirably\r\nformed, and the short hair drew attention to this.\r\n\r\nIt was agreed that Miss Harrow and Marian should come on the second\r\nday after to have tea with the Milvains. And when Jasper took leave of\r\nAlfred Yule, the latter expressed a wish that they might have a walk\r\ntogether one of these mornings.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III. HOLIDAY\r\n\r\nJasper\xe2\x80\x99s favourite walk led him to a spot distant perhaps a mile and a\r\nhalf from home. From a tract of common he turned into a short lane which\r\ncrossed the Great Western railway, and thence by a stile into certain\r\nmeadows forming a compact little valley. One recommendation of this\r\nretreat was that it lay sheltered from all winds; to Jasper a wind was\r\nobjectionable. Along the bottom ran a clear, shallow stream, overhung\r\nwith elder and hawthorn bushes; and close by the wooden bridge which\r\nspanned it was a great ash tree, making shadow for cows and sheep when\r\nthe sun lay hot upon the open field. It was rare for anyone to come\r\nalong this path, save farm labourers morning and evening.\r\n\r\nBut to-day--the afternoon that followed his visit to John Yule\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse--he saw from a distance that his lounging-place on the wooden\r\nbridge was occupied. Someone else had discovered the pleasure there was\r\nin watching the sun-flecked sparkle of the water as it flowed over the\r\nclean sand and stones. A girl in a yellow-straw hat; yes, and precisely\r\nthe person he had hoped, at the first glance, that it might be. He\r\nmade no haste as he drew nearer on the descending path. At length his\r\nfootstep was heard; Marian Yule turned her head and clearly recognised\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nShe assumed an upright position, letting one of her hands rest upon\r\nthe rail. After the exchange of ordinary greetings, Jasper leaned back\r\nagainst the same support and showed himself disposed for talk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I was here late in the spring,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98this ash was only just\r\nbudding, though everything else seemed in full leaf.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98An ash, is it?\xe2\x80\x99 murmured Marian. \xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know. I think an oak is the\r\nonly tree I can distinguish. Yet,\xe2\x80\x99 she added quickly, \xe2\x80\x98I knew that the\r\nash was late; some lines of Tennyson come to my memory.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which are those?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x98Delaying, as the tender ash delays\r\n     To clothe herself when all the woods are green,\r\n\r\nsomewhere in the \xe2\x80\x9cIdylls.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t remember; so I won\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to--though I should do so as a\r\nrule.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe looked at him oddly, and seemed about to laugh, yet did not.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have had little experience of the country?\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper continued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very little. You, I think, have known it from childhood?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In a sort of way. I was born in Wattleborough, and my people have\r\nalways lived here. But I am not very rural in temperament. I have really\r\nno friends here; either they have lost interest in me, or I in them.\r\nWhat do you think of the girls, my sisters?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe question, though put with perfect simplicity, was embarrassing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are tolerably intellectual,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper went on, when he saw that it\r\nwould be difficult for her to answer. \xe2\x80\x98I want to persuade them to try\r\ntheir hands at literary work of some kind or other. They give lessons,\r\nand both hate it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Would literary work be less--burdensome?\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, without looking\r\nat him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Rather more so, you think?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It depends, of course, on--on several things.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper agreed. \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think they have any marked faculty\r\nfor such work; but as they certainly haven\xe2\x80\x99t for teaching, that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmatter. It\xe2\x80\x99s a question of learning a business. I am going through my\r\napprenticeship, and find it a long affair. Money would shorten it, and,\r\nunfortunately, I have none.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, turning her eyes upon the stream, \xe2\x80\x98money is a help\r\nin everything.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Without it, one spends the best part of one\xe2\x80\x99s life in toiling for that\r\nfirst foothold which money could at once purchase. To have money is\r\nbecoming of more and more importance in a literary career; principally\r\nbecause to have money is to have friends. Year by year, such influence\r\ngrows of more account. A lucky man will still occasionally succeed by\r\ndint of his own honest perseverance, but the chances are dead against\r\nanyone who can\xe2\x80\x99t make private interest with influential people; his work\r\nis simply overwhelmed by that of the men who have better opportunities.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think that, even to-day, really good work will sooner or\r\nlater be recognised?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Later, rather than sooner; and very likely the man can\xe2\x80\x99t wait; he\r\nstarves in the meantime. You understand that I am not speaking of\r\ngenius; I mean marketable literary work. The quantity turned out is\r\nso great that there\xe2\x80\x99s no hope for the special attention of the public\r\nunless one can afford to advertise hugely. Take the instance of a\r\nsuccessful all-round man of letters; take Ralph Warbury, whose name\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll see in the first magazine you happen to open. But perhaps he is a\r\nfriend of yours?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh no!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t going to abuse him. I was only going to ask: Is there\r\nany quality which distinguishes his work from that of twenty struggling\r\nwriters one could name? Of course not. He\xe2\x80\x99s a clever, prolific man; so\r\nare they. But he began with money and friends; he came from Oxford into\r\nthe thick of advertised people; his name was mentioned in print six\r\ntimes a week before he had written a dozen articles. This kind of thing\r\nwill become the rule. Men won\xe2\x80\x99t succeed in literature that they may\r\nget into society, but will get into society that they may succeed in\r\nliterature.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I know it is true,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a friend of mine who writes novels,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper pursued. \xe2\x80\x98His\r\nbooks are not works of genius, but they are glaringly distinct from the\r\nordinary circulating novel. Well, after one or two attempts, he made\r\nhalf a success; that is to say, the publishers brought out a second\r\nedition of the book in a few months. There was his opportunity. But he\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t use it; he had no friends, because he had no money. A book of\r\nhalf that merit, if written by a man in the position of Warbury when\r\nhe started, would have established the reputation of a lifetime. His\r\ninfluential friends would have referred to it in leaders, in magazine\r\narticles, in speeches, in sermons. It would have run through numerous\r\neditions, and the author would have had nothing to do but to write\r\nanother book and demand his price. But the novel I\xe2\x80\x99m speaking of was\r\npractically forgotten a year after its appearance; it was whelmed\r\nbeneath the flood of next season\xe2\x80\x99s literature.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian urged a hesitating objection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, under the circumstances, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it in the author\xe2\x80\x99s power to make\r\nfriends? Was money really indispensable?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why, yes--because he chose to marry. As a bachelor he might possibly\r\nhave got into the right circles, though his character would in any case\r\nhave made it difficult for him to curry favour.\r\n\r\nBut as a married man, without means, the situation was hopeless. Once\r\nmarried you must live up to the standard of the society you frequent;\r\nyou can\xe2\x80\x99t be entertained without entertaining in return. Now if his wife\r\nhad brought him only a couple of thousand pounds all might have been\r\nwell. I should have advised him, in sober seriousness, to live for two\r\nyears at the rate of a thousand a year. At the end of that time he would\r\nhave been earning enough to continue at pretty much the same rate of\r\nexpenditure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I ought rather to say that the average man of letters would be\r\nable to do that. As for Reardon--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe stopped. The name had escaped him unawares.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Reardon?\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, looking up. \xe2\x80\x98You are speaking of him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have betrayed myself Miss Yule.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what does it matter? You have only spoken in his favour.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feared the name might affect you disagreeably.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian delayed her reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is true,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, \xe2\x80\x98we are not on friendly terms with my cousin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfamily. I have never met Mr Reardon. But I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like you to think\r\nthat the mention of his name is disagreeable to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It made me slightly uncomfortable yesterday--the fact that I am well\r\nacquainted with Mrs Edmund Yule, and that Reardon is my friend. Yet\r\nI didn\xe2\x80\x99t see why that should prevent my making your father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nacquaintance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely not. I shall say nothing about it; I mean, as you uttered the\r\nname unintentionally.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a pause in the dialogue. They had been speaking almost\r\nconfidentially, and Marian seemed to become suddenly aware of an oddness\r\nin the situation. She turned towards the uphill path, as if thinking of\r\nresuming her walk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are tired of standing still,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper. \xe2\x80\x98May I walk back a part\r\nof the way with you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you; I shall be glad.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey went on for a few minutes in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you published anything with your signature, Miss Yule?\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper at\r\nlength inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing. I only help father a little.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe silence that again followed was broken this time by Marian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When you chanced to mention Mr Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s name,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, with a\r\ndiffident smile in which lay that suggestion of humour so delightful\r\nupon a woman\xe2\x80\x99s face, \xe2\x80\x98you were going to say something more about him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only that--\xe2\x80\x99 he broke off and laughed. \xe2\x80\x98Now, how boyish it was, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nit? I remember doing just the same thing once when I came home\r\nfrom school and had an exciting story to tell, with preservation of\r\nanonymities. Of course I blurted out a name in the first minute or two,\r\nto my father\xe2\x80\x99s great amusement. He told me that I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t the diplomatic\r\ncharacter. I have been trying to acquire it ever since.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But why?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s one of the essentials of success in any kind of public life. And\r\nI mean to succeed, you know. I feel that I am one of the men who do\r\nsucceed. But I beg your pardon; you asked me a question. Really, I was\r\nonly going to say of Reardon what I had said before: that he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t the\r\ntact requisite for acquiring popularity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I may hope that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t his marriage with my cousin which has\r\nproved a fatal misfortune?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In no case,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Milvain, averting his look, \xe2\x80\x98would he have used\r\nhis advantages.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And now? Do you think he has but poor prospects?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish I could see any chance of his being estimated at his right\r\nvalue. It\xe2\x80\x99s very hard to say what is before him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I knew my cousin Amy when we were children,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, presently.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She gave promise of beauty.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, she is beautiful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And--the kind of woman to be of help to such a husband?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hardly know how to answer, Miss Yule,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper, looking frankly\r\nat her. \xe2\x80\x98Perhaps I had better say that it\xe2\x80\x99s unfortunate they are poor.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian cast down her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To whom isn\xe2\x80\x99t it a misfortune?\xe2\x80\x99 pursued her companion. \xe2\x80\x98Poverty is the\r\nroot of all social ills; its existence accounts even for the ills that\r\narise from wealth. The poor man is a man labouring in fetters. I declare\r\nthere is no word in our language which sounds so hideous to me as\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoverty.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShortly after this they came to the bridge over the railway line. Jasper\r\nlooked at his watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you indulge me in a piece of childishness?\xe2\x80\x99 he said. \xe2\x80\x98In less than\r\nfive minutes a London express goes by; I have often watched it here, and\r\nit amuses me. Would it weary you to wait?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should like to,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied with a laugh.\r\n\r\nThe line ran along a deep cutting, from either side of which grew hazel\r\nbushes and a few larger trees. Leaning upon the parapet of the bridge,\r\nJasper kept his eye in the westward direction, where the gleaming rails\r\nwere visible for more than a mile. Suddenly he raised his finger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You hear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian had just caught the far-off sound of the train. She looked\r\neagerly, and in a few moments saw it approaching. The front of the\r\nengine blackened nearer and nearer, coming on with dread force and\r\nspeed. A blinding rush, and there burst against the bridge a great\r\nvolley of sunlit steam. Milvain and his companion ran to the opposite\r\nparapet, but already the whole train had emerged, and in a few seconds\r\nit had disappeared round a sharp curve. The leafy branches that grew out\r\nover the line swayed violently backwards and forwards in the perturbed\r\nair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I were ten years younger,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper, laughing, \xe2\x80\x98I should say that\r\nwas jolly! It enspirits me. It makes me feel eager to go back and plunge\r\ninto the fight again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Upon me it has just the opposite effect,\xe2\x80\x99 fell from Marian, in very low\r\ntones.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, don\xe2\x80\x99t say that! Well, it only means that you haven\xe2\x80\x99t had enough\r\nholiday yet. I have been in the country more than a week; a few days\r\nmore and I must be off. How long do you think of staying?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not much more than a week, I think.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By-the-bye, you are coming to have tea with us to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper\r\nremarked a propos of nothing. Then he returned to another subject that\r\nwas in his thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was by a train like that that I first went up to London. Not really\r\nthe first time; I mean when I went to live there, seven years ago.\r\nWhat spirits I was in! A boy of eighteen going to live independently in\r\nLondon; think of it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You went straight from school?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was for two years at Redmayne College after leaving Wattleborough\r\nGrammar School. Then my father died, and I spent nearly half a year at\r\nhome. I was meant to be a teacher, but the prospect of entering a school\r\nby no means appealed to me. A friend of mine was studying in London for\r\nsome Civil Service exam., so I declared that I would go and do the same\r\nthing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you succeed?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not I! I never worked properly for that kind of thing. I read\r\nvoraciously, and got to know London. I might have gone to the dogs, you\r\nknow; but by when I had been in London a year a pretty clear purpose\r\nbegan to form in me. Strange to think that you were growing up there all\r\nthe time. I may have passed you in the street now and then.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I did at length see you at the British Museum, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey turned a corner of the road, and came full upon Marian\xe2\x80\x99s father,\r\nwho was walking in this direction with eyes fixed upon the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So here you are!\xe2\x80\x99 he exclaimed, looking at the girl, and for the moment\r\npaying no attention to Jasper. \xe2\x80\x98I wondered whether I should meet you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThen, more dryly, \xe2\x80\x98How do you do, Mr Milvain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn a tone of easy indifference Jasper explained how he came to be\r\naccompanying Miss Yule.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall I walk on with you, father?\xe2\x80\x99 Marian asked, scrutinising his\r\nrugged features.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just as you please; I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that I should have gone much further.\r\nBut we might take another way back.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper readily adapted himself to the wish he discerned in Mr Yule; at\r\nonce he offered leave-taking in the most natural way. Nothing was said\r\non either side about another meeting.\r\n\r\nThe young man proceeded homewards, but, on arriving, did not at once\r\nenter the house. Behind the garden was a field used for the grazing of\r\nhorses; he entered it by the unfastened gate, and strolled idly hither\r\nand thither, now and then standing to observe a poor worn-out beast, all\r\nskin and bone, which had presumably been sent here in the hope that a\r\nlittle more labour might still be exacted from it if it were suffered\r\nto repose for a few weeks. There were sores upon its back and legs; it\r\nstood in a fixed attitude of despondency, just flicking away troublesome\r\nflies with its grizzled tail.\r\n\r\nIt was tea-time when he went in. Maud was not at home, and Mrs Milvain,\r\ntormented by a familiar headache, kept her room; so Jasper and Dora sat\r\ndown together. Each had an open book on the table; throughout the meal\r\nthey exchanged only a few words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Going to play a little?\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper suggested when they had gone into the\r\nsitting-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you like.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe sat down at the piano, whilst her brother lay on the sofa, his\r\nhands clasped beneath his head. Dora did not play badly, but an\r\nabsentmindedness which was commonly observable in her had its effect\r\nupon the music. She at length broke off idly in the middle of a passage,\r\nand began to linger on careless chords. Then, without turning her head,\r\nshe asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Were you serious in what you said about writing storybooks?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite. I see no reason why you shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do something in that way. But\r\nI tell you what; when I get back, I\xe2\x80\x99ll inquire into the state of the\r\nmarket. I know a man who was once engaged at Jolly & Monk\xe2\x80\x99s--the chief\r\npublishers of that kind of thing, you know; I must look him up--what a\r\nmistake it is to neglect any acquaintance!--and get some information out\r\nof him. But it\xe2\x80\x99s obvious what an immense field there is for anyone who\r\ncan just hit the taste of the new generation of Board school children.\r\nMustn\xe2\x80\x99t be too goody-goody; that kind of thing is falling out of date.\r\nBut you\xe2\x80\x99d have to cultivate a particular kind of vulgarity.\r\n\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s an idea, by-the-bye. I\xe2\x80\x99ll write a paper on the characteristics\r\nof that new generation; it may bring me a few guineas, and it would be a\r\nhelp to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what do you know about the subject?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Dora doubtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a comical question! It is my business to know something about\r\nevery subject--or to know where to get the knowledge.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Dora, after a pause, \xe2\x80\x98there\xe2\x80\x99s no doubt Maud and I ought\r\nto think very seriously about the future. You are aware, Jasper, that\r\nmother has not been able to save a penny of her income.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t see how she could have done. Of course I know what you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nthinking; but for me, it would have been possible. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind\r\nconfessing to you that the thought troubles me a little now and then;\r\nI shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like to see you two going off governessing in strangers\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhouses. All I can say is, that I am very honestly working for the end\r\nwhich I am convinced will be most profitable.\r\n\r\nI shall not desert you; you needn\xe2\x80\x99t fear that. But just put your heads\r\ntogether, and cultivate your writing faculty. Suppose you could both\r\ntogether earn about a hundred a year in Grub Street, it would be better\r\nthan governessing; wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You say you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what Miss Yule writes?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I know a little more about her than I did yesterday. I\xe2\x80\x99ve had an\r\nhour\xe2\x80\x99s talk with her this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Met her down in the Leggatt fields. I find she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t write\r\nindependently; just helps her father. What the help amounts to I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsay. There\xe2\x80\x99s something very attractive about her. She quoted a line or\r\ntwo of Tennyson; the first time I ever heard a woman speak blank verse\r\nwith any kind of decency.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She was walking alone?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. On the way back we met old Yule; he seemed rather grumpy, I\r\nthought. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think she\xe2\x80\x99s the kind of girl to make a paying business\r\nof literature. Her qualities are personal. And it\xe2\x80\x99s pretty clear to\r\nme that the valley of the shadow of books by no means agrees with her\r\ndisposition. Possibly old Yule is something of a tyrant.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He doesn\xe2\x80\x99t impress me very favourably. Do you think you will keep up\r\ntheir acquaintance in London?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can\xe2\x80\x99t say. I wonder what sort of a woman that mother really is? Can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe so very gross, I should think.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Miss Harrow knows nothing about her, except that she was a quite\r\nuneducated girl.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, dash it! by this time she must have got decent manners. Of course\r\nthere may be other objections. Mrs Reardon knows nothing against her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMidway in the following morning, as Jasper sat with a book in the\r\ngarden, he was surprised to see Alfred Yule enter by the gate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought,\xe2\x80\x99 began the visitor, who seemed in high spirits, \xe2\x80\x98that you\r\nmight like to see something I received this morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe unfolded a London evening paper, and indicated a long letter from\r\na casual correspondent. It was written by the authoress of \xe2\x80\x98On the\r\nBoards,\xe2\x80\x99 and drew attention, with much expenditure of witticism, to the\r\nconflicting notices of that book which had appeared in The Study. Jasper\r\nread the thing with laughing appreciation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just what one expected!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I have private letters on the subject,\xe2\x80\x99 added Mr Yule.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There has been something like a personal conflict between Fadge and the\r\nman who looks after the minor notices. Fadge, more so, charged the other\r\nman with a design to damage him and the paper. There\xe2\x80\x99s talk of legal\r\nproceedings. An immense joke!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe laughed in his peculiar croaking way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you feel disposed for a turn along the lanes, Mr Milvain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By all means.--There\xe2\x80\x99s my mother at the window; will you come in for a\r\nmoment?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWith a step of quite unusual sprightliness Mr Yule entered the house.\r\nHe could talk of but one subject, and Mrs Milvain had to listen to a\r\nlaboured account of the blunder just committed by The Study. It was\r\nAlfred\xe2\x80\x99s Yule\xe2\x80\x99s characteristic that he could do nothing lighthandedly.\r\nHe seemed always to converse with effort; he took a seat with stiff\r\nungainliness; he walked with a stumbling or sprawling gait.\r\n\r\nWhen he and Jasper set out for their ramble, his loquacity was in strong\r\ncontrast with the taciturn mood he had exhibited yesterday and the day\r\nbefore. He fell upon the general aspects of contemporary literature.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98... The evil of the time is the multiplication of ephemerides.
