The\r\ndoor of the flat was heard to close after him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let us go into the study, then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, again in rather a cold\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\nOn Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s desk were lying slips of blank paper. Edith, approaching on\r\ntiptoe with what was partly make believe, partly genuine, awe, looked at\r\nthe literary apparatus, then turned with a laugh to her friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How delightful it must be to sit down and write about people one has\r\ninvented! Ever since I have known you and Mr Reardon I have been tempted\r\nto try if I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t write a story.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how you can resist the temptation. I feel\r\nsure you could write books almost as clever as your husband\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no intention of trying.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t seem very well to-day, Amy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I think I am as well as usual.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe guessed that her husband was once more brought to a standstill, and\r\nthis darkened her humour again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One of my reasons for coming,\xe2\x80\x99 said Edith, \xe2\x80\x98was to beg and entreat and\r\nimplore you and Mr Reardon to dine with us next Wednesday. Now, don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nput on such a severe face! Are you engaged that evening?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; in the ordinary way. Edwin can\xe2\x80\x99t possibly leave his work.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But for one poor evening! It\xe2\x80\x99s such ages since we saw you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m very sorry. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think we shall ever be able to accept\r\ninvitations in future.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy spoke thus at the prompting of a sudden impulse. A minute ago, no\r\nsuch definite declaration was in her mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Edith. \xe2\x80\x98But why? Whatever do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We find that social engagements consume too much time,\xe2\x80\x99 Amy replied,\r\nher explanation just as much of an impromptu as the announcement had\r\nbeen. \xe2\x80\x98You see, one must either belong to society or not. Married people\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t accept an occasional invitation from friends and never do their\r\nsocial duty in return.\r\n\r\nWe have decided to withdraw altogether--at all events for the present. I\r\nshall see no one except my relatives.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEdith listened with a face of astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You won\xe2\x80\x99t even see ME?\xe2\x80\x99 she exclaimed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed, I have no wish to lose your friendship. Yet I am ashamed to ask\r\nyou to come here when I can never return your visits.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, please don\xe2\x80\x99t put it in that way! But it seems so very strange.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEdith could not help conjecturing the true significance of this resolve.\r\nBut, as is commonly the case with people in easy circumstances, she\r\nfound it hard to believe that her friends were so straitened as to\r\nhave a difficulty in supporting the ordinary obligations of a civilised\r\nstate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know how precious your husband\xe2\x80\x99s time is,\xe2\x80\x99 she added, as if to remove\r\nthe effect of her last remark. \xe2\x80\x98Surely, there\xe2\x80\x99s no harm in my saying--we\r\nknow each other well enough--you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t think it necessary to devote\r\nan evening to entertaining us just because you had given us the pleasure\r\nof your company. I put it very stupidly, but I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you understand me,\r\nAmy. Don\xe2\x80\x99t refuse just to come to our house now and then.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid we shall have to be consistent, Edith.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But do you think this is a WISE thing to do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wise?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know what you once told me, about how necessary it was for a\r\nnovelist to study all sorts of people. How can Mr Reardon do this if he\r\nshuts himself up in the house? I should have thought he would find it\r\nnecessary to make new acquaintances.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As I said,\xe2\x80\x99 returned Amy, \xe2\x80\x98it won\xe2\x80\x99t be always like this. For the\r\npresent, Edwin has quite enough \xe2\x80\x9cmaterial.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe spoke distantly; it irritated her to have to invent excuses for the\r\nsacrifice she had just imposed on herself. Edith sipped the tea which\r\nhad been offered her, and for a minute kept silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When will Mr Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s next book be published?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked at length.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. Not before the spring.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall look so anxiously for it. Whenever I meet new people I always\r\nturn the conversation to novels, just for the sake of asking them if\r\nthey know your husband\xe2\x80\x99s books.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe laughed merrily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which is seldom the case, I should think,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, with a smile of\r\nindifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, my dear, you don\xe2\x80\x99t expect ordinary novel-readers to know about Mr\r\nReardon. I wish my acquaintances were a better kind of people; then, of\r\ncourse, I should hear of his books more often. But one has to make the\r\nbest of such society as offers. If you and your husband forsake me, I\r\nshall feel it a sad loss; I shall indeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy gave a quick glance at the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, we must be friends just the same,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, more naturally than\r\nshe had spoken hitherto. \xe2\x80\x98But don\xe2\x80\x99t ask us to come and dine just now.\r\nAll through this winter we shall be very busy, both of us. Indeed, we\r\nhave decided not to accept any invitations at all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then, so long as you let me come here now and then, I must give in. I\r\npromise not to trouble you with any more complaining. But how you can\r\nlive such a life I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I consider myself more of a reader than\r\nwomen generally are, and I should be mortally offended if anyone called\r\nme frivolous; but I must have a good deal of society. Really and truly,\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t live without it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No?\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy, with a smile which meant more than Edith could\r\ninterpret. It seemed slightly condescending.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no knowing; perhaps if I had married a literary man---\xe2\x80\x99 She\r\npaused, smiling and musing. \xe2\x80\x98But then I haven\xe2\x80\x99t, you see.\xe2\x80\x99 She laughed.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Albert is anything but a bookworm, as you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wish him to be.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh no! Not a bookworm. To be sure, we suit each other very well indeed.\r\nHe likes society just as much as I do. It would be the death of him if\r\nhe didn\xe2\x80\x99t spend three-quarters of every day with lively people.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s rather a large portion. But then you count yourself among the\r\nlively ones.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey exchanged looks, and laughed together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course you think me rather silly to want to talk so much with silly\r\npeople,\xe2\x80\x99 Edith went on. \xe2\x80\x98But then there\xe2\x80\x99s generally some amusement to\r\nbe got, you know. I don\xe2\x80\x99t take life quite so seriously as you do. People\r\nare people, after all; it\xe2\x80\x99s good fun to see how they live and hear how\r\nthey talk.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy felt that she was playing a sorry part. She thought of sour grapes,\r\nand of the fox who had lost his tail. Worst of all, perhaps Edith\r\nsuspected the truth. She began to make inquiries about common\r\nacquaintances, and fell into an easier current of gossip.\r\n\r\nA quarter of an hour after the visitor\xe2\x80\x99s departure Reardon came back.\r\nAmy had guessed aright; the necessity of selling his books weighed upon\r\nhim so that for the present he could do nothing. The evening was spent\r\ngloomily, with very little conversation.\r\n\r\nNext day came the bookseller to make his inspection. Reardon had\r\nchosen out and ranged upon a table nearly a hundred volumes. With a few\r\nexceptions, they had been purchased second-hand. The tradesman examined\r\nthem rapidly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you ask?\xe2\x80\x99 he inquired, putting his head aside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I prefer that you should make an offer,\xe2\x80\x99 Reardon replied, with the\r\nhelplessness of one who lives remote from traffic.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t say more than two pounds ten.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is at the rate of sixpence a volume---?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To me that\xe2\x80\x99s about the average value of books like these.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPerhaps the offer was a fair one; perhaps it was not. Reardon had\r\nneither time nor spirit to test the possibilities of the market; he was\r\nashamed to betray his need by higgling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll take it,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, in a matter-of-fact voice.\r\n\r\nA messenger was sent for the books that afternoon. He stowed them\r\nskilfully in two bags, and carried them downstairs to a cart that was\r\nwaiting.\r\n\r\nReardon looked at the gaps left on his shelves. Many of those vanished\r\nvolumes were dear old friends to him; he could have told you where he\r\nhad picked them up and when; to open them recalled a past moment of\r\nintellectual growth, a mood of hope or despondency, a stage of struggle.\r\nIn most of them his name was written, and there were often pencilled\r\nnotes in the margin. Of course he had chosen from among the most\r\nvaluable he possessed; such a multitude must else have been sold to make\r\nthis sum of two pounds ten. Books are cheap, you know. At need, one can\r\nbuy a Homer for fourpence, a Sophocles for sixpence. It was not rubbish\r\nthat he had accumulated at so small expenditure, but the library of a\r\npoor student--battered bindings, stained pages, supplanted editions.\r\nHe loved his books, but there was something he loved more, and when Amy\r\nglanced at him with eyes of sympathy he broke into a cheerful laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m only sorry they have gone for so little. Tell me when the money\r\nis nearly at an end again, and you shall have more. It\xe2\x80\x99s all right; the\r\nnovel will be done soon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnd that night he worked until twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, doggedly, fiercely.\r\n\r\nThe next day was Sunday. As a rule he made it a day of rest, and almost\r\nperforce, for the depressing influence of Sunday in London made work too\r\ndifficult. Then, it was the day on which he either went to see his own\r\nparticular friends or was visited by them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you expect anyone this evening?\xe2\x80\x99 Amy inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Biffen will look in, I dare say. Perhaps Milvain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think I shall take Willie to mother\xe2\x80\x99s. I shall be back before eight.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Amy, don\xe2\x80\x99t say anything about the books.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose they always ask you when we think of removing over the way?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe pointed in a direction that suggested Marylebone Workhouse. Amy tried\r\nto laugh, but a woman with a child in her arms has no keen relish for\r\nsuch jokes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t talk to them about our affairs,\xe2\x80\x99 she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s best.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe left home about three o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the servant going with her to carry\r\nthe child.\r\n\r\nAt five a familiar knock sounded through the flat; it was a heavy rap\r\nfollowed by half-a-dozen light ones, like a reverberating echo, the last\r\nstroke scarcely audible. Reardon laid down his book, but kept his pipe\r\nin his mouth, and went to the door. A tall, thin man stood there, with a\r\nslouch hat and long grey overcoat. He shook hands silently, hung his hat\r\nin the passage, and came forward into the study.\r\n\r\nHis name was Harold Biffen, and, to judge from his appearance, he did\r\nnot belong to the race of common mortals. His excessive meagreness would\r\nall but have qualified him to enter an exhibition in the capacity of\r\nliving skeleton, and the garments which hung upon this framework would\r\nperhaps have sold for three-and-sixpence at an old-clothes dealer\xe2\x80\x99s. But\r\nthe man was superior to these accidents of flesh and raiment. He had\r\na fine face: large, gentle eyes, nose slightly aquiline, small and\r\ndelicate mouth. Thick black hair fell to his coat-collar; he wore a\r\nheavy moustache and a full beard. In his gait there was a singular\r\ndignity; only a man of cultivated mind and graceful character could move\r\nand stand as he did.\r\n\r\nHis first act on entering the room was to take from his pocket a pipe,\r\na pouch, a little tobacco-stopper, and a box of matches, all of which\r\nhe arranged carefully on a corner of the central table. Then he drew\r\nforward a chair and seated himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Take your top-coat off;\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thanks, not this evening.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why the deuce not?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not this evening, thanks.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe reason, as soon as Reardon sought for it, was obvious. Biffen had\r\nno ordinary coat beneath the other. To have referred to this fact would\r\nhave been indelicate; the novelist of course understood it, and smiled,\r\nbut with no mirth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me have your Sophocles,\xe2\x80\x99 were the visitor\xe2\x80\x99s next words.\r\n\r\nReardon offered him a volume of the Oxford Pocket Classics.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I prefer the Wunder, please.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s gone, my boy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Gone?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wanted a little cash.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBiffen uttered a sound in which remonstrance and sympathy were blended.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry to hear that; very sorry. Well, this must do. Now, I want to\r\nknow how you scan this chorus in the \xe2\x80\x9cOedipus Rex.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon took the volume, considered, and began to read aloud with metric\r\nemphasis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Choriambics, eh?\xe2\x80\x99 cried the other. \xe2\x80\x98Possible, of course; but treat them\r\nas Ionics a minore with an anacrusis, and see if they don\xe2\x80\x99t go better.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe involved himself in terms of pedantry, and with such delight that his\r\neyes gleamed. Having delivered a technical lecture, he began to read in\r\nillustration, producing quite a different effect from that of the\r\nrhythm as given by his friend. And the reading was by no means that of a\r\npedant, rather of a poet.\r\n\r\nFor half an hour the two men talked Greek metres as if they lived in a\r\nworld where the only hunger known could be satisfied by grand or sweet\r\ncadences.\r\n\r\nThey had first met in an amusing way. Not long after the publication of\r\nhis book \xe2\x80\x98On Neutral Ground\xe2\x80\x99 Reardon was spending a week at Hastings.\r\nA rainy day drove him to the circulating library, and as he was looking\r\nalong the shelves for something readable a voice near at hand asked the\r\nattendant if he had anything \xe2\x80\x98by Edwin Reardon.\xe2\x80\x99 The novelist turned in\r\nastonishment; that any casual mortal should inquire for his books seemed\r\nincredible. Of course there was nothing by that author in the library,\r\nand he who had asked the question walked out again. On the morrow\r\nReardon encountered this same man at a lonely part of the shore; he\r\nlooked at him, and spoke a word or two of common civility; they got into\r\nconversation, with the result that Edwin told the story of yesterday.\r\nThe stranger introduced himself as Harold Biffen, an author in a small\r\nway, and a teacher whenever he could get pupils; an abusive review had\r\ninterested him in Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s novels, but as yet he knew nothing of them\r\nbut the names.\r\n\r\nTheir tastes were found to be in many respects sympathetic, and after\r\nreturning to London they saw each other frequently. Biffen was always in\r\ndire poverty, and lived in the oddest places; he had seen harder trials\r\nthan even Reardon himself. The teaching by which he partly lived was of\r\na kind quite unknown to the respectable tutorial world. In these days\r\nof examinations, numbers of men in a poor position--clerks\r\nchiefly--conceive a hope that by \xe2\x80\x98passing\xe2\x80\x99 this, that, or the other\r\nformal test they may open for themselves a new career. Not a few such\r\npersons nourish preposterous ambitions; there are warehouse clerks\r\nprivately preparing (without any means or prospect of them) for a\r\ncall to the Bar, drapers\xe2\x80\x99 assistants who \xe2\x80\x98go in\xe2\x80\x99 for the preliminary\r\nexamination of the College of Surgeons, and untaught men innumerable who\r\ndesire to procure enough show of education to be eligible for a curacy.\r\nCandidates of this stamp frequently advertise in the newspapers for\r\ncheap tuition, or answer advertisements which are intended to appeal to\r\nthem; they pay from sixpence to half-a-crown an hour--rarely as much as\r\nthe latter sum. Occasionally it happened that Harold Biffen had three or\r\nfour such pupils in hand, and extraordinary stories he could draw from\r\nhis large experience in this sphere.\r\n\r\nThen as to his authorship.--But shortly after the discussion of Greek\r\nmetres he fell upon the subject of his literary projects, and, by no\r\nmeans for the first time, developed the theory on which he worked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have thought of a new way of putting it. What I really aim at is an\r\nabsolute realism in the sphere of the ignobly decent. The field, as I\r\nunderstand it, is a new one; I don\xe2\x80\x99t know any writer who has treated\r\nordinary vulgar life with fidelity and seriousness. Zola writes\r\ndeliberate tragedies; his vilest figures become heroic from the\r\nplace they fill in a strongly imagined drama. I want to deal with the\r\nessentially unheroic, with the day-to-day life of that vast majority of\r\npeople who are at the mercy of paltry circumstance. Dickens understood\r\nthe possibility of such work, but his tendency to melodrama on the one\r\nhand, and his humour on the other, prevented him from thinking of it. An\r\ninstance, now. As I came along by Regent\xe2\x80\x99s Park half an hour ago a man\r\nand a girl were walking close in front of me, love-making; I passed them\r\nslowly and heard a good deal of their talk--it was part of the situation\r\nthat they should pay no heed to a stranger\xe2\x80\x99s proximity. Now, such\r\na love-scene as that has absolutely never been written down; it was\r\nentirely decent, yet vulgar to the nth power. Dickens would have made\r\nit ludicrous--a gross injustice. Other men who deal with low-class life\r\nwould perhaps have preferred idealising it--an absurdity. For my\r\nown part, I am going to reproduce it verbatim, without one single\r\nimpertinent suggestion of any point of view save that of honest\r\nreporting. The result will be something unutterably tedious. Precisely.\r\nThat is the stamp of the ignobly decent life. If it were anything but\r\ntedious it would be untrue. I speak, of course, of its effect upon the\r\nordinary reader.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t. You--well, you are a psychological realist in\r\nthe sphere of culture. You are impatient of vulgar circumstances.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In a great measure because my life has been martyred by them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And for that very same reason I delight in them,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Biffen.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are repelled by what has injured you; I am attracted by it. This\r\ndivergence is very interesting; but for that, we should have resembled\r\neach other so closely. You know that by temper we are rabid idealists,\r\nboth of us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But let me go on. I want, among other things, to insist upon the\r\nfateful power of trivial incidents. No one has yet dared to do this\r\nseriously. It has often been done in farce, and that\xe2\x80\x99s why farcical\r\nwriting so often makes one melancholy. You know my stock instances\r\nof the kind of thing I mean. There was poor Allen, who lost the most\r\nvaluable opportunity of his life because he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t a clean shirt to put\r\non; and Williamson, who would probably have married that rich girl but\r\nfor the grain of dust that got into his eye, and made him unable to say\r\nor do anything at the critical moment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon burst into a roar of laughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There you are!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Biffen, with friendly annoyance. \xe2\x80\x98You take the\r\nconventional view. If you wrote of these things you would represent them\r\nas laughable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They are laughable,\xe2\x80\x99 asserted the other, \xe2\x80\x98however serious to the\r\npersons concerned. The mere fact of grave issues in life depending on\r\nsuch paltry things is monstrously ludicrous. Life is a huge farce, and\r\nthe advantage of possessing a sense of humour is that it enables one to\r\ndefy fate with mocking laughter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s all very well, but it isn\xe2\x80\x99t an original view. I am not lacking\r\nin sense of humour, but I prefer to treat these aspects of life from\r\nan impartial standpoint. The man who laughs takes the side of a cruel\r\nomnipotence, if one can imagine such a thing.\r\n\r\nI want to take no side at all; simply to say, Look, this is the kind of\r\nthing that happens.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I admire your honesty, Biffen,\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon, sighing. \xe2\x80\x98You will\r\nnever sell work of this kind, yet you have the courage to go on with it\r\nbecause you believe in it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know; I may perhaps sell it some day.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In the meantime,\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon, laying down his pipe, \xe2\x80\x98suppose we eat a\r\nmorsel of something. I\xe2\x80\x99m rather hungry.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn the early days of his marriage Reardon was wont to offer the friends\r\nwho looked in on Sunday evening a substantial supper; by degrees the\r\nmeal had grown simpler, until now, in the depth of his poverty, he made\r\nno pretence of hospitable entertainment. It was only because he knew\r\nthat Biffen as often as not had nothing whatever to eat that he did not\r\nhesitate to offer him a slice of bread and butter and a cup of tea. They\r\nwent into the back room, and over the Spartan fare continued to discuss\r\naspects of fiction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall never,\xe2\x80\x99 said Biffen, \xe2\x80\x98write anything like a dramatic scene.\r\nSuch things do happen in life, but so very rarely that they are nothing\r\nto my purpose. Even when they happen, by-the-bye, it is in a shape that\r\nwould be useless to the ordinary novelist; he would have to cut away\r\nthis circumstance, and add that. Why? I should like to know. Such\r\nconventionalism results from stage necessities. Fiction hasn\xe2\x80\x99t yet\r\noutgrown the influence of the stage on which it originated. Whatever a\r\nman writes FOR EFFECT is wrong and bad.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Only in your view. There may surely exist such a thing as the ART of\r\nfiction.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is worked out. We must have a rest from it. You, now--the best\r\nthings you have done are altogether in conflict with novelistic\r\nconventionalities. It was because that blackguard review of \xe2\x80\x9cOn Neutral\r\nGround\xe2\x80\x9d clumsily hinted this that I first thought of you with interest.\r\nNo, no; let us copy life. When the man and woman are to meet for a\r\ngreat scene of passion, let it all be frustrated by one or other of\r\nthem having a bad cold in the head, and so on. Let the pretty girl get\r\na disfiguring pimple on her nose just before the ball at which she is\r\ngoing to shine. Show the numberless repulsive features of common decent\r\nlife. Seriously, coldly; not a hint of facetiousness, or the thing\r\nbecomes different.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAbout eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock Reardon heard his wife\xe2\x80\x99s knock at the door. On\r\nopening he saw not only Amy and the servant, the latter holding Willie\r\nin her arms, but with them Jasper Milvain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been at Mrs Yule\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper explained as he came in. \xe2\x80\x98Have you\r\nanyone here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Biffen.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, then we\xe2\x80\x99ll discuss realism.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s over for the evening. Greek metres also.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank Heaven!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe three men seated themselves with joking and laughter, and the smoke\r\nof their pipes gathered thickly in the little room. It was half an\r\nhour before Amy joined them. Tobacco was no disturbance to her, and\r\nshe enjoyed the kind of talk that was held on these occasions; but\r\nit annoyed her that she could no longer play the hostess at a merry\r\nsupper-table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why ever are you sitting in your overcoat, Mr Biffen?\xe2\x80\x99 were her first\r\nwords when she entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Please excuse me, Mrs Reardon. It happens to be more convenient this\r\nevening.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe was puzzled, but a glance from her husband warned her not to pursue\r\nthe subject.\r\n\r\nBiffen always behaved to Amy with a sincerity of respect which had made\r\nhim a favourite with her. To him, poor fellow, Reardon seemed supremely\r\nblessed. That a struggling man of letters should have been able to\r\nmarry, and such a wife, was miraculous in Biffen\xe2\x80\x99s eyes. A woman\xe2\x80\x99s love\r\nwas to him the unattainable ideal; already thirty-five years old, he had\r\nno prospect of ever being rich enough to assure himself a daily dinner;\r\nmarriage was wildly out of the question. Sitting here, he found it very\r\ndifficult not to gaze at Amy with uncivil persistency. Seldom in his\r\nlife had he conversed with educated women, and the sound of this clear\r\nvoice was always more delightful to him than any music.\r\n\r\nAmy took a place near to him, and talked in her most charming way of\r\nsuch things as she knew interested him. Biffen\xe2\x80\x99s deferential attitude\r\nas he listened and replied was in strong contrast with the careless\r\nease which marked Jasper Milvain. The realist would never smoke in Amy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npresence, but Jasper puffed jovial clouds even whilst she was conversing\r\nwith him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Whelpdale came to see me last night,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Milvain, presently.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98His novel is refused on all hands. He talks of earning a living as a\r\ncommission agent for some sewing-machine people.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t understand how his book should be positively refused,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nReardon. \xe2\x80\x98The last wasn\xe2\x80\x99t altogether a failure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very nearly. And this one consists of nothing but a series of\r\nconversations between two people. It is really a dialogue, not a novel\r\nat all. He read me some twenty pages, and I no longer wondered that he\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t sell it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, but it has considerable merit,\xe2\x80\x99 put in Biffen. \xe2\x80\x98The talk is\r\nremarkably true.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what\xe2\x80\x99s the good of talk that leads to nothing?\xe2\x80\x99 protested Jasper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s a bit of real life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, but it has no market value. You may write what you like, so long\r\nas people are willing to read you. Whelpdale\xe2\x80\x99s a clever fellow, but he\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t hit a practical line.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Like some other people I have heard of;\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But the odd thing is, that he always strikes one as practical-minded.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t you feel that, Mrs Reardon?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe and Amy talked for a few minutes, and Reardon, seemingly lost in\r\nmeditation, now and then observed them from the corner of his eye.\r\n\r\nAt eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock husband and wife were alone again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to say,\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Amy, \xe2\x80\x98that Biffen has sold his coat?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Or pawned it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But why not the overcoat?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Partly, I should think, because it\xe2\x80\x99s the warmer of the two; partly,\r\nperhaps, because the other would fetch more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That poor man will die of starvation, some day, Edwin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think it not impossible.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hope you gave him something to eat?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh yes. But I could see he didn\xe2\x80\x99t like to take as much as he wanted.\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t think of him with so much pity as I used to; that\xe2\x80\x99s a result of\r\nsuffering oneself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy set her lips and sighed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI. RESPITE\r\n\r\nThe last volume was written in fourteen days. In this achievement\r\nReardon rose almost to heroic pitch, for he had much to contend with\r\nbeyond the mere labour of composition. Scarcely had he begun when a\r\nsharp attack of lumbago fell upon him; for two or three days it was\r\ntorture to support himself at the desk, and he moved about like a\r\ncripple. Upon this ensued headaches, sore-throat, general enfeeblement.\r\nAnd before the end of the fortnight it was necessary to think of raising\r\nanother small sum of money; he took his watch to the pawnbroker\xe2\x80\x99s (you\r\ncan imagine that it would not stand as security for much), and sold a\r\nfew more books. All this notwithstanding, here was the novel at length\r\nfinished. When he had written \xe2\x80\x98The End\xe2\x80\x99 he lay back, closed his eyes,\r\nand let time pass in blankness for a quarter of an hour.\r\n\r\nIt remained to determine the title. But his brain refused another\r\neffort; after a few minutes\xe2\x80\x99 feeble search he simply took the name of\r\nthe chief female character, Margaret Home. That must do for the book.\r\nAlready, with the penning of the last word, all its scenes, personages,\r\ndialogues had slipped away into oblivion; he knew and cared nothing more\r\nabout them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Amy, you will have to correct the proofs for me. Never as long as I\r\nlive will I look upon a page of this accursed novel. It has all but\r\nkilled me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The point is,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Amy, \xe2\x80\x98that here we have it complete. Pack it up\r\nand take it to the publishers\xe2\x80\x99 to-morrow morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And--you will ask them to advance you a few pounds?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBut that undertaking was almost as hard to face as a rewriting of\r\nthe last volume would have been. Reardon had such superfluity of\r\nsensitiveness that, for his own part, he would far rather have gone\r\nhungry than ask for money not legally his due. To-day there was no\r\nchoice. In the ordinary course of business it would be certainly a month\r\nbefore he heard the publishers\xe2\x80\x99 terms, and perhaps the Christmas season\r\nmight cause yet more delay. Without borrowing, he could not provide for\r\nthe expenses of more than another week or two.\r\n\r\nHis parcel under his arm, he entered the ground-floor office, and\r\ndesired to see that member of the firm with whom he had previously had\r\npersonal relations. This gentleman was not in town; he would be away for\r\na few days. Reardon left the manuscript, and came out into the street\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nHe crossed, and looked up at the publishers\xe2\x80\x99 windows from the opposite\r\npavement. \xe2\x80\x98Do they suspect in what wretched circumstances I am? Would\r\nit surprise them to know all that depends upon that budget of paltry\r\nscribbling? I suppose not; it must be a daily experience with them.\r\nWell, I must write a begging letter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was raining and windy. He went slowly homewards, and was on the point\r\nof entering the public door of the flats when his uneasiness became so\r\ngreat that he turned and walked past. If he went in, he must at\r\nonce write his appeal for money, and he felt that he could not. The\r\ndegradation seemed too great.\r\n\r\nWas there no way of getting over the next few weeks? Rent, of course,\r\nwould be due at Christmas, but that payment might be postponed; it was\r\nonly a question of buying food and fuel. Amy had offered to ask her\r\nmother for a few pounds; it would be cowardly to put this task upon her\r\nnow that he had promised to meet the difficulty himself. What man in\r\nall London could and would lend him money? He reviewed the list of his\r\nacquaintances, but there was only one to whom he could appeal with the\r\nslightest hope--that was Carter.\r\n\r\nHalf an hour later he entered that same hospital door through which,\r\nsome years ago, he had passed as a half-starved applicant for work. The\r\nmatron met him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is Mr Carter here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, sir. But we expect him any minute. Will you wait?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe entered the familiar office, and sat down. At the table where he had\r\nbeen wont to work, a young clerk was writing. If only all the events of\r\nthe last few years could be undone, and he, with no soul dependent upon\r\nhim, be once more earning his pound a week in this room! What a happy\r\nman he was in those days!\r\n\r\nNearly half an hour passed. It is the common experience of beggars\r\nto have to wait. Then Carter came in with quick step; he wore a heavy\r\nulster of the latest fashion, new gloves, a resplendent silk hat; his\r\ncheeks were rosy from the east wind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha, Reardon! How do? how do? Delighted to see you!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you very busy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, no, not particularly. A few cheques to sign, and we\xe2\x80\x99re just\r\ngetting out our Christmas appeals. You remember?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe laughed gaily. There was a remarkable freedom from snobbishness in\r\nthis young man; the fact of Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s intellectual superiority had long\r\nago counteracted Carter\xe2\x80\x99s social prejudices.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should like to have a word with you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Right you are!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey went into a small inner room. Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s pulse beat at fever-rate;\r\nhis tongue was cleaving to his palate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is it, old man?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the secretary, seating himself and flinging\r\none of his legs over the other. \xe2\x80\x98You look rather seedy, do you know. Why\r\nthe deuce don\xe2\x80\x99t you and your wife look us up now and then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve had a hard pull to finish my novel.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Finished, is it? I\xe2\x80\x99m glad to hear that. When\xe2\x80\x99ll it be out? I\xe2\x80\x99ll send\r\nscores of people to Mudie\xe2\x80\x99s after it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thanks; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t think much of it, to tell you the truth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, we know what that means.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon was talking like an automaton. It seemed to him that he turned\r\nscrews and pressed levers for the utterance of his next words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I may as well say at once what I have come for. Could you lend me ten\r\npounds for a month--in fact, until I get the money for my book?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe secretary\xe2\x80\x99s countenance fell, though not to that expression of utter\r\ncoldness which would have come naturally under the circumstances to a\r\ngreat many vivacious men. He seemed genuinely embarrassed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By Jove! I--confound it! To tell you the truth, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t ten pounds\r\nto lend. Upon my word, I haven\xe2\x80\x99t, Reardon! These infernal housekeeping\r\nexpenses! I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind telling you, old man, that Edith and I have been\r\npushing the pace rather.\xe2\x80\x99 He laughed, and thrust his hands down into\r\nhis trousers-pockets. \xe2\x80\x98We pay such a darned rent, you know--hundred and\r\ntwenty-five. We\xe2\x80\x99ve only just been saying we should have to draw it mild\r\nfor the rest of the winter. But I\xe2\x80\x99m infernally sorry; upon my word I\r\nam.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And I am sorry to have annoyed you by the unseasonable request.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Devilish seasonable, Reardon, I assure you!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the secretary, and\r\nroared at his joke. It put him into a better temper than ever, and he\r\nsaid at length: \xe2\x80\x98I suppose a fiver wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be much use?--For a month,\r\nyou say?--I might manage a fiver, I think.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be very useful. But on no account if----\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no; I could manage a fiver, for a month. Shall I give you a\r\ncheque?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m ashamed----\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit of it! I\xe2\x80\x99ll go and write the cheque.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon\xe2\x80\x99s face was burning. Of the conversation that followed when\r\nCarter again presented himself he never recalled a word. The bit of\r\npaper was crushed together in his hand. Out in the street again, he all\r\nbut threw it away, dreaming for the moment that it was a \xe2\x80\x98bus ticket or\r\na patent medicine bill.\r\n\r\nHe reached home much after the dinner-hour. Amy was surprised at his\r\nlong absence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Got anything?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was half his intention to deceive her, to say that the publishers had\r\nadvanced him five pounds. But that would be his first word of untruth\r\nto Amy, and why should he be guilty of it? He told her all that had\r\nhappened. The result of this frankness was something that he had not\r\nanticipated; Amy exhibited profound vexation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, you SHOULDN\xe2\x80\x99T have done that!\xe2\x80\x99 she exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x98Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you come\r\nhome and tell me? I would have gone to mother at once.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But does it matter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course it does,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied sharply. \xe2\x80\x98Mr Carter will tell his wife,\r\nand how pleasant that is?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never thought of that. And perhaps it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have seemed to me so\r\nannoying as it does to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very likely not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe turned abruptly away, and stood at a distance in gloomy muteness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 she said at length, \xe2\x80\x98there\xe2\x80\x99s no helping it now. Come and have\r\nyour dinner.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have taken away my appetite.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense! I suppose you\xe2\x80\x99re dying of hunger.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey had a very uncomfortable meal, exchanging few words. On Amy\xe2\x80\x99s face\r\nwas a look more resembling bad temper than anything Reardon had ever\r\nseen there. After dinner he went and sat alone in the study. Amy did\r\nnot come near him. He grew stubbornly angry; remembering the pain he had\r\ngone through, he felt that Amy\xe2\x80\x99s behaviour to him was cruel. She must\r\ncome and speak when she would.\r\n\r\nAt six o\xe2\x80\x99clock she showed her face in the doorway and asked if he would\r\ncome to tea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied, \xe2\x80\x98I had rather stay here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you please.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnd he sat alone until about nine. It was only then he recollected that\r\nhe must send a note to the publishers, calling their attention to the\r\nparcel he had left. He wrote it, and closed with a request that they\r\nwould let him hear as soon as they conveniently could. As he was\r\nputting on his hat and coat to go out and post the letter Amy opened the\r\ndining-room door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re going out?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall you be long?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe was away only a few minutes. On returning he went first of all into\r\nthe study, but the thought of Amy alone in the other room would not let\r\nhim rest. He looked in and saw that she was sitting without a fire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You can\xe2\x80\x99t stay here in the cold, Amy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid I must get used to it,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied, affecting to be closely\r\nengaged upon some sewing.\r\n\r\nThat strength of character which it had always delighted him to read in\r\nher features was become an ominous hardness. He felt his heart sink as\r\nhe looked at her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is poverty going to have the usual result in our case?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked,\r\ndrawing nearer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I never pretended that I could be indifferent to it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Still, don\xe2\x80\x99t you care to try and resist it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe gave no answer. As usual in conversation with an aggrieved woman it\r\nwas necessary to go back from the general to the particular.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98that the Carters already knew pretty well how\r\nthings were going with us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s a very different thing. But when it comes to asking them for\r\nmoney--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m very sorry. I would rather have done anything if I had known how it\r\nwould annoy you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If we have to wait a month, five pounds will be very little use to us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe detailed all manner of expenses that had to be met--outlay there was\r\nno possibility of avoiding so long as their life was maintained on its\r\npresent basis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98However, you needn\xe2\x80\x99t trouble any more about it. I\xe2\x80\x99ll see to it. Now you\r\nare free from your book try to rest.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Come and sit by the fire. There\xe2\x80\x99s small chance of rest for me if we are\r\nthinking unkindly of each other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA doleful Christmas. Week after week went by and Reardon knew that Amy\r\nmust have exhausted the money he had given her. But she made no more\r\ndemands upon him, and necessaries were paid for in the usual way. He\r\nsuffered from a sense of humiliation; sometimes he found it difficult to\r\nlook in his wife\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\nWhen the publishers\xe2\x80\x99 letter came it contained an offer of seventy-five\r\npounds for the copyright of \xe2\x80\x98Margaret Home,\xe2\x80\x99 twenty-five more to be\r\npaid if the sale in three-volume form should reach a certain number of\r\ncopies.\r\n\r\nHere was failure put into unmistakable figures. Reardon said to himself\r\nthat it was all over with his profession of authorship. The book could\r\nnot possibly succeed even to the point of completing his hundred pounds;\r\nit would meet with universal contempt, and indeed deserved nothing\r\nbetter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall you accept this?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Amy, after dreary silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No one else would offer terms as good.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will they pay you at once?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must ask them to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWell, it was seventy-five pounds in hand. The cheque came as soon as\r\nit was requested, and Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s face brightened for the moment. Blessed\r\nmoney! root of all good, until the world invent some saner economy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How much do you owe your mother?\xe2\x80\x99 he inquired, without looking at Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Six pounds,\xe2\x80\x99 she answered coldly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And five to Carter; and rent, twelve pounds ten. We shall have a matter\r\nof fifty pounds to go on with.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XII. WORK WITHOUT HOPE\r\n\r\nThe prudent course was so obvious that he marvelled at Amy\xe2\x80\x99s failing\r\nto suggest it. For people in their circumstances to be paying a rent\r\nof fifty pounds when a home could be found for half the money was\r\nrecklessness; there would be no difficulty in letting the flat for this\r\nlast year of their lease, and the cost of removal would be trifling. The\r\nmental relief of such a change might enable him to front with courage\r\na problem in any case very difficult, and, as things were, desperate.\r\nThree months ago, in a moment of profoundest misery, he had proposed\r\nthis step; courage failed him to speak of it again, Amy\xe2\x80\x99s look and voice\r\nwere too vivid in his memory. Was she not capable of such a sacrifice\r\nfor his sake? Did she prefer to let him bear all the responsibility of\r\nwhatever might result from a futile struggle to keep up appearances?\r\n\r\nBetween him and her there was no longer perfect confidence. Her silence\r\nmeant reproach, and--whatever might have been the case before--there was\r\nno doubt that she now discussed him with her mother, possibly with other\r\npeople. It was not likely that she concealed his own opinion of the book\r\nhe had just finished; all their acquaintances would be prepared to greet\r\nits publication with private scoffing or with mournful shaking of the\r\nhead. His feeling towards Amy entered upon a new phase. The stability of\r\nhis love was a source of pain; condemning himself, he felt at the same\r\ntime that he was wronged. A coldness which was far from representing\r\nthe truth began to affect his manner and speech, and Amy did not seem\r\nto notice it, at all events she made no kind of protest. They no longer\r\ntalked of the old subjects, but of those mean concerns of material life\r\nwhich formerly they had agreed to dismiss as quickly as possible. Their\r\nrelations to each other--not long ago an inexhaustible topic--would not\r\nbear spoken comment; both were too conscious of the danger-signal when\r\nthey looked that way.\r\n\r\nIn the time of waiting for the publishers\xe2\x80\x99 offer, and now again when he\r\nwas asking himself how he should use the respite granted him, Reardon\r\nspent his days at the British Museum. He could not read to much purpose,\r\nbut it was better to sit here among strangers than seem to be idling\r\nunder Amy\xe2\x80\x99s glance. Sick of imaginative writing, he turned to the\r\nstudies which had always been most congenial, and tried to shape out a\r\npaper or two like those he had formerly disposed of to editors. Among\r\nhis unused material lay a mass of notes he had made in a reading of\r\nDiogenes Laertius, and it seemed to him now that he might make something\r\nsalable out of these anecdotes of the philosophers. In a happier mood he\r\ncould have written delightfully on such a subject--not learnedly, but in\r\nthe strain of a modern man whose humour and sensibility find free play\r\namong the classic ghosts; even now he was able to recover something of\r\nthe light touch which had given value to his published essays.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile the first number of The Current had appeared, and Jasper\r\nMilvain had made a palpable hit. Amy spoke very often of the article\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x98Typical Readers,\xe2\x80\x99 and her interest in its author was freely\r\nmanifested. Whenever a mention of Jasper came under her notice she read\r\nit out to her husband. Reardon smiled and appeared glad, but he did not\r\ncare to discuss Milvain with the same frankness as formerly.\r\n\r\nOne evening at the end of January he told Amy what he had been writing\r\nat the Museum, and asked her if she would care to hear it read.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I began to wonder what you were doing,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then why didn\xe2\x80\x99t you ask me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was rather afraid to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why afraid?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would have seemed like reminding you that--you know what I mean.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That a month or two more will see us at the same crisis again. Still, I\r\nhad rather you had shown an interest in my doings.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter a pause Amy asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think you can get a paper of this kind accepted?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It isn\xe2\x80\x99t impossible. I think it\xe2\x80\x99s rather well done. Let me read you a\r\npage--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where will you send it?\xe2\x80\x99 she interrupted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To The Wayside.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why not try The Current? Ask Milvain to introduce you to Mr Fadge. They\r\npay much better, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But this isn\xe2\x80\x99t so well suited for Fadge. And I much prefer to be\r\nindependent, as long as it\xe2\x80\x99s possible.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s one of your faults, Edwin,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked his wife, mildly. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nonly the strongest men that can make their way independently. You ought\r\nto use every means that offers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Seeing that I am so weak?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t think it would offend you. I only meant---\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no; you are quite right. Certainly, I am one of the men who need\r\nall the help they can get. But I assure you, this thing won\xe2\x80\x99t do for The\r\nCurrent.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a pity you will go back to those musty old times! Now think of\r\nthat article of Milvain\xe2\x80\x99s. If only you could do something of that kind!\r\nWhat do people care about Diogenes and his tub and his lantern?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear girl, Diogenes Laertius had neither tub nor lantern, that I\r\nknow of. You are making a mistake; but it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it does.\xe2\x80\x99 The caustic note was not very pleasant on\r\nAmy\xe2\x80\x99s lips. \xe2\x80\x98Whoever he was, the mass of readers will be frightened by\r\nhis name.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, we have to recognise that the mass of readers will never care for\r\nanything I do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will never convince me that you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t write in a popular way if\r\nyou tried. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you are quite as clever as Milvain--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon made an impatient gesture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do leave Milvain aside for a little! He and I are as unlike as two\r\nmen could be. What\xe2\x80\x99s the use of constantly comparing us?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy looked at him. He had never spoken to her so brusquely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How can you say that I am constantly comparing you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If not in spoken words, then in your thoughts.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s not a very nice thing to say, Edwin.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You make it so unmistakable, Amy. What I mean is, that you are always\r\nregretting the difference between him and me. You lament that I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nwrite in that attractive way. Well, I lament it myself--for your sake. I\r\nwish I had Milvain\xe2\x80\x99s peculiar talent, so that I could get reputation and\r\nmoney. But I haven\xe2\x80\x99t, and there\xe2\x80\x99s an end of it. It irritates a man to be\r\nperpetually told of his disadvantages.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will never mention Milvain\xe2\x80\x99s name again,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy coldly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now that\xe2\x80\x99s ridiculous, and you know it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feel the same about your irritation. I can\xe2\x80\x99t see that I have given\r\nany cause for it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then we\xe2\x80\x99ll talk no more of the matter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon threw his manuscript aside and opened a book. Amy never asked\r\nhim to resume his intention of reading what he had written.\r\n\r\nHowever, the paper was accepted. It came out in The Wayside for March,\r\nand Reardon received seven pounds ten for it. By that time he had\r\nwritten another thing of the same gossipy kind, suggested by Pliny\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nLetters. The pleasant occupation did him good, but there was no\r\npossibility of pursuing this course. \xe2\x80\x98Margaret Home\xe2\x80\x99 would be published\r\nin April; he might get the five-and-twenty pounds contingent upon a\r\ncertain sale, yet that could in no case be paid until the middle of the\r\nyear, and long before then he would be penniless. His respite drew to an\r\nend.\r\n\r\nBut now he took counsel of no one; as far as it was possible he lived in\r\nsolitude, never seeing those of his acquaintances who were outside the\r\nliterary world, and seldom even his colleagues. Milvain was so busy that\r\nhe had only been able to look in twice or thrice since Christmas, and\r\nReardon nowadays never went to Jasper\xe2\x80\x99s lodgings.\r\n\r\nHe had the conviction that all was over with the happiness of his\r\nmarried life, though how the events which were to express this ruin\r\nwould shape themselves he could not foresee. Amy was revealing that\r\naspect of her character to which he had been blind, though a practical\r\nman would have perceived it from the first; so far from helping him to\r\nsupport poverty, she perhaps would even refuse to share it with him.\r\nHe knew that she was slowly drawing apart; already there was a divorce\r\nbetween their minds, and he tortured himself in uncertainty as to how\r\nfar he retained her affections. A word of tenderness, a caress, no\r\nlonger met with response from her; her softest mood was that of mere\r\ncomradeship. All the warmth of her nature was expended upon the child;\r\nReardon learnt how easy it is for a mother to forget that both parents\r\nhave a share in her offspring.\r\n\r\nHe was beginning to dislike the child. But for Willie\xe2\x80\x99s existence Amy\r\nwould still love him with undivided heart; not, perhaps, so passionately\r\nas once, but still with lover\xe2\x80\x99s love. And Amy understood--or, at all\r\nevents, remarked--this change in him. She was aware that he seldom asked\r\na question about Willie, and that he listened with indifference when she\r\nspoke of the little fellow\xe2\x80\x99s progress. In part offended, she was also in\r\npart pleased.\r\n\r\nBut for the child, mere poverty, he said to himself, should never have\r\nsundered them. In the strength of his passion he could have overcome all\r\nher disappointments; and, indeed, but for that new care, he would\r\nmost likely never have fallen to this extremity of helplessness. It is\r\nnatural in a weak and sensitive man to dream of possibilities disturbed\r\nby the force of circumstance. For one hour which he gave to conflict\r\nwith his present difficulties, Reardon spent many in contemplation of\r\nthe happiness that might have been.\r\n\r\nEven yet, it needed but a little money to redeem all. Amy had no\r\nextravagant aspirations; a home of simple refinement and freedom from\r\nanxiety would restore her to her nobler self. How could he find fault\r\nwith her? She knew nothing of such sordid life as he had gone through,\r\nand to lack money for necessities seemed to her degrading beyond\r\nendurance. Why, even the ordinary artisan\xe2\x80\x99s wife does not suffer such\r\nprivations as hers at the end of the past year. For lack of that little\r\nmoney his life must be ruined. Of late he had often thought about the\r\nrich uncle, John Yule, who might perhaps leave something to Amy; but the\r\nhope was so uncertain. And supposing such a thing were to happen; would\r\nit be perfectly easy to live upon his wife\xe2\x80\x99s bounty--perhaps exhausting\r\na small capital, so that, some years hence, their position would be\r\nno better than before? Not long ago, he could have taken anything from\r\nAmy\xe2\x80\x99s hand; would it be so simple since the change that had come between\r\nthem?\r\n\r\nHaving written his second magazine-article (it was rejected by two\r\neditors, and he had no choice but to hold it over until sufficient time\r\nhad elapsed to allow of his again trying The Wayside), he saw that he\r\nmust perforce plan another novel. But this time he was resolute not to\r\nundertake three volumes. The advertisements informed him that numbers of\r\nauthors were abandoning that procrustean system; hopeless as he was, he\r\nmight as well try his chance with a book which could be written in a\r\nfew weeks. And why not a glaringly artificial story with a sensational\r\ntitle? It could not be worse than what he had last written.\r\n\r\nSo, without a word to Amy, he put aside his purely intellectual work\r\nand began once more the search for a \xe2\x80\x98plot.\xe2\x80\x99 This was towards the end of\r\nFebruary. The proofs of \xe2\x80\x98Margaret Home\xe2\x80\x99 were coming in day by day; Amy\r\nhad offered to correct them, but after all he preferred to keep his\r\nshame to himself as long as possible, and with a hurried reading he\r\ndismissed sheet after sheet. His imagination did not work the more\r\nhappily for this repugnant task; still, he hit at length upon a\r\nconception which seemed absurd enough for the purpose before him.\r\nWhether he could persevere with it even to the extent of one volume was\r\nvery doubtful. But it should not be said of him that he abandoned his\r\nwife and child to penury without one effort of the kind that Milvain and\r\nAmy herself had recommended.\r\n\r\nWriting a page or two of manuscript daily, and with several holocausts\r\nto retard him, he had done nearly a quarter of the story when there came\r\na note from Jasper telling of Mrs Milvain\xe2\x80\x99s death. He handed it across\r\nthe breakfast-table to Amy, and watched her as she read it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t alter his position,\xe2\x80\x99 Amy remarked, without much\r\ninterest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose not appreciably. He told me once his mother had a sufficient\r\nincome; but whatever she leaves will go to his sisters, I should think.\r\nHe has never said much to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNearly three weeks passed before they heard anything more from Jasper\r\nhimself; then he wrote, again from the country, saying that he purposed\r\nbringing his sisters to live in London. Another week, and one evening he\r\nappeared at the door.\r\n\r\nA want of heartiness in Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s reception of him might have been\r\nexplained as gravity natural under the circumstances. But Jasper had\r\nbefore this become conscious that he was not welcomed here quite so\r\ncheerily as in the old days. He remarked it distinctly on that evening\r\nwhen he accompanied Amy home from Mrs Yule\xe2\x80\x99s; since then he had allowed\r\nhis pressing occupations to be an excuse for the paucity of his visits.\r\nIt seemed to him perfectly intelligible that Reardon, sinking into\r\nliterary insignificance, should grow cool to a man entering upon a\r\nsuccessful career; the vein of cynicism in Jasper enabled him to pardon\r\na weakness of this kind, which in some measure flattered him. But he\r\nboth liked and respected Reardon, and at present he was in the mood to\r\ngive expression to his warmer feelings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your book is announced, I see,\xe2\x80\x99 he said with an accent of pleasure, as\r\nsoon as he had seated himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. \xe2\x80\x9cNew novel by the author of \xe2\x80\x98On Neutral Ground.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Down for the\r\nsixteenth of April. And I have a proposal to make about it. Will you\r\nlet me ask Fadge to have it noticed in \xe2\x80\x9cBooks of the Month,\xe2\x80\x9d in the May\r\nCurrent?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I strongly advise you to let it take its chance. The book isn\xe2\x80\x99t worth\r\nspecial notice, and whoever undertook to review it for Fadge would\r\neither have to lie, or stultify the magazine.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper turned to Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now what is to be done with a man like this? What is one to say to him,\r\nMrs Reardon?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Edwin dislikes the book,\xe2\x80\x99 Amy replied, carelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That has nothing to do with the matter. We know quite well that in\r\nanything he writes there\xe2\x80\x99ll be something for a well-disposed reviewer\r\nto make a good deal of. If Fadge will let me, I should do the thing\r\nmyself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nNeither Reardon nor his wife spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course,\xe2\x80\x99 went on Milvain, looking at the former, \xe2\x80\x98if you had rather\r\nI left it alone--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I had much rather. Please don\xe2\x80\x99t say anything about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was an awkward silence. Amy broke it by saying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are your sisters in town, Mr Milvain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. We came up two days ago. I found lodgings for them not far from\r\nMornington Road. Poor girls! they don\xe2\x80\x99t quite know where they are, yet.\r\nOf course they will keep very quiet for a time, then I must try to get\r\nfriends for them. Well, they have one already--your cousin, Miss Yule.\r\nShe has already been to see them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m very glad of that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy took an opportunity of studying his face. There was again a\r\nsilence as if of constraint. Reardon, glancing at his wife, said with\r\nhesitation:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When they care to see other visitors, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure Amy would be very\r\nglad--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Certainly!\xe2\x80\x99 his wife added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Thank you very much. Of course I knew I could depend on Mrs Reardon to\r\nshow them kindness in that way. But let me speak frankly of something.\r\nMy sisters have made quite a friend of Miss Yule, since she was down\r\nthere last year. Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t that\xe2\x80\x99--he turned to Amy--\xe2\x80\x98cause you a little\r\nawkwardness?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy had a difficulty in replying. She kept her eyes on the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have had no quarrel with your cousin,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Reardon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98None whatever. It\xe2\x80\x99s only my mother and my uncle.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine Miss Yule having a quarrel with anyone,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper.\r\nThen he added quickly: \xe2\x80\x98Well, things must shape themselves naturally. We\r\nshall see. For the present they will be fully occupied. Of course it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbest that they should be. I shall see them every day, and Miss Yule will\r\ncome pretty often, I dare say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon caught Amy\xe2\x80\x99s eye, but at once looked away again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My word!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Milvain, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s meditation. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s well\r\nthis didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen a year ago. The girls have no income; only a little\r\ncash to go on with. We shall have our work set. It\xe2\x80\x99s a precious lucky\r\nthing that I have just got a sort of footing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon muttered an assent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what are you doing now?\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper inquired suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Writing a one-volume story.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m glad to hear that. Any special plan for its publication?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then why not offer it to Jedwood? He\xe2\x80\x99s publishing a series of\r\none-volume novels. You know of Jedwood, don\xe2\x80\x99t you? He was Culpepper\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmanager; started business about half a year ago, and it looks as if he\r\nwould do well. He married that woman--what\xe2\x80\x99s her name?--Who wrote \xe2\x80\x9cMr\r\nHenderson\xe2\x80\x99s Wives\xe2\x80\x9d?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never heard of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense!--Miss Wilkes, of course. Well, she married this fellow\r\nJedwood, and there was a great row about something or other between\r\nhim and her publishers. Mrs Boston Wright told me all about it. An\r\nastonishing woman that; a cyclopaedia of the day\xe2\x80\x99s small talk. I\xe2\x80\x99m quite\r\na favourite with her; she\xe2\x80\x99s promised to help the girls all she can.\r\nWell, but I was talking about Jedwood. Why not offer him this book of\r\nyours? He\xe2\x80\x99s eager to get hold of the new writers. Advertises hugely; he\r\nhas the whole back page of The Study about every other week. I suppose\r\nMiss Wilkes\xe2\x80\x99s profits are paying for it. He has just given Markland two\r\nhundred pounds for a paltry little tale that would scarcely swell out\r\nto a volume. Markland told me himself. You know that I\xe2\x80\x99ve scraped an\r\nacquaintance with him? Oh! I suppose I haven\xe2\x80\x99t seen you since then. He\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na dwarfish fellow with only one eye. Mrs Boston Wright cries him up at\r\nevery opportunity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who IS Mrs Boston Wright?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Reardon, laughing impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Edits The English Girl, you know. She\xe2\x80\x99s had an extraordinary life.\r\nWas born in Mauritius--no, Ceylon--I forget; some such place. Married a\r\nsailor at fifteen. Was shipwrecked somewhere, and only restored to life\r\nafter terrific efforts;--her story leaves it all rather vague. Then she\r\nturns up as a newspaper correspondent at the Cape. Gave up that, and\r\ntook to some kind of farming, I forget where. Married again (first\r\nhusband lost in aforementioned shipwreck), this time a Baptist minister,\r\nand began to devote herself to soup-kitchens in Liverpool. Husband\r\nburned to death, somewhere. She\xe2\x80\x99s next discovered in the thick of\r\nliterary society in London. A wonderful woman, I assure you. Must be\r\nnearly fifty, but she looks twenty-five.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe paused, then added impulsively:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me take you to one of her evenings--nine on Thursday. Do persuade\r\nhim, Mrs Reardon?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no. I should be horribly out of my element.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t see why. You would meet all sorts of well-known people; those\r\nyou ought to have met long ago. Better still, let me ask her to send\r\nan invitation for both of you. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure you\xe2\x80\x99d like her, Mrs Reardon.\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s a good deal of humbug about her, it\xe2\x80\x99s true, but some solid\r\nqualities as well. No one has a word to say against her. And it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nsplendid advertisement to have her for a friend. She\xe2\x80\x99ll talk about your\r\nbooks and articles till all is blue.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy gave a questioning look at her husband. But Reardon moved in an\r\nuncomfortable way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We\xe2\x80\x99ll see about it,\xe2\x80\x99 he said. \xe2\x80\x98Some day, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let me know whenever you feel disposed. But about Jedwood: I happen to\r\nknow a man who reads for him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Heavens!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Reardon. \xe2\x80\x98Who don\xe2\x80\x99t you know?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The simplest thing in the world. At present it\xe2\x80\x99s a large part of my\r\nbusiness to make acquaintances. Why, look you; a man who has to live\r\nby miscellaneous writing couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get on without a vast variety of\r\nacquaintances. One\xe2\x80\x99s own brain would soon run dry; a clever fellow knows\r\nhow to use the brains of other people.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy listened with an unconscious smile which expressed keen interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Jasper, \xe2\x80\x98when did you see Whelpdale last?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Haven\xe2\x80\x99t seen him for a long time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t know what he\xe2\x80\x99s doing? The fellow has set up as a \xe2\x80\x9cliterary\r\nadviser.\xe2\x80\x9d He has an advertisement in The Study every week. \xe2\x80\x9cTo Young\r\nAuthors and Literary Aspirants\xe2\x80\x9d--something of the kind. \xe2\x80\x9cAdvice given on\r\nchoice of subjects, MSS. read, corrected, and recommended to publishers.\r\nModerate terms.\xe2\x80\x9d A fact! And what\xe2\x80\x99s more, he made six guineas in the\r\nfirst fortnight; so he says, at all events. Now that\xe2\x80\x99s one of the finest\r\njokes I ever heard. A man who can\xe2\x80\x99t get anyone to publish his own books\r\nmakes a living by telling other people how to write!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it\xe2\x80\x99s a confounded swindle!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. He\xe2\x80\x99s capable of correcting the grammar of \xe2\x80\x9cliterary\r\naspirants,\xe2\x80\x9d and as for recommending to publishers--well, anyone can\r\nrecommend, I suppose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon\xe2\x80\x99s indignation yielded to laughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s not impossible that he may thrive by this kind of thing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all,\xe2\x80\x99 assented Jasper.\r\n\r\nShortly after this he looked at his watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must be off, my friends. I have something to write before I can go to\r\nmy truckle-bed, and it\xe2\x80\x99ll take me three hours at least.\r\nGood-bye, old man. Let me know when your story\xe2\x80\x99s finished, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ntalk about it. And think about Mrs Boston Wright; oh, and about that\r\nreview in The Current. I wish you\xe2\x80\x99d let me do it. Talk it over with your\r\nguide, philosopher, and friend.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe indicated Amy, who laughed in a forced way.\r\n\r\nWhen he was gone, the two sat without speaking for several minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you care to make friends with those girls?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Reardon at length.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose in decency I must call upon them?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may find them very agreeable.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey conversed with their own thoughts for a while. Then Reardon burst\r\nout laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, there\xe2\x80\x99s the successful man, you see. Some day he\xe2\x80\x99ll live in a\r\nmansion, and dictate literary opinions to the universe.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How has he offended you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Offended me? Not at all. I am glad of his cheerful prospects.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why should you refuse to go among those people? It might be good for\r\nyou in several ways.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If the chance had come when I was publishing my best work, I dare say I\r\nshouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have refused. But I certainly shall not present myself as the\r\nauthor of \xe2\x80\x9cMargaret Home,\xe2\x80\x9d and the rubbish I\xe2\x80\x99m now writing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you must cease to write rubbish.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I must cease to write altogether.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And do what?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wish to Heaven I knew!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIII. A WARNING\r\n\r\nIn the spring list of Mr Jedwood\xe2\x80\x99s publications, announcement was\r\nmade of a new work by Alfred Yule. It was called \xe2\x80\x98English Prose in the\r\nNineteenth Century,\xe2\x80\x99 and consisted of a number of essays (several of\r\nwhich had already seen the light in periodicals) strung into continuity.\r\nThe final chapter dealt with contemporary writers, more especially those\r\nwho served to illustrate the author\xe2\x80\x99s theme--that journalism is the\r\ndestruction of prose style: on certain popular writers of the day there\r\nwas an outpouring of gall which was not likely to be received as though\r\nit were sweet ointment. The book met with rather severe treatment in\r\ncritical columns; it could scarcely be ignored (the safest mode of\r\nattack when one\xe2\x80\x99s author has no expectant public), and only the most\r\nskilful could write of it in a hostile spirit without betraying that\r\nsome of its strokes had told. An evening newspaper which piqued itself\r\non independence indulged in laughing appreciation of the polemical\r\nchapter, and the next day printed a scornful letter from a\r\nthinly-disguised correspondent who assailed both book and reviewer. For\r\nthe moment people talked more of Alfred Yule than they had done since\r\nhis memorable conflict with Clement Fadge.\r\n\r\nThe publisher had hoped for this. Mr Jedwood was an energetic and\r\nsanguine man, who had entered upon his business with a determination to\r\nrival in a year or so the houses which had slowly risen into commanding\r\nstability. He had no great capital, but the stroke of fortune which had\r\nwedded him to a popular novelist enabled him to count on steady profit\r\nfrom one source, and boundless faith in his own judgment urged him to an\r\ninitial outlay which made the prudent shake their heads. He talked much\r\nof \xe2\x80\x98the new era,\xe2\x80\x99 foresaw revolutions in publishing and book-selling,\r\nplanned every week a score of untried ventures which should appeal to\r\nthe democratic generation just maturing; in the meantime, was ready to\r\npublish anything which seemed likely to get talked about.\r\n\r\nThe May number of The Current, in its article headed \xe2\x80\x98Books of the\r\nMonth,\xe2\x80\x99 devoted about half a page to \xe2\x80\x98English Prose in the Nineteenth\r\nCentury.\xe2\x80\x99 This notice was a consummate example of the flippant style of\r\nattack. Flippancy, the most hopeless form of intellectual vice, was a\r\ncharacterising note of Mr Fadge\xe2\x80\x99s periodical; his monthly comments on\r\npublications were already looked for with eagerness by that growing\r\nclass of readers who care for nothing but what can be made matter of\r\nridicule. The hostility of other reviewers was awkward and ineffectual\r\ncompared with this venomous banter, which entertained by showing that in\r\nthe book under notice there was neither entertainment nor any other kind\r\nof interest. To assail an author without increasing the number of his\r\nreaders is the perfection of journalistic skill, and The Current, had\r\nit stood alone, would fully have achieved this end. As it was, silence\r\nmight have been better tactics. But Mr Fadge knew that his enemy would\r\nsmart under the poisoned pin-points, and that was something gained.\r\n\r\nOn the day that The Current appeared, its treatment of Alfred Yule was\r\ndiscussed in Mr Jedwood\xe2\x80\x99s private office. Mr Quarmby, who had intimate\r\nrelations with the publisher, happened to look in just as a young man\r\n(one of Mr Jedwood\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98readers\xe2\x80\x99) was expressing a doubt whether Fadge\r\nhimself was the author of the review.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But there\xe2\x80\x99s Fadge\xe2\x80\x99s thumb-mark all down the page,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Mr Quarmby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He inspired the thing, of course; but I rather think it was written by\r\nthat fellow Milvain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Think so?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the publisher.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I know with certainty that the notice of Markland\xe2\x80\x99s novel is his\r\nwriting, and I have reasons for suspecting that he did Yule\xe2\x80\x99s book as\r\nwell.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Smart youngster, that,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Mr Jedwood. \xe2\x80\x98Who is he, by-the-bye?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Somebody\xe2\x80\x99s illegitimate son, I believe,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the source of\r\ntrustworthy information, with a laugh. \xe2\x80\x98Denham says he met him in New\r\nYork a year or two ago, under another name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Excuse me,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed Mr Quarmby, \xe2\x80\x98there\xe2\x80\x99s some mistake in all that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe went on to state what he knew, from Yule himself, concerning\r\nMilvain\xe2\x80\x99s history. Though in this instance a corrector, Mr Quarmby took\r\nan opportunity, a few hours later, of informing Mr Hinks that the attack\r\non Yule in The Current was almost certainly written by young Milvain,\r\nwith the result that when the rumour reached Yule\xe2\x80\x99s ears it was\r\ndelivered as an undoubted and well-known fact.\r\n\r\nIt was a month prior to this that Milvain made his call upon Marian\r\nYule, on the Sunday when her father was absent. When told of the visit,\r\nYule assumed a manner of indifference, but his daughter understood that\r\nhe was annoyed. With regard to the sisters who would shortly be living\r\nin London, he merely said that Marian must behave as discretion directed\r\nher. If she wished to invite the Miss Milvains to St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s Crescent,\r\nhe only begged that the times and seasons of the household might not be\r\ndisturbed.\r\n\r\nAs her habit was, Marian took refuge in silence. Nothing could have been\r\nmore welcome to her than the proximity of Maud and Dora, but she foresaw\r\nthat her own home would not be freely open to them; perhaps it might be\r\nnecessary to behave with simple frankness, and let her friends know the\r\nembarrassments of the situation. But that could not be done in the first\r\ninstance; the unkindness would seem too great. A day after the arrival\r\nof the girls, she received a note from Dora, and almost at once replied\r\nto it by calling at her friends\xe2\x80\x99 lodgings. A week after that, Maud and\r\nDora came to St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s Crescent; it was Sunday, and Mr Yule purposely\r\nkept away from home. They had only been once to the house since then,\r\nagain without meeting Mr Yule. Marian, however, visited them at their\r\nlodgings frequently; now and then she met Jasper there. The latter never\r\nspoke of her father, and there was no question of inviting him to repeat\r\nhis call.\r\n\r\nIn the end, Marian was obliged to speak on the subject with her mother.\r\nMrs Yule offered an occasion by asking when the Miss Milvains were\r\ncoming again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I shall ever ask them again,\xe2\x80\x99 Marian replied.\r\n\r\nHer mother understood, and looked troubled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must tell them how it is, that\xe2\x80\x99s all,\xe2\x80\x99 the girl went on. \xe2\x80\x98They are\r\nsensible; they won\xe2\x80\x99t be offended with me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But your father has never had anything to say against them,\xe2\x80\x99 urged Mrs\r\nYule. \xe2\x80\x98Not a word to me, Marian. I\xe2\x80\x99d tell you the truth if he had.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s too disagreeable, all the same. I can\xe2\x80\x99t invite them here with\r\npleasure.
