In spite of their poor lodgings, they had been brought into\r\nsocial relations with Mrs Boston Wright and a few of her friends; their\r\nposition was understood, and in accepting invitations they had no fear\r\nlest unwelcome people should pounce down upon them in their shabby\r\nlittle sitting-room. The younger sister cared little for society such\r\nas Jasper procured them; with Marian Yule for a companion she would have\r\nbeen quite content to spend her evenings at home. But Maud relished the\r\nintroduction to strangers. She was admired, and knew it. Prudence\r\ncould not restrain her from buying a handsomer dress than those she had\r\nbrought from her country home, and it irked her sorely that she might\r\nnot reconstruct all her equipment to rival the appearance of well-to-do\r\ngirls whom she studied and envied. Her disadvantages, for the present,\r\nwere insuperable. She had no one to chaperon her; she could not form\r\nintimacies because of her poverty. A rare invitation to luncheon, a\r\npermission to call at the sacred hour of small-talk--this was all she\r\ncould hope for.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I advise you to possess your soul in patience,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper said to her,\r\nas they talked one day on the sea-shore. \xe2\x80\x98You are not to blame that you\r\nlive without conventional protection, but it necessitates your being\r\nvery careful. These people you are getting to know are not rigid about\r\nsocial observances, and they won\xe2\x80\x99t exactly despise you for poverty; all\r\nthe same, their charity mustn\xe2\x80\x99t be tested too severely. Be very quiet\r\nfor the present; let it be seen that you understand that your position\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t quite regular--I mean, of course, do so in a modest and nice\r\nway. As soon as ever it\xe2\x80\x99s possible, we\xe2\x80\x99ll arrange for you to live with\r\nsomeone who will preserve appearances. All this is contemptible,\r\nof course; but we belong to a contemptible society, and can\xe2\x80\x99t help\r\nourselves. For Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, don\xe2\x80\x99t spoil your chances by rashness; be\r\ncontent to wait a little, till some more money comes in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMidway in October, about half-past eight one evening, Jasper received\r\nan unexpected visit from Dora. He was in his sitting-room, smoking and\r\nreading a novel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Anything wrong?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked, as his sister entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; but I\xe2\x80\x99m alone this evening, and I thought I would see if you were\r\nin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where\xe2\x80\x99s Maud, then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She went to see the Lanes this afternoon, and Mrs Lane invited her\r\nto go to the Gaiety to-night; she said a friend whom she had invited\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come, and the ticket would be wasted. Maud went back to dine\r\nwith them. She\xe2\x80\x99ll come home in a cab.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why is Mrs Lane so affectionate all at once? Take your things off; I\r\nhave nothing to do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Miss Radway was going as well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who\xe2\x80\x99s Miss Radway?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you know her? She\xe2\x80\x99s staying with the Lanes. Maud says she writes\r\nfor The West End.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And will that fellow Lane be with them?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper mused, contemplating the bowl of his pipe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose she was in rare excitement?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pretty well. She has wanted to go to the Gaiety for a long time.\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s no harm, is there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora asked the question with that absent air which girls are wont to\r\nassume when they touch on doubtful subjects.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Harm, no. Idiocy and lively music, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. It\xe2\x80\x99s too late, or I\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nhave taken you, for the joke of the thing. Confound it! she ought to\r\nhave better dresses.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, she looked very nice, in that best.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Pooh! But I don\xe2\x80\x99t care for her to be running about with the Lanes. Lane\r\nis too big a blackguard; it reflects upon his wife to a certain extent.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey gossiped for half an hour, then a tap at the door interrupted them;\r\nit was the landlady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mr Whelpdale has called to see you, sir. I mentioned as Miss Milvain\r\nwas here, so he said he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t come up unless you sent to ask him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper smiled at Dora, and said in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you say? Shall he come up? He can behave himself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just as you please, Jasper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ask him to come up, Mrs Thompson, please.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Whelpdale presented himself. He entered with much more ceremony than\r\nwhen Milvain was alone; on his visage was a grave respectfulness, his\r\nstep was light, his whole bearing expressed diffidence and pleasurable\r\nanticipation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My younger sister, Whelpdale,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper, with subdued amusement.\r\n\r\nThe dealer in literary advice made a bow which did him no discredit, and\r\nbegan to speak in a low, reverential tone not at all disagreeable to the\r\near. His breeding, in truth, had been that of a gentleman, and it was\r\nonly of late years that he had fallen into the hungry region of New Grub\r\nStreet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How\xe2\x80\x99s the \xe2\x80\x9cManual\xe2\x80\x9d going off?\xe2\x80\x99 Milvain inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Excellently! We have sold nearly six hundred.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My sister is one of your readers. I believe she has studied the book\r\nwith much conscientiousness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Really? You have really read it, Miss Milvain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora assured him that she had, and his delight knew no bounds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It isn\xe2\x80\x99t all rubbish, by any means,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper, graciously. \xe2\x80\x98In the\r\nchapter on writing for magazines, there are one or two very good hints.\r\nWhat a pity you can\xe2\x80\x99t apply your own advice, Whelpdale!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now that\xe2\x80\x99s horribly unkind of you!\xe2\x80\x99 protested the other. \xe2\x80\x98You might\r\nhave spared me this evening. But unfortunately it\xe2\x80\x99s quite true, Miss\r\nMilvain. I point the way, but I haven\xe2\x80\x99t been able to travel it myself.\r\nYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t think I have never succeeded in getting things published;\r\nbut I can\xe2\x80\x99t keep it up as a profession.\r\n\r\nYour brother is the successful man. A marvellous facility! I envy him.\r\nFew men at present writing have such talent.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Please don\xe2\x80\x99t make him more conceited than he naturally is,\xe2\x80\x99 interposed\r\nDora.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What news of Biffen?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Jasper, presently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He says he shall finish \xe2\x80\x9cMr Bailey, Grocer,\xe2\x80\x9d in about a month. He read\r\nme one of the later chapters the other night. It\xe2\x80\x99s really very fine;\r\nmost remarkable writing, it seems to me. It will be scandalous if he\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t get it published; it will, indeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do hope he may!\xe2\x80\x99 said Dora, laughing. \xe2\x80\x98I have heard so much of \xe2\x80\x9cMr\r\nBailey,\xe2\x80\x9d that it will be a great disappointment if I am never to read\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid it would give you very little pleasure,\xe2\x80\x99 Whelpdale replied,\r\nhesitatingly. \xe2\x80\x98The matter is so very gross.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And the hero grocer!\xe2\x80\x99 shouted Jasper, mirthfully. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, but it\xe2\x80\x99s quite\r\ndecent; only rather depressing. The decently ignoble--or, the ignobly\r\ndecent? Which is Biffen\xe2\x80\x99s formula? I saw him a week ago, and he looked\r\nhungrier than ever.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah, but poor Reardon! I passed him at King\xe2\x80\x99s Cross not long ago.\r\n\r\nHe didn\xe2\x80\x99t see me--walks with his eyes on the ground always--and I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthe courage to stop him. He\xe2\x80\x99s the ghost of his old self. He can\xe2\x80\x99t live\r\nlong.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora and her brother exchanged a glance. It was a long time since Jasper\r\nhad spoken to his sisters about the Reardons; nowadays he seldom heard\r\neither of husband or wife.\r\n\r\nThe conversation that went on was so agreeable to Whelpdale, that he\r\nlost consciousness of time. It was past eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock when Jasper felt\r\nobliged to remind him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dora, I think I must be taking you home.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe visitor at once made ready for departure, and his leave-taking was\r\nas respectful as his entrance had been. Though he might not say what\r\nhe thought, there was very legible upon his countenance a hope that he\r\nwould again be privileged to meet Miss Dora Milvain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bad fellow, in his way,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper, when Dora and he were alone\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe had heard the story of Whelpdale\xe2\x80\x99s hapless wooing half a year ago,\r\nand her recollection of it explained the smile with which she spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never get on, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper pursued. \xe2\x80\x98He has his allowance of\r\ntwenty pounds a year, and makes perhaps fifty or sixty more. If I were\r\nin his position, I should go in for some kind of regular business; he\r\nhas people who could help him. Good-natured fellow; but what\xe2\x80\x99s the use\r\nof that if you\xe2\x80\x99ve no money?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey set out together, and walked to the girls\xe2\x80\x99 lodgings. Dora was about\r\nto use her latch-key, but Jasper checked her. \xe2\x80\x98No. There\xe2\x80\x99s a light in\r\nthe kitchen still; better knock, as we\xe2\x80\x99re so late.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But why?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never mind; do as I tell you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe landlady admitted them, and Jasper spoke a word or two with her,\r\nexplaining that he would wait until his elder sister\xe2\x80\x99s return; the\r\ndarkness of the second-floor windows had shown that Maud was not yet\r\nback.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What strange fancies you have!\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Dora, when they were upstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So have people in general, unfortunately.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nA letter lay on the table. It was addressed to Maud, and Dora recognised\r\nthe handwriting as that of a Wattleborough friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There must be some news here,\xe2\x80\x99 she said. \xe2\x80\x98Mrs Haynes wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t write\r\nunless she had something special to say.\r\n\r\nJust upon midnight, a cab drew up before the house. Dora ran down to\r\nopen the door to her sister, who came in with very bright eyes and more\r\ncolour than usual on her cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How late for you to be here!\xe2\x80\x99 she exclaimed, on entering the\r\nsitting-room and seeing Jasper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have felt comfortable till I knew that you were back all\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What fear was there?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe threw off her wraps, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, have you enjoyed yourself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh yes!\xe2\x80\x99 she replied, carelessly. \xe2\x80\x98This letter for me? What has Mrs\r\nHaynes got to say, I wonder?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe opened the envelope, and began to glance hurriedly over the sheet of\r\npaper. Then her face changed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you think? Mr Yule is dead!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora uttered an exclamation; Jasper displayed the keenest interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He died yesterday--no, it would be the day before yesterday. He had a\r\nfit of some kind at a public meeting, was taken to the hospital because\r\nit was nearest, and died in a few hours. So that has come, at last! Now\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99ll be the result of it, I wonder?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When shall you be seeing Marian?\xe2\x80\x99 asked her brother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She might come to-morrow evening.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But won\xe2\x80\x99t she go to the funeral?\xe2\x80\x99 suggested Dora.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps; there\xe2\x80\x99s no saying. I suppose her father will, at all events.\r\nThe day before yesterday? Then the funeral will be on Saturday, I should\r\nthink.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ought I to write to Marian?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Dora.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x99 was Jasper\xe2\x80\x99s reply. \xe2\x80\x98Better wait till she lets you\r\nhear. That\xe2\x80\x99s sure to be soon. She may have gone to Wattleborough this\r\nafternoon, or be going to-morrow morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe letter from Mrs Haynes was passed from hand to hand. \xe2\x80\x98Everybody\r\nfeels sure,\xe2\x80\x99 it said, \xe2\x80\x98that a great deal of his money will be left for\r\npublic purposes. The ground for the park being already purchased, he is\r\nsure to have made provision for carrying out his plans connected with\r\nit. But I hope your friends in London may benefit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was some time before Jasper could put an end to the speculative\r\nconversation and betake himself homewards. And even on getting back to\r\nhis lodgings he was little disposed to go to bed. This event of John\r\nYule\xe2\x80\x99s death had been constantly in his mind, but there was always a\r\nfear that it might not happen for long enough; the sudden announcement\r\nexcited him almost as much as if he were a relative of the deceased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Confound his public purposes!\xe2\x80\x99 was the thought upon which he at length\r\nslept.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXI. MR YULE LEAVES TOWN\r\n\r\nSince the domestic incidents connected with that unpleasant review in\r\nThe Current, the relations between Alfred Yule and his daughter had\r\nsuffered a permanent change, though not in a degree noticeable by any\r\none but the two concerned. To all appearances, they worked together and\r\nconversed very much as they had been wont to do; but Marian was made\r\nto feel in many subtle ways that her father no longer had complete\r\nconfidence in her, no longer took the same pleasure as formerly in the\r\nskill and conscientiousness of her work, and Yule on his side perceived\r\ntoo clearly that the girl was preoccupied with something other than\r\nher old wish to aid and satisfy him, that she had a new life of her own\r\nalien to, and in some respects irreconcilable with, the existence\r\nin which he desired to confirm her. There was no renewal of open\r\ndisagreement, but their conversations frequently ended by tacit mutual\r\nconsent, at a point which threatened divergence; and in Yule\xe2\x80\x99s case\r\nevery such warning was a cause of intense irritation. He feared to\r\nprovoke Marian, and this fear was again a torture to his pride.\r\n\r\nBeyond the fact that his daughter was in constant communication with\r\nthe Miss Milvains, he knew, and could discover, nothing of the terms on\r\nwhich she stood with the girls\xe2\x80\x99 brother, and this ignorance was harder\r\nto bear than full assurance of a disagreeable fact would have been. That\r\na man like Jasper Milvain, whose name was every now and then forced\r\nupon his notice as a rising periodicalist and a faithful henchman of\r\nthe unspeakable Fadge--that a young fellow of such excellent prospects\r\nshould seriously attach himself to a girl like Marian seemed to him\r\nhighly improbable, save, indeed, for the one consideration, that\r\nMilvain, who assuredly had a very keen eye to chances, might regard the\r\ngirl as a niece of old John Yule, and therefore worth holding in view\r\nuntil it was decided whether or not she would benefit by her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndecease. Fixed in his antipathy to the young man, he would not allow\r\nhimself to admit any but a base motive on Milvain\xe2\x80\x99s side, if, indeed,\r\nMarian and Jasper were more to each other than slight acquaintances; and\r\nhe persuaded himself that anxiety for the girl\xe2\x80\x99s welfare was at least\r\nas strong a motive with him as mere prejudice against the ally of Fadge,\r\nand, it might be, the reviewer of \xe2\x80\x98English Prose.\xe2\x80\x99 Milvain was quite\r\ncapable of playing fast and loose with a girl, and Marian, owing to the\r\npeculiar circumstances of her position, would easily be misled by the\r\npretence of a clever speculator.\r\n\r\nThat she had never spoken again about the review in The Current might\r\nreceive several explanations. Perhaps she had not been able to convince\r\nherself either for or against Milvain\xe2\x80\x99s authorship; perhaps she had\r\nreason to suspect that the young man was the author; perhaps she merely\r\nshrank from reviving a discussion in which she might betray what she\r\ndesired to keep secret. This last was the truth. Finding that her father\r\ndid not recur to the subject, Marian concluded that he had found himself\r\nto be misinformed. But Yule, though he heard the original rumour denied\r\nby people whom in other matters he would have trusted, would not lay\r\naside the doubt that flattered his prejudices. If Milvain were not the\r\nwriter of the review, he very well might have been; and what certainty\r\ncould be arrived at in matters of literary gossip?\r\n\r\nThere was an element of jealousy in the father\xe2\x80\x99s feeling. If he did not\r\nlove Marian with all the warmth of which a parent is capable, at least\r\nhe had more affection for her than for any other person, and of this he\r\nbecame strongly aware now that the girl seemed to be turning from him.\r\nIf he lost Marian, he would indeed be a lonely man, for he considered\r\nhis wife of no account.\r\n\r\nIntellectually again, he demanded an entire allegiance from his\r\ndaughter; he could not bear to think that her zeal on his behalf was\r\ndiminishing, that perhaps she was beginning to regard his work as futile\r\nand antiquated in comparison with that of the new generation. Yet this\r\nmust needs be the result of frequent intercourse with such a man as\r\nMilvain. It seemed to him that he remarked it in her speech and manner,\r\nand at times he with difficulty restrained himself from a reproach or a\r\nsarcasm which would have led to trouble.\r\n\r\nHad he been in the habit of dealing harshly with Marian, as with her\r\nmother, of course his position would have been simpler. But he had\r\nalways respected her, and he feared to lose that measure of respect with\r\nwhich she repaid him. Already he had suffered in her esteem, perhaps\r\nmore than he liked to think, and the increasing embitterment of his\r\ntemper kept him always in danger of the conflict he dreaded. Marian was\r\nnot like her mother; she could not submit to tyrannous usage. Warned\r\nof that, he did his utmost to avoid an outbreak of discord, constantly\r\nhoping that he might come to understand his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s position, and\r\nperhaps discover that his greatest fear was unfounded.\r\n\r\nTwice in the course of the summer he inquired of his wife whether she\r\nknew anything about the Milvains. But Mrs Yule was not in Marian\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconfidence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I only know that she goes to see the young ladies, and that they do\r\nwriting of some kind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She never even mentions their brother to you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never. I haven\xe2\x80\x99t heard his name from her since she told me the Miss\r\nMilvains weren\xe2\x80\x99t coming here again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe was not sorry that Marian had taken the decision to keep her friends\r\naway from St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s Crescent, for it saved him a recurring annoyance;\r\nbut, on the other hand, if they had continued to come, he would not\r\nhave been thus completely in the dark as to her intercourse with Jasper;\r\nscraps of information must now and then have been gathered by his wife\r\nfrom the girls\xe2\x80\x99 talk.\r\n\r\nThroughout the month of July he suffered much from his wonted bilious\r\nattacks, and Mrs Yule had to endure a double share of his ill-temper,\r\nthat which was naturally directed against her, and that of which Marian\r\nwas the cause. In August things were slightly better; but with the\r\nreturn to labour came a renewal of Yule\xe2\x80\x99s sullenness and savageness.\r\nSundry pieces of ill-luck of a professional kind--warnings, as he too\r\nwell understood, that it was growing more and more difficult for him\r\nto hold his own against the new writers--exasperated his quarrel with\r\ndestiny. The gloom of a cold and stormy September was doubly wretched\r\nin that house on the far borders of Camden Town, but in October the sun\r\nreappeared and it seemed to mollify the literary man\xe2\x80\x99s mood. Just when\r\nMrs Yule and Marian began to hope that this long distemper must surely\r\ncome to an end, there befell an incident which, at the best of times,\r\nwould have occasioned misery, and which in the present juncture proved\r\ndisastrous.\r\n\r\nIt was one morning about eleven. Yule was in his study; Marian was at\r\nthe Museum; Mrs Yule had gone shopping. There came a sharp knock at\r\nthe front door, and the servant, on opening, was confronted with a\r\ndecently-dressed woman, who asked in a peremptory voice if Mrs Yule was\r\nat home.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No? Then is Mr Yule?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, mum, but I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid he\xe2\x80\x99s busy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t care, I must see him. Say that Mrs Goby wants to see him at\r\nonce.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe servant, not without apprehensions, delivered this message at the\r\ndoor of the study.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs Goby? Who is Mrs Goby?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed the man of letters, irate at the\r\ndisturbance.\r\n\r\nThere sounded an answer out of the passage, for the visitor had followed\r\nclose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am Mrs Goby, of the \xe2\x80\x98Olloway Road, wife of Mr C. O. Goby,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98aberdasher. I just want to speak to you, Mr Yule, if you please, seeing\r\nthat Mrs Yule isn\xe2\x80\x99t in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYule started up in fury, and stared at the woman, to whom the servant\r\nhad reluctantly given place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What business can you have with me? If you wish to see Mrs Yule, come\r\nagain when she is at home.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, Mr Yule, I will not come again!\xe2\x80\x99 cried the woman, red in the face.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought I might have had respectable treatment here, at all events;\r\nbut I see you\xe2\x80\x99re pretty much like your relations in the way of behaving\r\nto people, though you do wear better clothes, and--I s\xe2\x80\x99pose--call\r\nyourself a gentleman. I won\xe2\x80\x99t come again, and you shall just hear what\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve got to say.\r\n\r\nShe closed the door violently, and stood in an attitude of robust\r\ndefiance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s all this about?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the enraged author, overcoming an impulse\r\nto take Mrs Goby by the shoulders and throw her out--though he might\r\nhave found some difficulty in achieving this feat. \xe2\x80\x98Who are you? And why\r\ndo you come here with your brawling?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m the respectable wife of a respectable man--that\xe2\x80\x99s who I am, Mr\r\nYule, if you want to know. And I always thought Mrs Yule was the same,\r\nfrom the dealings we\xe2\x80\x99ve had with her at the shop, though not knowing any\r\nmore of her, it\xe2\x80\x99s true, except that she lived in St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s Crezzent.\r\nAnd so she may be respectable, though I can\xe2\x80\x99t say as her husband behaves\r\nhimself very much like what he pretends to be. But I can\xe2\x80\x99t say as much\r\nfor her relations in Perker Street, \xe2\x80\x98Olloway, which I s\xe2\x80\x99pose they\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nyour relations as well, at least by marriage. And if they think they\xe2\x80\x99re\r\ngoing to insult me, and use their blackguard tongues--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What are you talking about?\xe2\x80\x99 shouted Yule, who was driven to frenzy by\r\nthe mention of his wife\xe2\x80\x99s humble family. \xe2\x80\x98What have I to do with these\r\npeople?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have you to do with them? I s\xe2\x80\x99pose they\xe2\x80\x99re your relations, ain\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthey? And I s\xe2\x80\x99pose the girl Annie Rudd is your niece, ain\xe2\x80\x99t she? At\r\nleast, she\xe2\x80\x99s your wife\xe2\x80\x99s niece, and that comes to the same thing, I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nalways understood, though I dare say a gentleman as has so many books\r\nabout him can correct me if I\xe2\x80\x99ve made a mistake.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe looked scornfully, though also with some surprise, round the volumed\r\nwalls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what of this girl? Will you have the goodness to say what your\r\nbusiness is?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I will have the goodness! I s\xe2\x80\x99pose you know very well that I took\r\nyour niece Annie Rudd as a domestic servant\xe2\x80\x99--she repeated this precise\r\ndefinition--\xe2\x80\x98as a domestic servant, because Mrs Yule \xe2\x80\x98appened to \xe2\x80\x98arst\r\nme if I knew of a place for a girl of that kind, as hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been out\r\nbefore, but could be trusted to do her best to give satisfaction to a\r\ngood mistress? I s\xe2\x80\x99pose you know that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know nothing of the kind. What have I to do with servants?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, whether you\xe2\x80\x99ve much to do with them or little, that\xe2\x80\x99s how it\r\nwas. And nicely she\xe2\x80\x99s paid me out, has your niece, Miss Rudd. Of all the\r\ntrouble I ever had with a girl! And now when she\xe2\x80\x99s run away back \xe2\x80\x98ome,\r\nand when I take the trouble to go arfter her, I\xe2\x80\x99m to be insulted and\r\nabused as never was! Oh, they\xe2\x80\x99re a nice respectable family, those Rudds!\r\nMrs Rudd--that\xe2\x80\x99s Mrs Yule\xe2\x80\x99s sister--what a nice, polite-spoken lady she\r\nis, to be sure? If I was to repeat the language--but there, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlower myself. And I\xe2\x80\x99ve been a brute of a mistress; I ill-use my\r\nservants, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t give \xe2\x80\x98em enough to eat, and I pay \xe2\x80\x98em worse than\r\nany woman in London! That\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99ve learnt about myself by going to\r\nPerker Street, \xe2\x80\x98Olloway. And when I come here to ask Mrs Yule what she\r\nmeans by recommending such a creature, from such a \xe2\x80\x98ome, I get insulted\r\nby her gentleman husband.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYule was livid with rage, but the extremity of his scorn withheld him\r\nfrom utterance of what he felt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As I said, all this has nothing to do with me. I will let Mrs Yule know\r\nthat you have called. I have no more time to spare.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Goby repeated at still greater length the details of her grievance,\r\nbut long before she had finished Yule was sitting again at his desk in\r\nostentatious disregard of her. Finally, the exasperated woman flung open\r\nthe door, railed in a loud voice along the passage, and left the house\r\nwith an alarming crash.\r\n\r\nIt was not long before Mrs Yule returned. Before taking off her things,\r\nshe went down into the kitchen with certain purchases, and there she\r\nlearnt from the servant what had happened during her absence. Fear and\r\ntrembling possessed her--the sick, faint dread always excited by her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s wrath--but she felt obliged to go at once to the study. The\r\nscene that took place there was one of ignoble violence on Yule\xe2\x80\x99s part,\r\nand, on that of his wife, of terrified self-accusation, changing at\r\nlength to dolorous resentment of the harshness with which she was\r\ntreated. When it was over, Yule took his hat and went out.\r\n\r\nHe did not return for the mid-day meal, and when Marian, late in the\r\nafternoon, came back from the Museum, he was still absent.\r\n\r\nNot finding her mother in the parlour, Marian called at the head of the\r\nkitchen stairs. The servant answered, saying that Mrs Yule was up in\r\nher bedroom, and that she didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem well. Marian at once went up and\r\nknocked at the bedroom door. In a moment or two her mother came out,\r\nshowing a face of tearful misery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is it, mother? What\xe2\x80\x99s the matter?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey went into Marian\xe2\x80\x99s room, where Mrs Yule gave free utterance to her\r\nlamentations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t put up with it, Marian! Your father is too hard with me.\r\nI was wrong, I dare say, and I might have known what would have come of\r\nit, but he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t speak to me worse if I did him all the harm I could\r\non purpose. It\xe2\x80\x99s all about Annie, because I found a place for her at Mrs\r\nGoby\xe2\x80\x99s in the \xe2\x80\x98Olloway Road; and now Mrs Goby\xe2\x80\x99s been here and seen your\r\nfather, and told him she\xe2\x80\x99s been insulted by the Rudds, because Annie\r\nwent off home, and she went after her to make inquiries. And your\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s in such a passion about it as never was. That woman Mrs Goby\r\nrushed into the study when he was working; it was this morning, when I\r\nhappened to be out. And she throws all the blame on me for recommending\r\nher such a girl. And I did it for the best, that I did! Annie promised\r\nme faithfully she\xe2\x80\x99d behave well, and never give me trouble, and she\r\nseemed thankful to me, because she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t happy at home. And now to\r\nthink of her causing all this disturbance! I oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to have done\r\nsuch a thing without speaking about it to your father; but you know how\r\nafraid I am to say a word to him about those people. And my sister\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntold me so often I ought to be ashamed of myself never helping her and\r\nher children; she thinks I could do such a lot if I only liked. And now\r\nthat I did try to do something, see what comes of it!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian listened with a confusion of wretched feelings. But her\r\nsympathies were strongly with her mother; as well as she could\r\nunderstand the broken story, her father seemed to have no just cause\r\nfor his pitiless rage, though such an occasion would be likely enough to\r\nbring out his worst faults.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is he in the study?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, he went out at twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and he\xe2\x80\x99s never been back since. I\r\nfeel as if I must do something; I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear with it, Marian. He tells\r\nme I\xe2\x80\x99m the curse of his life--yes, he said that. I oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to tell you,\r\nI know I oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t; but it\xe2\x80\x99s more than I can bear. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always tried to\r\ndo my best, but it gets harder and harder for me. But for me he\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nnever be in these bad tempers; it\xe2\x80\x99s because he can\xe2\x80\x99t look at me without\r\ngetting angry. He says I\xe2\x80\x99ve kept him back all through his life; but for\r\nme he might have been far better off than he is. It may be true; I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\noften enough thought it. But I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear to have it told me like that,\r\nand to see it in his face every time he looks at me. I shall have to do\r\nsomething. He\xe2\x80\x99d be glad if only I was out of his way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father has no right to make you so unhappy,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian. \xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t see\r\nthat you did anything blameworthy; it seems to me that it was your duty\r\nto try and help Annie, and if it turned out unfortunately, that can\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nhelped. I must tell father that he is making our lives\r\na burden to us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t speak to him like that, Marian! She had been weak to hold her peace so\r\nlong; at her age it was a simple duty to interfere when her mother\r\nwas treated with such flagrant injustice. Dinner was delayed for half an hour, then Marian\r\ndeclared that they would wait no longer. They two made a sorry meal, and\r\nafterwards went together into the sitting-room. At eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock they\r\nheard the front door open, and Yule\xe2\x80\x99s footstep in the passage. Marian\r\nrose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t speak till to-morrow!\xe2\x80\x99 whispered her mother, catching at the\r\ngirl\xe2\x80\x99s arm. \xe2\x80\x98Let it be till to-morrow, Marian!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must speak! We can\xe2\x80\x99t live in this terror.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe reached the study just as her father was closing the door behind\r\nhim. But I can\xe2\x80\x99t see that mother was to blame; I don\xe2\x80\x99t think you\r\nought to be so angry with her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt cost Marian a terrible effort to address her father in these terms.\r\nWhen he turned fiercely upon her, she shrank back and felt as if\r\nstrength must fail her even to stand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You can\xe2\x80\x99t see that she was to blame? Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it entirely against my wish\r\nthat she keeps up any intercourse with those low people? Am I to be\r\nexposed to insulting disturbance in my very study, because she chooses\r\nto introduce girls of bad character as servants to vulgar women?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think Annie Rudd can be called a girl of bad character, and\r\nit was very natural that mother should try to do something for her. You\r\nhave never actually forbidden her to see her relatives.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A thousand times I have given her to understand that I utterly\r\ndisapproved of such association. She knew perfectly well that this girl\r\nwas as likely as not to discredit her. If she had consulted me, I should\r\nat once have forbidden anything of the kind; she was aware of that. She\r\nkept it secret from me, knowing that it would excite my displeasure. I\r\nwill not be drawn into such squalid affairs; I won\xe2\x80\x99t have my name spoken\r\nin such connection. Your mother has only herself to blame if I am angry\r\nwith her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your anger goes beyond all bounds. It is cruel that you should\r\nmake her suffer as she is doing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian was being strengthened to resist. When mother is brought to the\r\npoint of saying that she would rather leave home and everything than\r\nendure her misery any longer, I should be wrong if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t speak to\r\nyou. Why are you so unkind? What serious cause has mother ever given\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I refuse to argue such questions with you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you are very unjust. I am not a child, and there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing wrong\r\nin my asking you why home is made a place of misery, instead of being\r\nwhat home ought to be.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You prove that you are a child, in asking for explanations which ought\r\nto be clear enough to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mean that mother is to blame for everything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The subject is no fit one to be discussed between a father and his\r\ndaughter. If you cannot see the impropriety of it, be so good as to go\r\naway and reflect, and leave me to my occupations.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian came to a pause. But she knew that his rebuke was mere unworthy\r\nevasion; she saw that her father could not meet her look, and this\r\nperception of shame in him impelled her to finish what she had begun.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will say nothing of mother, then, but speak only for myself. I suffer\r\ntoo much from your unkindness; you ask too much endurance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mean that I exact too much work from you?\xe2\x80\x99 asked her father, with a\r\nlook which might have been directed to a recalcitrant clerk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. But that you make the conditions of my work too hard. I live in\r\nconstant fear of your anger.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed? When did I last ill-use you, or threaten you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I often think that threats, or even ill-usage, would be easier to bear\r\nthan an unchanging gloom which always seems on the point of breaking\r\ninto violence.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am obliged to you for your criticism of my disposition and manner,\r\nbut unhappily I am too old to reform. Life has made me what I am, and I\r\nshould have thought that your knowledge of what my life has been would\r\nhave gone far to excuse a lack of cheerfulness in me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe irony of this laborious period was full of self-pity. His voice\r\nquavered at the close, and a tremor was noticeable in his stiff frame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It isn\xe2\x80\x99t lack of cheerfulness that I mean, father. That could never\r\nhave brought me to speak like this.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you wish me to admit that I am bad-tempered, surly, irritable--I\r\nmake no difficulty about that. The charge is true enough. I can only ask\r\nyou again: What are the circumstances that have ruined my temper? When\r\nyou present yourself here with a general accusation of my behaviour, I\r\nam at a loss to understand what you ask of me, what you wish me to say\r\nor do. I must beg you to speak plainly. Are you suggesting that I should\r\nmake provision for the support of you and your mother away from my\r\nintolerable proximity? My income is not large, as I think you are aware,\r\nbut of course, if a demand of this kind is seriously made, I must do my\r\nbest to comply with it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It hurts me very much that you can understand me no better than this.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry. I think we used to understand each other, but that was\r\nbefore you were subjected to the influence of strangers.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn his perverse frame of mind he was ready to give utterance to any\r\nthought which confused the point at issue. This last allusion was\r\nsuggested to him by a sudden pang of regret for the pain he was causing\r\nMarian; he defended himself against self-reproach by hinting at the true\r\nreason of much of his harshness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am subjected to no influence that is hostile to you,\xe2\x80\x99 Marian replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may think that. But in such a matter it is very easy for you to\r\ndeceive yourself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course I know what you refer to, and I can assure you that I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndeceive myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYule flashed a searching glance at her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Can you deny that you are on terms of friendship with a--a person who\r\nwould at any moment rejoice to injure me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am friendly with no such person. Will you say whom you are thinking\r\nof?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be useless. I have no wish to discuss a subject on which we\r\nshould only disagree unprofitably.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian kept silence for a moment, then said in a low, unsteady voice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is perhaps because we never speak of that subject that we are so\r\nfar from understanding each other. If you think that Mr Milvain is\r\nyour enemy, that he would rejoice to injure you, you are grievously\r\nmistaken.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When I see a man in close alliance with my worst enemy, and looking to\r\nthat enemy for favour, I am justified in thinking that he would injure\r\nme if the right kind of opportunity offered. One need not be very deeply\r\nread in human nature to have assurance of that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I know Mr Milvain!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Far better than you can, I am sure. You draw conclusions from general\r\nprinciples; but I know that they don\xe2\x80\x99t apply in this case.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no doubt you sincerely think so. I repeat that nothing can be\r\ngained by such a discussion as this.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98One thing I must tell you. There was no truth in your suspicion that Mr\r\nMilvain wrote that review in The Current. He assured me himself that he\r\nwas not the writer, that he had nothing to do with it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nYule looked askance at her, and his face displayed solicitude, which\r\nsoon passed, however, into a smile of sarcasm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s word no doubt has weight with you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father, what do you mean?\xe2\x80\x99 broke from Marian, whose eyes of a sudden\r\nflashed stormily. \xe2\x80\x98Would Mr Milvain tell me a lie?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like to say that it is impossible,\xe2\x80\x99 replied her father in\r\nthe same tone as before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But--what right have you to insult him so grossly?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have every right, my dear child, to express an opinion about him\r\nor any other man, provided I do it honestly. I beg you not to strike\r\nattitudes and address me in the language of the stage. You insist on my\r\nspeaking plainly, and I have spoken plainly. I warned you that we were\r\nnot likely to agree on this topic.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Literary quarrels have made you incapable of judging honestly in\r\nthings such as this. I wish I could have done for ever with the hateful\r\nprofession that so poisons men\xe2\x80\x99s minds.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Believe me, my girl,\xe2\x80\x99 said her father, incisively, \xe2\x80\x98the simpler thing\r\nwould be to hold aloof from such people as use the profession in a\r\nspirit of unalloyed selfishness, who seek only material advancement, and\r\nwho, whatever connection they form, have nothing but self-interest in\r\nview.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnd he glared at her with much meaning. Marian--both had remained\r\nstanding all through the dialogue--cast down her eyes and became lost in\r\nbrooding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I speak with profound conviction,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued her father, \xe2\x80\x98and, however\r\nlittle you credit me with such a motive, out of desire to guard you\r\nagainst the dangers to which your inexperience is exposed. It is perhaps\r\nas well that you have afforded me this--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere sounded at the house-door that duplicated double-knock which\r\ngenerally announces the bearer of a telegram. Yule interrupted himself,\r\nand stood in an attitude of waiting. The servant was heard to go along\r\nthe passage, to open the door, and then return towards the study. Yes,\r\nit was a telegram. Such despatches rarely came to this house; Yule tore\r\nthe envelope, read its contents, and stood with gaze fixed upon the slip\r\nof paper until the servant inquired if there was any reply for the boy\r\nto take with him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No reply.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe slowly crumpled the envelope, and stepped aside to throw it into the\r\npaper-basket. The telegram he laid on his desk. Marian stood all\r\nthe time with bent head; he now looked at her with an expression of\r\nmeditative displeasure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that there\xe2\x80\x99s much good in resuming our conversation,\xe2\x80\x99 he\r\nsaid, in quite a changed tone, as if something of more importance had\r\ntaken possession of his thoughts and had made him almost indifferent to\r\nthe past dispute. \xe2\x80\x98But of course I am quite willing to hear anything you\r\nwould still like to say.\r\n\r\nMarian had lost her vehemence. She was absent and melancholy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can only ask you,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied, \xe2\x80\x98to try and make life less of a\r\nburden to us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall have to leave town to-morrow for a few days; no doubt it will\r\nbe some satisfaction to you to hear that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian\xe2\x80\x99s eyes turned involuntarily towards the telegram.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As for your occupation in my absence,\xe2\x80\x99 he went on, in a hard tone which\r\nyet had something tremulous, emotional, making it quite different from\r\nthe voice he had hitherto used, \xe2\x80\x98that will be entirely a matter for your\r\nown judgment. I have felt for some time that you assisted me with less\r\ngood-will than formerly, and now that you have frankly admitted it, I\r\nshall of course have very little satisfaction in requesting your aid. I\r\nmust leave it to you; consult your own inclination.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was resentful, but not savage; between the beginning and the end of\r\nhis speech he softened to a sort of self-satisfied pathos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t pretend,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Marian, \xe2\x80\x98that I have as much pleasure in the\r\nwork as I should have if your mood were gentler.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry. I might perhaps have made greater efforts to appear at ease\r\nwhen I was suffering.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you mean physical suffering?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Physical and mental. But that can\xe2\x80\x99t concern you. During my absence I\r\nwill think of your reproof. I know that it is deserved, in some degree.\r\nIf it is possible, you shall have less to complain of in future.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe looked about the room, and at length seated himself; his eyes were\r\nfixed in a direction away from Marian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose you had dinner somewhere?\xe2\x80\x99 Marian asked, after catching a\r\nglimpse of his worn, colourless face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I had a mouthful of something. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt seemed as if he found some special pleasure in assuming this tone of\r\nmartyrdom just now. At the same time he was becoming more absorbed in\r\nthought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall I have something brought up for you, father?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Something--? Oh no, no; on no account.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe rose again impatiently, then approached his desk, and laid a hand on\r\nthe telegram. Marian observed this movement, and examined his face; it\r\nwas set in an expression of eagerness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have nothing more to say, then?\xe2\x80\x99 He turned sharply upon her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feel that I haven\xe2\x80\x99t made you understand me, but I can say nothing\r\nmore.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I understand you very well--too well. That you should misunderstand and\r\nmistrust me, I suppose, is natural. You are young, and I am old. You are\r\nstill full of hope, and I have been so often deceived and defeated that\r\nI dare not let a ray of hope enter my mind. Judge me; judge me as hardly\r\nas you like. My life has been one long, bitter struggle, and if now--. I\r\nsay,\xe2\x80\x99 he began a new sentence, \xe2\x80\x98that only the hard side of life has been\r\nshown to me; small wonder if I have become hard myself. Desert me;\r\ngo your own way, as the young always do. But bear in mind my warning.\r\nRemember the caution I have given you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe spoke in a strangely sudden agitation. The arm with which he leaned\r\nupon the table trembled violently. After a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause he added, in a\r\nthick voice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Leave me. I will speak to you again in the morning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nImpressed in a way she did not understand, Marian at once obeyed, and\r\nrejoined her mother in the parlour. Mrs Yule gazed anxiously at her as\r\nshe entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, with difficulty bringing herself to\r\nspeak. \xe2\x80\x98I think it will be better.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Was that a telegram that came?\xe2\x80\x99 her mother inquired after a silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know where it was from. But father said he would have to\r\nleave town for a few days.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey exchanged looks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps your uncle is very ill,\xe2\x80\x99 said the mother in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe evening passed drearily. Fatigued with her emotions, Marian went\r\nearly to bed; she even slept later than usual in the morning, and on\r\ndescending she found her father already at the breakfast-table. No\r\ngreeting passed, and there was no conversation during the meal. Marian\r\nnoticed that her mother kept glancing at her in a peculiarly grave way;\r\nbut she felt ill and dejected, and could fix her thoughts on no subject.\r\nAs he left the table Yule said to her:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I want to speak to you for a moment. I shall be in the study.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe joined him there very soon. He looked coldly at her, and said in a\r\ndistant tone:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The telegram last night was to tell me that your uncle is dead.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Dead!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He died of apoplexy, at a meeting in Wattleborough. I shall go down\r\nthis morning, and of course remain till after the funeral. I see no\r\nnecessity for your going, unless, of course, it is your desire to do\r\nso.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; I should do as you wish.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you had better not go to the Museum whilst I am away. You will\r\noccupy yourself as you think fit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall go on with the Harrington notes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you please. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what mourning it would be decent for you to\r\nwear; you must consult with your mother about that. That is all I wished\r\nto say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis tone was dismissal. Marian had a struggle with herself but she could\r\nfind nothing to reply to his cold phrases. And an hour or two afterwards\r\nYule left the house without leave-taking.\r\n\r\nSoon after his departure there was a visitor\xe2\x80\x99s rat-tat at the door;\r\nit heralded Mrs Goby. In the interview which then took place Marian\r\nassisted her mother to bear the vigorous onslaughts of the haberdasher\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwife. For more than two hours Mrs Goby related her grievances, against\r\nthe fugitive servant, against Mrs Yule, against Mr Yule; meeting with no\r\nirritating opposition, she was able in this space of time to cool down\r\nto the temperature of normal intercourse, and when she went forth from\r\nthe house again it was in a mood of dignified displeasure which she felt\r\nto be some recompense for the injuries of yesterday.\r\n\r\nA result of this annoyance was to postpone conversation between mother\r\nand daughter on the subject of John Yule\xe2\x80\x99s death until a late hour of\r\nthe afternoon. Marian was at work in the study, or endeavouring to work,\r\nfor her thoughts would not fix themselves on the matter in hand for\r\nmany minutes together, and Mrs Yule came in with more than her customary\r\ndiffidence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you nearly done for to-day, dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Enough for the present, I think.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe laid down her pen, and leant back in the chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Marian, do you think your father will be rich?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no idea, mother. I suppose we shall know very soon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHer tone was dreamy. She seemed to herself to be speaking of something\r\nwhich scarcely at all concerned her, of vague possibilities which did\r\nnot affect her habits of thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If that happens,\xe2\x80\x99 continued Mrs Yule, in a low tone of distress, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know what I shall do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian looked at her questioningly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t wish that it mayn\xe2\x80\x99t happen,\xe2\x80\x99 her mother went on; \xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t, for\r\nhis sake and for yours; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I shall do. He\xe2\x80\x99d think me\r\nmore in his way than ever. He\xe2\x80\x99d wish to have a large house, and live\r\nin quite a different way; and how could I manage then? I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t show\r\nmyself; he\xe2\x80\x99d be too much ashamed of me. I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be in my place; even\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d feel ashamed of me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mustn\xe2\x80\x99t say that, mother. I have never given you cause to think\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, my dear, you haven\xe2\x80\x99t; but it would be only natural. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t live\r\nthe kind of life that you\xe2\x80\x99re fit for. I shall be nothing but a hindrance\r\nand a shame to both of you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To me you would never be either hindrance or shame; be quite sure of\r\nthat. And as for father, I am all but certain that, if he became rich,\r\nhe would be a very much kinder man, a better man in every way. It is\r\npoverty that has made him worse than he naturally is; it has that effect\r\non almost everybody. Money does harm, too, sometimes; but never, I\r\nthink, to people who have a good heart and a strong mind. Father is\r\nnaturally a warm-hearted man; riches would bring out all the best in\r\nhim. He would be generous again, which he has almost forgotten how to\r\nbe among all his disappointments and battlings. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid of that\r\nchange, but hope for it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Yule gave a troublous sigh, and for a few minutes pondered\r\nanxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t thinking so much about myself\xe2\x80\x99 she said at length. \xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nhindrance I should be to father. Just because of me, he mightn\xe2\x80\x99t be able\r\nto use his money as he\xe2\x80\x99d wish. He\xe2\x80\x99d always be feeling that if it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nfor me things would be so much better for him and for you as well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You must remember,\xe2\x80\x99 Marian replied, \xe2\x80\x98that at father\xe2\x80\x99s age people don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncare to make such great changes. His home life, I feel sure, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nso very different from what it is now; he would prefer to use his money\r\nin starting a paper or magazine. I know that would be his first thought.\r\nIf more acquaintances came to his house, what would that matter? It\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t as if he wished for fashionable society. They would be literary\r\npeople, and why ever shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you meet with them?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve always been the reason why he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have many friends.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s a great mistake. If father ever said that, in his bad temper, he\r\nknew it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the truth. The chief reason has always been his poverty.\r\nIt costs money to entertain friends; time as well. Don\xe2\x80\x99t think in this\r\nanxious way, mother. If we are to be rich, it will be better for all of\r\nus.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian had every reason for seeking to persuade herself that this was\r\ntrue. In her own heart there was a fear of how wealth might affect her\r\nfather, but she could not bring herself to face the darker prospect. For\r\nher so much depended on that hope of a revival of generous feeling under\r\nsunny influences.\r\n\r\nIt was only after this conversation that she began to reflect on all the\r\npossible consequences of her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s death. As yet she had been too much\r\ndisturbed to grasp as a reality the event to which she had often looked\r\nforward, though as to something still remote, and of quite uncertain\r\nresults. Perhaps at this moment, though she could not know it, the\r\ncourse of her life had undergone the most important change. Perhaps\r\nthere was no more need for her to labour upon this \xe2\x80\x98article\xe2\x80\x99 she was\r\nmanufacturing.\r\n\r\nShe did not think it probable that she herself would benefit directly by\r\nJohn Yule\xe2\x80\x99s will. There was no certainty that even her father would, for\r\nhe and his brother had never been on cordial terms. But on the whole it\r\nseemed likely that he would inherit money enough to free him from the\r\ntoil of writing for periodicals. He himself anticipated that. What else\r\ncould be the meaning of those words in which (and it was before\r\nthe arrival of the news) he had warned her against \xe2\x80\x98people who made\r\nconnections only with self-interest in view?\xe2\x80\x99 This threw a sudden light\r\nupon her father\xe2\x80\x99s attitude towards Jasper Milvain. Evidently he thought\r\nthat Jasper regarded her as a possible heiress, sooner or later.\r\nThat suspicion was rankling in his mind; doubtless it intensified the\r\nprejudice which originated in literary animosity.\r\n\r\nWas there any truth in his suspicion? She did not shrink from admitting\r\nthat there might be. Jasper had from the first been so frank with her,\r\nhad so often repeated that money was at present his chief need. If her\r\nfather inherited substantial property, would it induce Jasper to declare\r\nhimself more than her friend? She could view the possibility of that,\r\nand yet not for a moment be shaken in her love. It was plain that\r\nJasper could not think of marrying until his position and prospects were\r\ngreatly improved; practically, his sisters depended upon him. What folly\r\nit would be to draw back if circumstances led him to avow what hitherto\r\nhe had so slightly disguised! She had the conviction that he valued her\r\nfor her own sake; if the obstacle between them could only be removed,\r\nwhat matter how?\r\n\r\nWould he be willing to abandon Clement Fadge, and come over to her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s side? If Yule were able to found a magazine?\r\n\r\nHad she read or heard of a girl who went so far in concessions, Marian\r\nwould have turned away, her delicacy offended. In her own case she could\r\nindulge to the utmost that practicality which colours a woman\xe2\x80\x99s thought\r\neven in mid passion. The cold exhibition of ignoble scheming will repel\r\nmany a woman who, for her own heart\xe2\x80\x99s desire, is capable of that same\r\ncompromise with her strict sense of honour.\r\n\r\nMarian wrote to Dora Milvain, telling her what had happened. But she\r\nrefrained from visiting her friends.\r\n\r\nEach night found her more restless, each morning less able to employ\r\nherself. She shut herself in the study merely to be alone with her\r\nthoughts, to be able to walk backwards and forwards, or sit for hours in\r\nfeverish reverie. From her father came no news. Her mother was suffering\r\ndreadfully from suspense, and often had eyes red with weeping. Absorbed\r\nin her own hopes and fears, whilst every hour harassed her more\r\nintolerably, Marian was unable to play the part of an encourager; she\r\nhad never known such exclusiveness of self-occupation.\r\n\r\nYule\xe2\x80\x99s return was unannounced. Early in the afternoon, when he had been\r\nabsent five days, he entered the house, deposited his travelling-bag in\r\nthe passage, and went upstairs. Marian had come out of the study just\r\nin time to see him up on the first landing; at the same moment Mrs Yule\r\nascended from the kitchen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Wasn\xe2\x80\x99t that father?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, he has gone up.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did he say anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian shook her head. They looked at the travelling-bag, then went into\r\nthe parlour and waited in silence for more than a quarter of an hour.\r\nYule\xe2\x80\x99s foot was heard on the stairs; he came down slowly, paused in the\r\npassage, entered the parlour with his usual grave, cold countenance.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXII. THE LEGATEES\r\n\r\nEach day Jasper came to inquire of his sisters if they had news from\r\nWattleborough or from Marian Yule. He exhibited no impatience, spoke of\r\nthe matter in a disinterested tone; still, he came daily.\r\n\r\nOne afternoon he found Dora working alone. Maud, he was told, had gone\r\nto lunch at Mrs Lane\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So soon again? She\xe2\x80\x99s getting very thick with those people. And why\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t they ask you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Maud has told them that I don\xe2\x80\x99t care to go out.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s all very well, but she mustn\xe2\x80\x99t neglect her work. Did she write\r\nanything last night or this morning?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora bit the end of her pen and shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why not?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The invitation came about five o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and it seemed to unsettle her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Precisely. That\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid of. She isn\xe2\x80\x99t the kind of girl to\r\nstick at work if people begin to send her invitations. But I tell you\r\nwhat it is, you must talk seriously to her; she has to get her living,\r\nyou know. Mrs Lane and her set are not likely to be much use, that\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nworst of it; they\xe2\x80\x99ll merely waste her time, and make her discontented.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis sister executed an elaborate bit of cross-hatching on some waste\r\npaper. Her lips were drawn together, and her brows wrinkled. At length\r\nshe broke the silence by saying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Marian hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been yet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper seemed to pay no attention; she looked up at him, and saw that he\r\nwas in thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did you go to those people last night?\xe2\x80\x99 she inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. By-the-bye, Miss Rupert was there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe spoke as if the name would be familiar to his hearer, but Dora seemed\r\nat a loss.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Who is Miss Rupert?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I tell you about her? I thought I did. Oh, I met her first of\r\nall at Barlow\xe2\x80\x99s, just after we got back from the seaside. Rather an\r\ninteresting girl. She\xe2\x80\x99s a daughter of Manton Rupert, the advertising\r\nagent. I want to get invited to their house; useful people, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But is an advertising agent a gentleman?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think of him as a bill-poster? At all events he is enormously\r\nwealthy, and has a magnificent house at Chislehurst. The girl goes about\r\nwith her stepmother. I call her a girl, but she must be nearly thirty,\r\nand Mrs Rupert looks only two or three years older. I had quite a long\r\ntalk with her--Miss Rupert, I mean--last night. She told me she was\r\ngoing to stay next week with the Barlows, so I shall have a run out to\r\nWimbledon one afternoon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora looked at him inquiringly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just to see Miss Rupert?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked, meeting his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure. Why not?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99 ejaculated his sister, as if the question did not concern her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She isn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly good-looking,\xe2\x80\x99 pursued Jasper, meditatively, with a\r\nquick glance at the listener, \xe2\x80\x98but fairly intellectual. Plays very well,\r\nand has a nice contralto voice; she sang that new thing of Tosti\xe2\x80\x99s--what\r\ndo you call it? I thought her rather masculine when I first saw her, but\r\nthe impression wears off when one knows her better. She rather takes to\r\nme, I fancy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But--\xe2\x80\x99 began Dora, after a minute\xe2\x80\x99s silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But what?\xe2\x80\x99 inquired her brother with an air of interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t quite understand you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In general, or with reference to some particular?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What right have you to go to places just to see this Miss Rupert?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What right?\xe2\x80\x99 He laughed. \xe2\x80\x98I am a young man with my way to make. I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nafford to lose any opportunity. If Miss Rupert is so good as to take an\r\ninterest in me, I have no objection. She\xe2\x80\x99s old enough to make friends\r\nfor herself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, then you consider her simply a friend?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall see how things go on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, pray, do you consider yourself perfectly free?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Dora, with\r\nsome indignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I think you have been behaving very strangely.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper saw that she was in earnest. He stroked the back of his head and\r\nsmiled at the wall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With regard to Marian, you mean?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course I do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But Marian understands me perfectly. I have never for a moment tried\r\nto make her think that--well, to put it plainly, that I was in love with\r\nher. In all our conversations it has been my one object to afford her\r\ninsight into my character, and to explain my position. She has no excuse\r\nwhatever for misinterpreting me. And I feel assured that she has done\r\nnothing of the kind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well, if you feel satisfied with yourself--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But come now, Dora; what\xe2\x80\x99s all this about? You are Marian\xe2\x80\x99s friend,\r\nand, of course, I don\xe2\x80\x99t wish you to say a word about her.\r\n\r\nBut let me explain myself. I have occasionally walked part of the way\r\nhome with Marian, when she and I have happened to go from here at the\r\nsame time; now there was nothing whatever in our talk at such times that\r\nanyone mightn\xe2\x80\x99t have listened to. We are both intellectual people, and\r\nwe talk in an intellectual way. You seem to have rather old-fashioned\r\nideas--provincial ideas. A girl like Marian Yule claims the new\r\nprivileges of woman; she would resent it if you supposed that she\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be friendly with a man without attributing \xe2\x80\x9cintentions\xe2\x80\x9d to\r\nhim--to use the old word. We don\xe2\x80\x99t live in Wattleborough, where liberty\r\nis rendered impossible by the cackling of gossips.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, but--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It seems to me rather strange, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. We had better not talk about\r\nit any more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I have only just begun to talk about it; I must try to make\r\nmy position intelligible to you. Now, suppose--a quite impossible\r\nthing--that Marian inherited some twenty or thirty thousand pounds; I\r\nshould forthwith ask her to be my wife.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh indeed!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see no reason for sarcasm. It would be a most rational proceeding.\r\nI like her very much; but to marry her (supposing she would have me)\r\nwithout money would he a gross absurdity, simply spoiling my career, and\r\nleading to all sorts of discontents.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No one would suggest that you should marry as things are.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; but please to bear in mind that to obtain money somehow or\r\nother--and I see no other way than by marriage--is necessary to me, and\r\nthat with as little delay as possible. I am not at all likely to get a\r\nbig editorship for some years to come, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel disposed to make\r\nmyself prematurely old by toiling for a few hundreds per annum in the\r\nmeantime. Now all this I have frankly and fully explained to Marian. I\r\ndare say she suspects what I should do if she came into possession of\r\nmoney; there\xe2\x80\x99s no harm in that. But she knows perfectly well that, as\r\nthings are, we remain intellectual friends.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then listen to me, Jasper. If we hear that Marian gets nothing from her\r\nuncle, you had better behave honestly, and let her see that you haven\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nas much interest in her as before.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That would be brutality.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be honest.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, no, it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t. Strictly speaking, my interest in Marian\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t suffer at all. I should know that we could be nothing but\r\nfriends, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Hitherto I haven\xe2\x80\x99t known what might come to pass;\r\nI don\xe2\x80\x99t know yet. So far from following your advice, I shall let Marian\r\nunderstand that, if anything, I am more her friend than ever, seeing\r\nthat henceforth there can be no ambiguities.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can only tell you that Maud would agree with me in what I have been\r\nsaying.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then both of you have distorted views.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think not. It\xe2\x80\x99s you who are unprincipled.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear girl, haven\xe2\x80\x99t I been showing you that no man could be more\r\nabove-board, more straightforward?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have been talking nonsense, Jasper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense? Oh, this female lack of logic! Then my argument has been\r\nutterly thrown away. Now that\xe2\x80\x99s one of the things I like in Miss Rupert;\r\nshe can follow an argument and see consequences. And for that matter so\r\ncan Marian. I only wish it were possible to refer this question to her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a tap at the door. Dora called \xe2\x80\x98Come in!\xe2\x80\x99 and Marian herself\r\nappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What an odd thing!\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Jasper, lowering his voice. \xe2\x80\x98I was that\r\nmoment saying I wished it were possible to refer a question to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora reddened, and stood in an embarrassed attitude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was the old dispute whether women in general are capable of logic.\r\nBut pardon me, Miss Yule; I forget that you have been occupied with sad\r\nthings since I last saw you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora led her to a chair, asking if her father had returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, he came back yesterday.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper and his sister could not think it likely that Marian had suffered\r\nmuch from grief at her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s death; practically John Yule was a\r\nstranger to her. Yet her face bore the signs of acute mental trouble,\r\nand it seemed as if some agitation made it difficult for her to speak.\r\nThe awkward silence that fell upon the three was broken by Jasper, who\r\nexpressed a regret that he was obliged to take his leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Maud is becoming a young lady of society,\xe2\x80\x99 he said--just for the sake\r\nof saying something--as he moved towards the door. \xe2\x80\x98If she comes back\r\nwhilst you are here, Miss Yule, warn her that that is the path of\r\ndestruction for literary people.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You should bear that in mind yourself\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Dora, with a\r\nsignificant look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I am cool-headed enough to make society serve my own ends.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian turned her head with a sudden movement which was checked before\r\nshe had quite looked round to him. The phrase he uttered last appeared\r\nto have affected her in some way; her eyes fell, and an expression of\r\npain was on her brows for a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can only stay a few minutes,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, bending with a faint smile\r\ntowards Dora, as soon as they were alone. \xe2\x80\x98I have come on my way from\r\nthe Museum.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where you have tired yourself to death as usual, I can see.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; I have done scarcely anything. I only pretended to read; my mind is\r\ntoo much troubled. Have you heard anything about my uncle\xe2\x80\x99s will?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing whatever.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought it might have been spoken of in Wattleborough, and some\r\nfriend might have written to you. But I suppose there has hardly been\r\ntime for that. I shall surprise you very much. Father receives nothing,\r\nbut I have a legacy of five thousand pounds.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora kept her eyes down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then--what do you think?\xe2\x80\x99 continued Marian. \xe2\x80\x98My cousin Amy has ten\r\nthousand pounds.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good gracious! What a difference that will make!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, indeed. And her brother John has six thousand. But nothing to\r\ntheir mother. There are a good many other legacies, but most of\r\nthe property goes to the Wattleborough park--\xe2\x80\x9cYule Park\xe2\x80\x9d it will be\r\ncalled--and to the volunteers, and things of that kind. They say he\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t as rich as people thought.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know what Miss Harrow gets?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She has the house for her life, and fifteen hundred pounds.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And your father nothing whatever?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing. Not a penny. Oh I am so grieved! I think it so unkind, so\r\nwrong. Amy and her brother to have sixteen thousand pounds and father\r\nnothing! I can\xe2\x80\x99t understand it. There was no unkind feeling between him\r\nand father. He knew what a hard life father has had. Doesn\xe2\x80\x99t it seem\r\nheartless?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What does your father say?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think he feels the unkindness more than he does the disappointment;\r\nof course he must have expected something. He came into the room where\r\nmother and I were, and sat down, and began to tell us about the will\r\njust as if he were speaking to strangers about something he had read in\r\nthe newspaper--that\xe2\x80\x99s the only way I can describe it. Then he got up and\r\nwent away into the study. I waited a little, and then went to him there;\r\nhe was sitting at work, as if he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been away from home at all. I\r\ntried to tell him how sorry I was, but I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t say anything. I began\r\nto cry foolishly. He spoke kindly to me, far more kindly than he has\r\ndone for a long time; but he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t talk about the will, and I had to\r\ngo away and leave him. Poor mother! for all she was afraid that we were\r\ngoing to be rich, is broken-hearted at his disappointment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your mother was afraid?\xe2\x80\x99 said Dora.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because she thought herself unfitted for life in a large house, and\r\nfeared we should think her in our way.\xe2\x80\x99 She smiled sadly. \xe2\x80\x98Poor mother!\r\nshe is so humble and so good. I do hope that father will be kinder to\r\nher. But there\xe2\x80\x99s no telling yet what the result of this may be. I feel\r\nguilty when I stand before him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But he must feel glad that you have five thousand pounds.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian delayed her reply for a moment, her eyes down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, perhaps he is glad of that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He can\xe2\x80\x99t help thinking, Dora, what use he could have made of it.\r\nIt has always been his greatest wish to have a literary paper of his\r\nown--like The Study, you know. He would have used the money in that way,\r\nI am sure.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But, all the same, he ought to feel pleasure in your good fortune.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian turned to another subject.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Think of the Reardons; what a change all at once! What will they do, I\r\nwonder? Surely they won\xe2\x80\x99t continue to live apart?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We shall hear from Jasper.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhilst they were discussing the affairs of that branch of the family,\r\nMaud returned. There was ill-humour on her handsome face, and she\r\ngreeted Marian but coldly. Throwing off her hat and gloves and mantle\r\nshe listened to the repeated story of John Yule\xe2\x80\x99s bequests.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But why ever has Mrs Reardon so much more than anyone else?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We can only suppose it is because she was the favourite child of the\r\nbrother he liked best. Yet at her wedding he gave her nothing, and spoke\r\ncontemptuously of her for marrying a literary man.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fortunate for her poor husband that her uncle was able to forgive her.\r\nI wonder what\xe2\x80\x99s the date of the will? Who knows but he may have rewarded\r\nher for quarrelling with Mr Reardon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis excited a laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know when the will was made,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian. \xe2\x80\x98And I don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nwhether uncle had even heard of the Reardons\xe2\x80\x99 misfortunes. I suppose he\r\nmust have done. My cousin John was at the funeral, but not my aunt. I\r\nthink it most likely father and John didn\xe2\x80\x99t speak a word to each other.\r\nFortunately the relatives were lost sight of in the great crowd of\r\nWattleborough people; there was an enormous procession, of course.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMaud kept glancing at her sister. The ill-humour had not altogether\r\npassed from her face, but it was now blended with reflectiveness.\r\n\r\nA few moments more, and Marian had to hasten home. When she was gone the\r\nsisters looked at each other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Five thousand pounds,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured the elder. \xe2\x80\x98I suppose that is\r\nconsidered nothing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose so.--He was here when Marian came, but didn\xe2\x80\x99t stay.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you\xe2\x80\x99ll take him the news this evening?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Dora. Then, after musing, \xe2\x80\x98He seemed annoyed that you\r\nwere at the Lanes\xe2\x80\x99 again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMaud made a movement of indifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What has been putting you out?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Things were rather stupid. Some people who were to have come didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nturn up. And--well, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe rose and glanced at herself in the little oblong mirror over the\r\nmantelpiece.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did Jasper ever speak to you of a Miss Rupert?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Dora.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not that I remember.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you think? He told me in the calmest way that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t see\r\nwhy Marian should think of him as anything but the most ordinary\r\nfriend--said he had never given her reason to think anything else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed! And Miss Rupert is someone who has the honour of his\r\npreference?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He says she is about thirty, and rather masculine, but a great heiress.\r\nJasper is shameful!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What do you expect? I consider it is your duty to let Marian know\r\neverything he says. Otherwise you help to deceive her. He has no sense\r\nof honour in such things.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora was so impatient to let her brother have the news that she left\r\nthe house as soon as she had had tea on the chance of finding Jasper\r\nat home. She had not gone a dozen yards before she encountered him in\r\nperson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was afraid Marian might still be with you,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, laughing.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should have asked the landlady. Well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We can\xe2\x80\x99t stand talking here. You had better come in.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe was in too much excitement to wait.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just tell me.
