What has she?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora walked quickly towards the house, looking annoyed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing at all? Then what has her father?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He has nothing,\xe2\x80\x99 replied his sister, \xe2\x80\x98and she has five thousand\r\npounds.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper walked on with bent head. He said nothing more until he was\r\nupstairs in the sitting-room, where Maud greeted him carelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mrs Reardon anything?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora informed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What?\xe2\x80\x99 he cried incredulously. \xe2\x80\x98Ten thousand? You don\xe2\x80\x99t say so!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe burst into uproarious laughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So Reardon is rescued from the slum and the clerk\xe2\x80\x99s desk! Well, I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nglad; by Jove, I am. I should have liked it better if Marian had had the\r\nten thousand and he the five, but it\xe2\x80\x99s an excellent joke. Perhaps the\r\nnext thing will be that he\xe2\x80\x99ll refuse to have anything to do with his\r\nwife\xe2\x80\x99s money; that would be just like him.\xe2\x80\x99 After amusing himself with\r\nthis subject for a few minutes more, he turned to the window and stood\r\nthere in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you going to have tea with us?\xe2\x80\x99 Dora inquired.\r\n\r\nHe did not seem to hear her. On a repetition of the inquiry, he answered\r\nabsently:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I may as well. Then I can go home and get to work.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDuring the remainder of his stay he talked very little, and as Maud also\r\nwas in an abstracted mood, tea passed almost in silence. On the point of\r\ndeparting he asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When is Marian likely to come here again?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I haven\xe2\x80\x99t the least idea,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Dora.\r\n\r\nHe nodded, and went his way.\r\n\r\nIt was necessary for him to work at a magazine article which he had\r\nbegun this morning, and on reaching home he spread out his papers in\r\nthe usual businesslike fashion. The subject out of which he was\r\nmanufacturing \xe2\x80\x98copy\xe2\x80\x99 had its difficulties, and was not altogether\r\ncongenial to him; this morning he had laboured with unwonted effort to\r\nproduce about a page of manuscript, and now that he tried to resume the\r\ntask his thoughts would not centre upon it. Jasper was too young to have\r\nthoroughly mastered the art of somnambulistic composition; to write,\r\nhe was still obliged to give exclusive attention to the matter under\r\ntreatment. Dr Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s saying, that a man may write at any time if he\r\nwill set himself doggedly to it, was often upon his lips, and had even\r\nbeen of help to him, as no doubt it has to many another man obliged to\r\ncompose amid distracting circumstances; but the formula had no efficacy\r\nthis evening. Twice or thrice he rose from his chair, paced the room\r\nwith a determined brow, and sat down again with vigorous clutch of the\r\npen; still he failed to excogitate a single sentence that would serve\r\nhis purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must have it out with myself before I can do anything,\xe2\x80\x99 was his\r\nthought as he finally abandoned the endeavour. \xe2\x80\x98I must make up my mind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTo this end he settled himself in an easy-chair and began to smoke\r\ncigarettes. Some dozen of these aids to reflection only made him so\r\nnervous that he could no longer remain alone. He put on his hat and\r\novercoat and went out--to find that it was raining heavily. He returned\r\nfor an umbrella, and before long was walking aimlessly about the Strand,\r\nunable to make up his mind whether to turn into a theatre or not.\r\nInstead of doing so, he sought a certain upper room of a familiar\r\nrestaurant, where the day\xe2\x80\x99s papers were to be seen, and perchance an\r\nacquaintance might be met. Only half-a-dozen men were there, reading and\r\nsmoking, and all were unknown to him. He drank a glass of lager beer,\r\nskimmed the news of the evening, and again went out into the bad\r\nweather.\r\n\r\nAfter all it was better to go home. Everything he encountered had an\r\nunsettling effect upon him, so that he was further than ever from the\r\ndecision at which he wished to arrive. In Mornington Road he came upon\r\nWhelpdale, who was walking slowly under an umbrella.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve just called at your place.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98All right; come back if you like.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But perhaps I shall waste your time?\xe2\x80\x99 said Whelpdale, with unusual\r\ndiffidence.\r\n\r\nReassured, he gladly returned to the house. Milvain acquainted him\r\nwith the fact of John Yule\xe2\x80\x99s death, and with its result so far as it\r\nconcerned the Reardons. They talked of how the couple would probably\r\nbehave under this decisive change of circumstances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Biffen professes to know nothing about Mrs Reardon,\xe2\x80\x99 said Whelpdale. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nsuspect he keeps his knowledge to himself, out of regard for Reardon. It\r\nwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t surprise me if they live apart for a long time yet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not very likely. It was only want of money.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They\xe2\x80\x99re not at all suited to each other. Mrs Reardon, no doubt, repents\r\nher marriage bitterly, and I doubt whether Reardon cares much for his\r\nwife.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As there\xe2\x80\x99s no way of getting divorced they\xe2\x80\x99ll make the best of it. Ten\r\nthousand pounds produce about four hundred a year; it\xe2\x80\x99s enough to live\r\non.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And be miserable on--if they no longer love each other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re such a sentimental fellow!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Jasper. \xe2\x80\x98I believe you\r\nseriously think that love--the sort of frenzy you understand by\r\nit--ought to endure throughout married life. How has a man come to your\r\nage with such primitive ideas?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. Perhaps you err a little in the opposite\r\ndirection.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I haven\xe2\x80\x99t much faith in marrying for love, as you know. What\xe2\x80\x99s more,\r\nI believe it\xe2\x80\x99s the very rarest thing for people to be in love with each\r\nother. Reardon and his wife perhaps were an instance; perhaps--I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nnot quite sure about her. As a rule, marriage is the result of a mild\r\npreference, encouraged by circumstances, and deliberately heightened\r\ninto strong sexual feeling. You, of all men, know well enough that the\r\nsame kind of feeling could be produced for almost any woman who wasn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nrepulsive.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The same kind of feeling; but there\xe2\x80\x99s vast difference of degree.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure. I think it\xe2\x80\x99s only a matter of degree. When it rises to the\r\npoint of frenzy people may strictly be said to be in love; and, as I\r\ntell you, I think that comes to pass very rarely indeed. For my own\r\npart, I have no experience of it, and think I never shall have.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t say the same.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I dare say you have imagined yourself in love--or really been so for\r\naught I know--a dozen times. How the deuce you can attach any importance\r\nto such feeling where marriage is concerned I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Whelpdale, \xe2\x80\x98I have never upheld the theory--at least\r\nnot since I was sixteen--that a man can be in love only once, or that\r\nthere is one particular woman if he misses whom he can never be happy.\r\nThere may be thousands of women whom I could love with equal sincerity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I object to the word \xe2\x80\x9clove\xe2\x80\x9d altogether. It has been vulgarised. Let us\r\ntalk about compatibility. Now, I should say that, no doubt, and speaking\r\nscientifically, there is one particular woman supremely fitted to\r\neach man. I put aside consideration of circumstances; we know that\r\ncircumstances will disturb any degree of abstract fitness. But in the\r\nnature of things there must be one woman whose nature is specially well\r\nadapted to harmonise with mine, or with yours. If there were any means\r\nof discovering this woman in each case, then I have no doubt it would\r\nbe worth a man\xe2\x80\x99s utmost effort to do so, and any amount of erotic\r\njubilation would be reasonable when the discovery was made. But\r\nthe thing is impossible, and, what\xe2\x80\x99s more, we know what ridiculous\r\nfallibility people display when they imagine they have found the best\r\nsubstitute for that indiscoverable. This is what makes me impatient with\r\nsentimental talk about marriage. An educated man mustn\xe2\x80\x99t play so into\r\nthe hands of ironic destiny. Let him think he wants to marry a woman;\r\nbut don\xe2\x80\x99t let him exaggerate his feelings or idealise their nature.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s a good deal in all that,\xe2\x80\x99 admitted Whelpdale, though\r\ndiscontentedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s more than a good deal; there\xe2\x80\x99s the last word on the subject.\r\nThe days of romantic love are gone by. The scientific spirit has put\r\nan end to that kind of self-deception. Romantic love was inextricably\r\nblended with all sorts of superstitions--belief in personal immortality,\r\nin superior beings, in--all the rest of it. What we think of now is\r\nmoral and intellectual and physical compatibility; I mean, if we are\r\nreasonable people.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And if we are not so unfortunate as to fall in love with an\r\nincompatible,\xe2\x80\x99 added Whelpdale, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, that is a form of unreason--a blind desire which science could\r\nexplain in each case. I rejoice that I am not subject to that form of\r\nepilepsy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You positively never were in love!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you understand it, never. But I have felt a very distinct\r\npreference.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Based on what you think compatibility?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Not strong enough to make me lose sight of prudence and advantage.\r\nNo, not strong enough for that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe seemed to be reassuring himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then of course that can\xe2\x80\x99t be called love,\xe2\x80\x99 said Whelpdale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps not. But, as I told you, a preference of this kind can be\r\nheightened into emotion, if one chooses. In the case of which I am\r\nthinking it easily might be. And I think it very improbable indeed that\r\nI should repent it if anything led me to indulge such an impulse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhelpdale smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98This is very interesting. I hope it may lead to something.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it will. I am far more likely to marry some woman for\r\nwhom I have no preference, but who can serve me materially.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I confess that amazes me. I know the value of money as well as you do,\r\nbut I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t marry a rich woman for whom I had no preference. By Jove,\r\nno!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes. You are a consistent sentimentalist.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Doomed to perpetual disappointment,\xe2\x80\x99 said the other, looking\r\ndisconsolately about the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Courage, my boy! I have every hope that I shall see you marry and\r\nrepent.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I admit the danger of that. But shall I tell you something I have\r\nobserved? Each woman I fall in love with is of a higher type than the\r\none before.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper roared irreverently, and his companion looked hurt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I am perfectly serious, I assure you. To go back only three or four\r\nyears. There was the daughter of my landlady in Barham Street; well, a\r\nnice girl enough, but limited, decidedly limited.\r\n\r\nNext came that girl at the stationer\xe2\x80\x99s--you remember? She was distinctly\r\nan advance, both in mind and person. Then there was Miss Embleton; yes,\r\nI think she made again an advance. She had been at Bedford College,\r\nyou know, and was really a girl of considerable attainments; morally,\r\nadmirable. Afterwards--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The maiden from Birmingham, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it?\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper, again exploding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, it was. Well, I can\xe2\x80\x99t be quite sure. But in many respects that\r\ngirl was my ideal; she really was.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you once or twice told me at the time.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really believe she would rank above Miss Embleton--at all events from\r\nmy point of view. And that\xe2\x80\x99s everything, you know. It\xe2\x80\x99s the effect a\r\nwoman produces on one that has to be considered.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The next should be a paragon,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The next?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nWhelpdale again looked about the room, but added nothing, and fell into\r\na long silence.\r\n\r\nWhen left to himself Jasper walked about a little, then sat down at his\r\nwriting-table, for he felt easier in mind, and fancied that he might\r\nstill do a couple of hours\xe2\x80\x99 work before going to bed. He did in fact\r\nwrite half-a-dozen lines, but with the effort came back his former mood.\r\nVery soon the pen dropped, and he was once more in the throes of anxious\r\nmental debate.\r\n\r\nHe sat till after midnight, and when he went to his bedroom it was with\r\na lingering step, which proved him still a prey to indecision.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPART FOUR\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIII. A PROPOSED INVESTMENT\r\n\r\nAlfred Yule\xe2\x80\x99s behaviour under his disappointment seemed to prove that\r\neven for him the uses of adversity could be sweet. On the day after his\r\nreturn home he displayed a most unwonted mildness in such remarks as\r\nhe addressed to his wife, and his bearing towards Marian was gravely\r\ngentle. At meals he conversed, or rather monologised, on literary\r\ntopics, with occasionally one of his grim jokes, pointed for Marian\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nappreciation. He became aware that the girl had been overtaxing her\r\nstrength of late, and suggested a few weeks of recreation among new\r\nnovels. The coldness and gloom which had possessed him when he made a\r\nformal announcement of the news appeared to have given way before the\r\nsympathy manifested by his wife and daughter; he was now sorrowful, but\r\nresigned.\r\n\r\nHe explained to Marian the exact nature of her legacy. It was to be paid\r\nout of her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s share in a wholesale stationery business, with which\r\nJohn Yule had been connected for the last twenty years, but from which\r\nhe had not long ago withdrawn a large portion of his invested capital.\r\nThis house was known as \xe2\x80\x98Turberville & Co.,\xe2\x80\x99 a name which Marian now\r\nheard for the first time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I knew nothing of his association with them,\xe2\x80\x99 said her father. \xe2\x80\x98They\r\ntell me that seven or eight thousand pounds will be realised from that\r\nsource; it seems a pity that the investment was not left to you intact.\r\nWhether there will be any delay in withdrawing the money I can\xe2\x80\x99t say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe executors were two old friends of the deceased, one of them a former\r\npartner in his paper-making concern.\r\n\r\nOn the evening of the second day, about an hour after dinner was over,\r\nMr Hinks called at the house; as usual, he went into the study. Before\r\nlong came a second visitor, Mr Quarmby, who joined Yule and Hinks. The\r\nthree had all sat together for some time, when Marian, who happened to\r\nbe coming down stairs, saw her father at the study door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ask your mother to let us have some supper at a quarter to ten,\xe2\x80\x99 he\r\nsaid urbanely. \xe2\x80\x98And come in, won\xe2\x80\x99t you? We are only gossiping.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt had not often happened that Marian was invited to join parties of\r\nthis kind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you wish me to come?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I should like you to, if you have nothing particular to do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian informed Mrs Yule that the visitors would have supper, and then\r\nwent to the study. Mr Quarmby was smoking a pipe; Mr Hinks, who on\r\ngrounds of economy had long since given up tobacco, sat with his hands\r\nin his trouser pockets, and his long, thin legs tucked beneath the\r\nchair; both rose and greeted Marian with more than ordinary warmth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you allow me five or six more puffs?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mr Quarmby, laying one\r\nhand on his ample stomach and elevating his pipe as if it were a glass\r\nof beaded liquor. \xe2\x80\x98I shall then have done.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As many more as you like,\xe2\x80\x99 Marian replied.\r\n\r\nThe easiest chair was placed for her, Mr Hinks hastening to perform this\r\ncourtesy, and her father apprised her of the topic they were discussing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s your view, Marian? Is there anything to be said for the\r\nestablishment of a literary academy in England?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMr Quarmby beamed benevolently upon her, and Mr Hinks, his scraggy neck\r\nat full length, awaited her reply with a look of the most respectful\r\nattention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really think we have quite enough literary quarrelling as it is,\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\ngirl replied, casting down her eyes and smiling.\r\n\r\nMr Quarmby uttered a hollow chuckle, Mr Hinks laughed thinly and\r\nexclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98Very good indeed! Very good!\xe2\x80\x99 Yule affected to applaud with\r\nimpartial smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t harmonise with the Anglo-Saxon spirit,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Mr Hinks,\r\nwith an air of diffident profundity.\r\n\r\nYule held forth on the subject for a few minutes in laboured phrases.\r\nPresently the conversation turned to periodicals, and the three men were\r\nunanimous in an opinion that no existing monthly or quarterly could be\r\nconsidered as representing the best literary opinion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We want,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked Mr Quarmby, \xe2\x80\x98we want a monthly review which\r\nshall deal exclusively with literature. The Fortnightly, the\r\nContemporary--they are very well in their way, but then they are mere\r\nmiscellanies. You will find one solid literary article amid a confused\r\nmass of politics and economics and general clap-trap.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Articles on the currency and railway statistics and views of\r\nevolution,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Hinks, with a look as if something were grating\r\nbetween his teeth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The quarterlies?\xe2\x80\x99 put in Yule. \xe2\x80\x98Well, the original idea of the\r\nquarterlies was that there are not enough important books published to\r\noccupy solid reviewers more than four times a year. That may be true,\r\nbut then a literary monthly would include much more than professed\r\nreviews. Hinks\xe2\x80\x99s essays on the historical drama would have come out in\r\nit very well; or your \xe2\x80\x9cSpanish Poets,\xe2\x80\x9d Quarmby.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I threw out the idea to Jedwood the other day,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mr Quarmby, \xe2\x80\x98and\r\nhe seemed to nibble at it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes,\xe2\x80\x99 came from Yule; \xe2\x80\x98but Jedwood has so many irons in the fire.\r\nI doubt if he has the necessary capital at command just now. No doubt\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s the man, if some capitalist would join him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No enormous capital needed,\xe2\x80\x99 opined Mr Quarmby. \xe2\x80\x98The thing would\r\npay its way almost from the first. It would take a place between the\r\nliterary weeklies and the quarterlies. The former are too academic,\r\nthe latter too massive, for multitudes of people who yet have strong\r\nliterary tastes. Foreign publications should be liberally dealt with.\r\nBut, as Hinks says, no meddling with the books that are no books--biblia\r\nabiblia; nothing about essays on bimetallism and treatises for or\r\nagainst vaccination.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEven here, in the freedom of a friend\xe2\x80\x99s study, he laughed his\r\nReading-room laugh, folding both hands upon his expansive waistcoat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Fiction? I presume a serial of the better kind might be admitted?\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nYule.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That would be advisable, no doubt. But strictly of the better kind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, strictly of the better kind,\xe2\x80\x99 chimed in Mr Hinks.\r\n\r\nThey pursued the discussion as if they were an editorial committee\r\nplanning a review of which the first number was shortly to appear.\r\nIt occupied them until Mrs Yule announced at the door that supper was\r\nready.\r\n\r\nDuring the meal Marian found herself the object of unusual attention;\r\nher father troubled to inquire if the cut of cold beef he sent her was\r\nto her taste, and kept an eye on her progress. Mr Hinks talked to her in\r\na tone of respectful sympathy, and Mr Quarmby was paternally jovial when\r\nhe addressed her. Mrs Yule would have kept silence, in her ordinary way,\r\nbut this evening her husband made several remarks which he had adapted\r\nto her intellect, and even showed that a reply would be graciously\r\nreceived.\r\n\r\nMother and daughter remained together when the men withdrew to their\r\ntobacco and toddy. Neither made allusion to the wonderful change, but\r\nthey talked more light-heartedly than for a long time.\r\n\r\nOn the morrow Yule began by consulting Marian with regard to the\r\ndisposition of matter in an essay he was writing. What she said he\r\nweighed carefully, and seemed to think that she had set his doubts at\r\nrest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor old Hinks!\xe2\x80\x99 he said presently, with a sigh. \xe2\x80\x98Breaking up, isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhe? He positively totters in his walk. I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid he\xe2\x80\x99s the kind of\r\nman to have a paralytic stroke; it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t astonish me to hear at any\r\nmoment that he was lying helpless.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What ever would become of him in that case?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Goodness knows! One might ask the same of so many of us. What would\r\nbecome of me, for instance, if I were incapable of work?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian could make no reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s something I\xe2\x80\x99ll just mention to you,\xe2\x80\x99 he went on in a lowered\r\ntone, \xe2\x80\x98though I don\xe2\x80\x99t wish you to take it too seriously. I\xe2\x80\x99m beginning\r\nto have a little trouble with my eyes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe looked at him, startled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98With your eyes?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Nothing, I hope; but--well, I think I shall see an oculist. One doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncare to face a prospect of failing sight, perhaps of cataract, or\r\nsomething of that kind; still, it\xe2\x80\x99s better to know the facts, I should\r\nsay.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By all means go to an oculist,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, earnestly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t disturb yourself about it. It may be nothing at all. But in any\r\ncase I must change my glasses.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe rustled over some slips of manuscript, whilst Marian regarded him\r\nanxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now, I appeal to you, Marian,\xe2\x80\x99 he continued: \xe2\x80\x98could I possibly save\r\nmoney out of an income that has never exceeded two hundred and fifty\r\npounds, and often--I mean even in latter years--has been much less?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t see how you could.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In one way, of course, I have managed it. My life is insured for five\r\nhundred pounds. But that is no provision for possible disablement. If I\r\ncould no longer earn money with my pen, what would become of me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian could have made an encouraging reply, but did not venture to\r\nutter her thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sit down,\xe2\x80\x99 said her father. \xe2\x80\x98You are not to work for a few days, and I\r\nmyself shall be none the worse for a morning\xe2\x80\x99s rest. Poor old Hinks!\r\nI suppose we shall help him among us, somehow. Quarmby, of course, is\r\ncomparatively flourishing. Well, we have been companions for a quarter\r\nof a century, we three. When I first met Quarmby I was a Grub Street\r\ngazetteer, and I think he was even poorer than I. A life of toil! A life\r\nof toil!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That it has been, indeed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By-the-bye\xe2\x80\x99--he threw an arm over the back of his chair--\xe2\x80\x98what did\r\nyou think of our imaginary review, the thing we were talking about last\r\nnight?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There are so many periodicals,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Marian, doubtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So many? My dear child, if we live another ten years we shall see the\r\nnumber trebled.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is it desirable?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That there should be such growth of periodicals? Well, from one point\r\nof view, no. No doubt they take up the time which some people would\r\ngive to solid literature. But, on the other hand, there\xe2\x80\x99s a far greater\r\nnumber of people who would probably not read at all, but for the\r\ntemptations of these short and new articles; and they may be induced to\r\npass on to substantial works. Of course it all depends on the quality of\r\nthe periodical matter you offer. Now, magazines like\xe2\x80\x99--he named two or\r\nthree of popular stamp--\xe2\x80\x98might very well be dispensed with, unless one\r\nregards them as an alternative to the talking of scandal or any other\r\nvicious result of total idleness. But such a monthly as we projected\r\nwould be of distinct literary value. There can be no doubt that someone\r\nor other will shortly establish it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am afraid,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, \xe2\x80\x98I haven\xe2\x80\x99t so much sympathy with literary\r\nundertakings as you would like me to have.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMoney is a great fortifier of self-respect. Since she had become really\r\nconscious of her position as the owner of five thousand pounds, Marian\r\nspoke with a steadier voice, walked with firmer step; mentally she felt\r\nherself altogether a less dependent being. She might have confessed this\r\nlukewarmness towards literary enterprise in the anger which her father\r\nexcited eight or nine days ago, but at that time she could not have\r\nuttered her opinion calmly, deliberately, as now. The smile which\r\naccompanied the words was also new; it signified deliverance from\r\npupilage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have felt that,\xe2\x80\x99 returned her father, after a slight pause to command\r\nhis voice, that it might be suave instead of scornful. \xe2\x80\x98I greatly fear\r\nthat I have made your life something of a martyrdom----\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t think I meant that, father. I am speaking only of the general\r\nquestion. I can\xe2\x80\x99t be quite so zealous as you are, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. I love\r\nbooks, but I could wish people were content for a while with those we\r\nalready have.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My dear Marian, don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose that I am out of sympathy with you here.\r\nAlas! how much of my work has been mere drudgery, mere labouring for a\r\nlivelihood! How gladly I would have spent much more of my time among\r\nthe great authors, with no thought of making money of them! If I speak\r\napprovingly of a scheme for a new periodical, it is greatly because of\r\nmy necessities.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe paused and looked at her. Marian returned the look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would of course write for it,\xe2\x80\x99 she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Marian, why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I edit it? Why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it be your property?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My property--?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe checked a laugh. There came into her mind a more disagreeable\r\nsuspicion than she had ever entertained of her father. Was this\r\nthe meaning of his softened behaviour? Was he capable of calculated\r\nhypocrisy? That did not seem consistent with his character, as she knew\r\nit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let us talk it over,\xe2\x80\x99 said Yule. He was in visible agitation and his\r\nvoice shook. \xe2\x80\x98The idea may well startle you at first. It will seem to\r\nyou that I propose to make away with your property before you have even\r\ncome into possession of it.\xe2\x80\x99 He laughed. \xe2\x80\x98But, in fact, what I have in\r\nmind is merely an investment for your capital, and that an admirable\r\none. Five thousand pounds at three per cent.--one doesn\xe2\x80\x99t care to reckon\r\non more--represents a hundred and fifty a year. Now, there can be very\r\nlittle doubt that, if it were invested in literary property such as I\r\nhave in mind, it would bring you five times that interest, and before\r\nlong perhaps much more. Of course I am now speaking in the roughest\r\noutline. I should have to get trustworthy advice; complete and detailed\r\nestimates would be submitted to you. At present I merely suggest to you\r\nthis form of investment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe watched her face eagerly, greedily. When Marian\xe2\x80\x99s eyes rose to his he\r\nlooked away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then, of course,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, \xe2\x80\x98you don\xe2\x80\x99t expect me to give any decided\r\nanswer.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course not--of course not. I merely put before you the chief\r\nadvantages of such an investment. As I am a selfish old fellow, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ntalk about the benefit to myself first of all. I should be editor of the\r\nnew review; I should draw a stipend sufficient to all my needs--quite\r\ncontent, at first, to take far less than another man would ask, and to\r\nprogress with the advance of the periodical. This position would enable\r\nme to have done with mere drudgery; I should only write when I felt\r\ncalled to do so--when the spirit moved me.\xe2\x80\x99 Again he laughed, as though\r\ndesirous of keeping his listener in good humour. \xe2\x80\x98My eyes would be\r\ngreatly spared henceforth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe dwelt on that point, waiting its effect on Marian. As she said\r\nnothing he proceeded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And suppose I really were doomed to lose my sight in the course of a\r\nfew years, am I wrong in thinking that the proprietor of this periodical\r\nwould willingly grant a small annuity to the man who had firmly\r\nestablished it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I see the force of all that,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian; \xe2\x80\x98but it takes for granted\r\nthat the periodical will be successful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It does. In the hands of a publisher like Jedwood--a vigorous man of\r\nthe new school--its success could scarcely be doubtful.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think five thousand pounds would be enough to start such a\r\nreview?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, I can say nothing definite on that point. For one thing, the\r\ncoat must be made according to the cloth; expenditure can be largely\r\ncontrolled without endangering success. Then again, I think Jedwood\r\nwould take a share in the venture. These are details. At present I only\r\nwant to familiarise you with the thought that an investment of this sort\r\nwill very probably offer itself to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It would be better if we called it a speculation,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, smiling\r\nuneasily.\r\n\r\nHer one object at present was to oblige her father to understand that\r\nthe suggestion by no means lured her. She could not tell him that what\r\nhe proposed was out of the question, though as yet that was the light in\r\nwhich she saw it. His subtlety of approach had made her feel justified\r\nin dealing with him in a matter-of-fact way. He must see that she was\r\nnot to be cajoled. Obviously, and in the nature of the case, he was\r\nurging a proposal in which he himself had all faith; but Marian knew\r\nhis judgment was far from infallible. It mitigated her sense of behaving\r\nunkindly to reflect that in all likelihood this disposal of her money\r\nwould be the worst possible for her own interests, and therefore for\r\nhis. If, indeed, his dark forebodings were warranted, then upon her\r\nwould fall the care of him, and the steadiness with which she faced that\r\nresponsibility came from a hope of which she could not speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Name it as you will,\xe2\x80\x99 returned her father, hardly suppressing a note of\r\nirritation. \xe2\x80\x98True, every commercial enterprise is a speculation. But let\r\nme ask you one question, and beg you to reply frankly. Do you distrust\r\nmy ability to conduct this periodical?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe did. She knew that he was not in touch with the interests of the\r\nday, and that all manner of considerations akin to the prime end of\r\nselling his review would make him an untrustworthy editor.\r\n\r\nBut how could she tell him this?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My opinion would be worthless,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If Jedwood were disposed to put confidence in me, you also would?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no need to talk of that now, father. Indeed, I can\xe2\x80\x99t say\r\nanything that would sound like a promise.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe flashed a glance at her. Then she was more than doubtful?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you have no objection, Marian, to talk in a friendly way of a\r\nproject that would mean so much to me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I am afraid to encourage you,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied, frankly. \xe2\x80\x98It is\r\nimpossible for me to say whether I can do as you wish, or not.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes; I perfectly understand that. Heaven forbid that I should\r\nregard you as a child to be led independently of your own views and\r\nwishes! With so large a sum of money at stake, it would be monstrous\r\nif I acted rashly, and tried to persuade you to do the same. The matter\r\nwill have to be most gravely considered.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99 She spoke mechanically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But if only it should come to something! You don\xe2\x80\x99t know what it would\r\nmean to me, Marian.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, father; I know very well how you think and feel about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you?\xe2\x80\x99 He leaned forward, his features working under stress of\r\nemotion. \xe2\x80\x98If I could see myself the editor of an influential review, all\r\nmy bygone toils and sufferings would be as nothing; I should rejoice in\r\nthem as the steps to this triumph. Meminisse juvabit! My dear, I am not\r\na man fitted for subordinate places. My nature is framed for authority.\r\nThe failure of all my undertakings rankles so in my heart that sometimes\r\nI feel capable of every brutality, every meanness, every hateful\r\ncruelty. To you I have behaved shamefully. Don\xe2\x80\x99t interrupt me, Marian.\r\nI have treated you abominably, my child, my dear daughter--and all the\r\ntime with a full sense of what I was doing. That\xe2\x80\x99s the punishment of\r\nfaults such as mine. I hate myself for every harsh word and angry look I\r\nhave given you; at the time, I hated myself!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, no; let me speak, Marian. You have forgiven me; I know it. You were\r\nalways ready to forgive, dear. Can I ever forget that evening when I\r\nspoke like a brute, and you came afterwards and addressed me as if the\r\nwrong had been on your side? It burns in my memory. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t I who\r\nspoke; it was the demon of failure, of humiliation. My enemies sit\r\nin triumph, and scorn at me; the thought of it is infuriating. Have I\r\ndeserved this? Am I the inferior of--of those men who have succeeded\r\nand now try to trample on me? No! I am not! I have a better brain and a\r\nbetter heart!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nListening to this strange outpouring, Marian more than forgave the\r\nhypocrisy of the last day or two. Nay, could it be called hypocrisy? It\r\nwas only his better self declared at the impulse of a passionate hope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why should you think so much of these troubles, father? Is it such a\r\ngreat matter that narrow-minded people triumph over you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Narrow-minded?\xe2\x80\x99 He clutched at the word. \xe2\x80\x98You admit they are that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feel very sure that Mr Fadge is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you are not on his side against me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How could you suppose such a thing?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well; we won\xe2\x80\x99t talk of that. Perhaps it isn\xe2\x80\x99t a great matter.\r\nNo--from a philosophical point of view, such things are unspeakably\r\npetty. But I am not much of a philosopher.\xe2\x80\x99 He laughed, with a break in\r\nhis voice. \xe2\x80\x98Defeat in life is defeat, after all; and unmerited failure\r\nis a bitter curse. You see, I am not too old to do something yet. My\r\nsight is failing, but I can take care of it. If I had my own review, I\r\nwould write every now and then a critical paper in my very best style.\r\nYou remember poor old Hinks\xe2\x80\x99s note about me in his book? We laughed at\r\nit, but he wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so far wrong. I have many of those qualities. A man is\r\nconscious of his own merits as well as of his defects. I have done a few\r\nadmirable things. You remember my paper on Lord Herbert of Cherbury? No\r\none ever wrote a more subtle piece of criticism; but it was swept aside\r\namong the rubbish of the magazines. And it\xe2\x80\x99s just because of my pungent\r\nphrases that I have excited so much enmity. Wait! Wait! Let me have my\r\nown review, and leisure, and satisfaction of mind--heavens! what I will\r\nwrite! How I will scarify!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is unworthy of you. How much better to ignore your enemies!\r\nIn such a position, I should carefully avoid every word that betrayed\r\npersonal feeling.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, well; you are of course right, my good girl. And I believe I\r\nshould do injustice to myself if I made you think that those ignoble\r\nmotives are the strongest in me. No; it isn\xe2\x80\x99t so. From my boyhood I\r\nhave had a passionate desire of literary fame, deep down below all the\r\nsurface faults of my character. The best of my life has gone by, and it\r\ndrives me to despair when I feel that I have not gained the position due\r\nto me. There is only one way of doing this now, and that is by becoming\r\nthe editor of an important periodical. Only in that way shall I succeed\r\nin forcing people to pay attention to my claims. Many a man goes to\r\nhis grave unrecognised, just because he has never had a fair judgment.\r\nNowadays it is the unscrupulous men of business who hold the attention\r\nof the public; they blow their trumpets so loudly that the voices of\r\nhonest men have no chance of being heard.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian was pained by the humility of his pleading with her--for what was\r\nall this but an endeavour to move her sympathies?--and by the necessity\r\nshe was under of seeming to turn a deaf ear. She believed that there\r\nwas some truth in his estimate of his own powers; though as an editor\r\nhe would almost certainly fail, as a man of letters he had probably\r\ndone far better work than some who had passed him by on their way to\r\npopularity. Circumstances might enable her to assist him, though not in\r\nthe way he proposed. The worst of it was that she could not let him see\r\nwhat was in her mind. He must think that she was simply balancing\r\nher own satisfaction against his, when in truth she suffered from the\r\nconviction that to yield would be as unwise in regard to her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfuture as it would be perilous to her own prospect of happiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Shall we leave this to be talked of when the money has been paid over\r\nto me?\xe2\x80\x99 she said, after a silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose I wish to influence you by dwelling on my\r\nown hardships. That would be contemptible. I have only taken this\r\nopportunity of making myself better known to you. I don\xe2\x80\x99t readily talk\r\nof myself and in general my real feelings are hidden by the faults of\r\nmy temper. In suggesting how you could do me a great service, and at the\r\nsame time reap advantage for yourself I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t but remember how little\r\nreason you have to think kindly of me. But we will postpone further\r\ntalk. You will think over what I have said?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian promised that she would, and was glad to bring the conversation\r\nto an end.\r\n\r\nWhen Sunday came, Yule inquired of his daughter if she had any\r\nengagement for the afternoon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I have,\xe2\x80\x99 she replied, with an effort to disguise her\r\nembarrassment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry. I thought of asking you to come with me to Quarmby\xe2\x80\x99s. Shall\r\nyou be away through the evening?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Till about nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock, I think.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah! Never mind, never mind.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe tried to dismiss the matter as if it were of no moment, but Marian\r\nsaw the shadow that passed over his countenance. This was just after\r\nbreakfast. For the remainder of the morning she did not meet him, and at\r\nthe mid-day dinner he was silent, though he brought no book to the table\r\nwith him, as he was wont to do when in his dark moods. Marian\r\ntalked with her mother, doing her best to preserve the appearance of\r\ncheerfulness which was natural since the change in Yule\xe2\x80\x99s demeanour.\r\n\r\nShe chanced to meet her father in the passage just as she was going\r\nout. He smiled (it was more like a grin of pain) and nodded, but said\r\nnothing.\r\n\r\nWhen the front door closed, he went into the parlour. Mrs Yule was\r\nreading, or, at all events, turning over a volume of an illustrated\r\nmagazine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Where do you suppose she has gone?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked, in a voice which was only\r\ndistant, not offensive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To the Miss Milvains, I believe,\xe2\x80\x99 Mrs Yule answered, looking aside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did she tell you so?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. We don\xe2\x80\x99t talk about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe seated himself on the corner of a chair and bent forward, his chin in\r\nhis hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Has she said anything to you about the review?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a word.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe glanced at him timidly, and turned a few pages of her book.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wanted her to come to Quarmby\xe2\x80\x99s, because there\xe2\x80\x99ll be a man there who\r\nis anxious that Jedwood should start a magazine, and it would be useful\r\nfor her to hear practical opinions. There\xe2\x80\x99d be no harm if you just spoke\r\nto her about it now and then. Of course if she has made up her mind\r\nto refuse me it\xe2\x80\x99s no use troubling myself any more. I should think you\r\nmight find out what\xe2\x80\x99s really going on.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nOnly dire stress of circumstances could have brought Alfred Yule to make\r\ndistinct appeal for his wife\xe2\x80\x99s help. There was no underhand plotting\r\nbetween them to influence their daughter; Mrs Yule had as much desire\r\nfor the happiness of her husband as for that of Marian, but she felt\r\npowerless to effect anything on either side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If ever she says anything, I\xe2\x80\x99ll let you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it seems to me that you have a right to question her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t do that, Alfred.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Unfortunately, there are a good many things you can\xe2\x80\x99t do.\xe2\x80\x99 With that\r\nremark, familiar to his wife in substance, though the tone of it was\r\nless caustic than usual, he rose and sauntered from the room. He spent\r\na gloomy hour in the study, then went off to join the literary circle at\r\nMr Quarmby\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIV. JASPER\xe2\x80\x99S MAGNANIMITY\r\n\r\nOccasionally Milvain met his sisters as they came out of church on\r\nSunday morning, and walked home to have dinner with them. He did so\r\nto-day, though the sky was cheerless and a strong north-west wind made\r\nit anything but agreeable to wait about in open spaces.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you going to Mrs Wright\xe2\x80\x99s this afternoon?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked, as they went\r\non together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought of going,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Maud. \xe2\x80\x98Marian will be with Dora.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You ought both to go. You mustn\xe2\x80\x99t neglect that woman.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe said nothing more just then, but when presently he was alone with\r\nDora in the sitting-room for a few minutes, he turned with a peculiar\r\nsmile and remarked quietly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you had better go with Maud this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I can\xe2\x80\x99t. I expect Marian at three.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s just why I want you to go.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe looked her surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I want to have a talk with Marian. We\xe2\x80\x99ll manage it in this way. At a\r\nquarter to three you two shall start, and as you go out you can tell the\r\nlandlady that if Miss Yule comes she is to wait for you, as you won\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nlong. She\xe2\x80\x99ll come upstairs, and I shall be there. You see?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nDora turned half away, disturbed a little, but not displeased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what about Miss Rupert?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, Miss Rupert may go to Jericho for all I care. I\xe2\x80\x99m in a magnanimous\r\nmood.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very, I\xe2\x80\x99ve no doubt.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, you\xe2\x80\x99ll do this? One of the results of poverty, you see; one can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\neven have a private conversation with a friend without plotting to get\r\nthe use of a room. But there shall be an end of this state of things.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe nodded significantly. Thereupon Dora left the room to speak with her\r\nsister.\r\n\r\nThe device was put into execution, and Jasper saw his sisters depart\r\nknowing that they were not likely to return for some three hours. He\r\nseated himself comfortably by the fire and mused. Five minutes had\r\nhardly gone by when he looked at his watch, thinking Marian must be\r\nunpunctual. He was nervous, though he had believed himself secure\r\nagainst such weakness. His presence here with the purpose he had in his\r\nmind seemed to him distinctly a concession to impulses he ought to have\r\ncontrolled; but to this resolve he had come, and it was now too late to\r\nrecommence the arguments with himself. Too late? Well, not strictly so;\r\nhe had committed himself to nothing; up to the last moment of freedom he\r\ncould always--\r\n\r\nThat was doubtless Marian\xe2\x80\x99s knock at the front door. He jumped up,\r\nwalked the length of the room, sat down on another chair, returned to\r\nhis former seat. Then the door opened and Marian came in.\r\n\r\nShe was not surprised; the landlady had mentioned to her that Mr Milvain\r\nwas upstairs, waiting the return of his sisters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am to make Dora\xe2\x80\x99s excuses,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper said. \xe2\x80\x98She begged you would\r\nforgive her--that you would wait.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you were to be sure to take off your hat,\xe2\x80\x99 he added in a laughing\r\ntone; \xe2\x80\x98and to let me put your umbrella in the corner--like that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe had always admired the shape of Marian\xe2\x80\x99s head, and the beauty of her\r\nshort, soft, curly hair. As he watched her uncovering it, he was pleased\r\nwith the grace of her arms and the pliancy of her slight figure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which is usually your chair?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98When one goes to see a friend frequently, one gets into regular\r\nhabits in these matters. In Biffen\xe2\x80\x99s garret I used to have the most\r\nuncomfortable chair it was ever my lot to sit upon; still, I came to\r\nfeel an affection for it. At Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s I always had what was supposed to\r\nbe the most luxurious seat, but it was too small for me, and I eyed it\r\nresentfully on sitting down and rising.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you any news about the Reardons?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I am told that Reardon has had the offer of a secretaryship to a\r\nboys\xe2\x80\x99 home, or something of the kind, at Croydon. But I suppose there\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nbe no need for him to think of that now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Surely not!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh there\xe2\x80\x99s no saying.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why should he do work of that kind now?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Perhaps his wife will tell him that she wants her money all for\r\nherself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian laughed. It was very rarely that Jasper had heard her laugh at\r\nall, and never so spontaneously as this. He liked the music.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You haven\xe2\x80\x99t a very good opinion of Mrs Reardon,\xe2\x80\x99 she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She is a difficult person to judge. I never disliked her, by any means;\r\nbut she was decidedly out of place as the wife of a struggling author.\r\nPerhaps I have been a little prejudiced against her since Reardon\r\nquarrelled with me on her account.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian was astonished at this unlooked-for explanation of the rupture\r\nbetween Milvain and his friend. That they had not seen each other for\r\nsome months she knew from Jasper himself but no definite cause had been\r\nassigned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I may as well let you know all about it,\xe2\x80\x99 Milvain continued, seeing\r\nthat he had disconcerted the girl, as he meant to. \xe2\x80\x98I met Reardon not\r\nlong after they had parted, and he charged me with being in great part\r\nthe cause of his troubles.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe listener did not raise her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would never imagine what my fault was. Reardon declared that the\r\ntone of my conversation had been morally injurious to his wife. He said\r\nI was always glorifying worldly success, and that this had made her\r\ndiscontented with her lot. Sounds rather ludicrous, don\xe2\x80\x99t you think?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was very strange.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Reardon was in desperate earnest, poor fellow. And, to tell you the\r\ntruth, I fear there may have been something in his complaint.\r\n\r\nI told him at once that I should henceforth keep away from Mrs Edmund\r\nYule\xe2\x80\x99s; and so I have done, with the result, of course, that they\r\nsuppose I condemn Mrs Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s behaviour. The affair was a nuisance,\r\nbut I had no choice, I think.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You say that perhaps your talk really was harmful to her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It may have been, though such a danger never occurred to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then Amy must be very weak-minded.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be influenced by such a paltry fellow?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be influenced by anyone in such a way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You think the worse of me for this story?\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t quite understand it. How did you talk to her?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As I talk to everyone. You have heard me say the same things many a\r\ntime. I simply declare my opinion that the end of literary work--unless\r\none is a man of genius--is to secure comfort and repute. This doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nseem to me very scandalous. But Mrs Reardon was perhaps too urgent in\r\nrepeating such views to her husband. She saw that in my case they were\r\nlikely to have solid results, and it was a misery to her that Reardon\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t or wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t work in the same practical way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was very unfortunate.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you are inclined to blame me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; because I am so sure that you only spoke in the way natural to you,\r\nwithout a thought of such consequences.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s precisely the truth. Nearly all men who have their way to make\r\nthink as I do, but most feel obliged to adopt a false tone, to talk\r\nabout literary conscientiousness, and so on. I simply say what I think,\r\nwith no pretences. I should like to be conscientious, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a luxury\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t afford. I\xe2\x80\x99ve told you all this often enough, you know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But it hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been morally injurious to you,\xe2\x80\x99 he said with a laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not at all. Still I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper was startled. He gazed at her. Ought he, then, to have dealt\r\nwith her less frankly? Had he been mistaken in thinking that the\r\nunusual openness of his talk was attractive to her? She spoke with quite\r\nunaccustomed decision; indeed, he had noticed from her entrance that\r\nthere was something unfamiliar in her way of conversing. She was so much\r\nmore self-possessed than of wont, and did not seem to treat him with the\r\nsame deference, the same subdual of her own personality.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t like it?\xe2\x80\x99 he repeated calmly. \xe2\x80\x98It has become rather tiresome\r\nto you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feel sorry that you should always represent yourself in an\r\nunfavourable light.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe was an acute man, but the self-confidence with which he had entered\r\nupon this dialogue, his conviction that he had but to speak when he\r\nwished to receive assurance of Marian\xe2\x80\x99s devotion, prevented him from\r\nunderstanding the tone of independence she had suddenly adopted. With\r\nmore modesty he would have felt more subtly at this juncture, would have\r\ndivined that the girl had an exquisite pleasure in drawing back now that\r\nshe saw him approaching her with unmistakable purpose, that she wished\r\nto be wooed in less off-hand fashion before confessing what was in her\r\nheart. For the moment he was disconcerted. Those last words of hers had\r\na slight tone of superiority, the last thing he would have expected upon\r\nher lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yet I surely haven\xe2\x80\x99t always appeared so--to you?\xe2\x80\x99 he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, not always.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you are in doubt concerning the real man?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure that I understand you. You say that you do really think as\r\nyou speak.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So I do. I think that there is no choice for a man who can\xe2\x80\x99t bear\r\npoverty. I have never said, though, that I had pleasure in mean\r\nnecessities; I accept them because I can\xe2\x80\x99t help it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was a delight to Marian to observe the anxiety with which he turned\r\nto self-defence. Never in her life had she felt this joy of holding a\r\nposition of command. It was nothing to her that Jasper valued her more\r\nbecause of her money; impossible for it to be otherwise. Satisfied that\r\nhe did value her, to begin with, for her own sake, she was very willing\r\nto accept money as her ally in the winning of his love. He scarcely\r\nloved her yet, as she understood the feeling, but she perceived her\r\npower over him, and passion taught her how to exert it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you resign yourself very cheerfully to the necessity,\xe2\x80\x99 she said,\r\nlooking at him with merely intellectual eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You had rather I lamented my fate in not being able to devote myself to\r\nnobly unremunerative work?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was a note of irony here. It caused her a tremor, but she held her\r\nposition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That you never do so would make one think--but I won\xe2\x80\x99t speak unkindly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That I neither care for good work nor am capable of it,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper\r\nfinished her sentence. \xe2\x80\x98I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have thought it would make you think\r\nso.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nInstead of replying she turned her look towards the door. There was a\r\nfootstep on the stairs, but it passed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I thought it might be Dora,\xe2\x80\x99 she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She won\xe2\x80\x99t be here for another couple of hours at least,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Jasper\r\nwith a slight smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you said--?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I sent her to Mrs Boston Wright\xe2\x80\x99s that I might have an opportunity of\r\ntalking to you. Will you forgive the stratagem?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian resumed her former attitude, the faintest smile hovering about\r\nher lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m glad there\xe2\x80\x99s plenty of time,\xe2\x80\x99 he continued. \xe2\x80\x98I begin to suspect\r\nthat you have been misunderstanding me of late. I must set that right.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I have misunderstood you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That may mean something very disagreeable. I know that some people whom\r\nI esteem have a very poor opinion of me, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t allow you to be one\r\nof them. What do I seem to you? What is the result on your mind of all\r\nour conversations?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have already told you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not seriously. Do you believe I am capable of generous feeling?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To say no, would be to put you in the lowest class of men, and that a\r\nvery small one.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good! Then I am not among the basest. But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t give me very\r\ndistinguished claims upon your consideration. Whatever I am, I am high\r\nin some of my ambitions.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which of them?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98For instance, I have been daring enough to hope that you might love\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian delayed for a moment, then said quietly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why do you call that daring?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because I have enough of old-fashioned thought to believe that a woman\r\nwho is worthy of a man\xe2\x80\x99s love is higher than he, and condescends in\r\ngiving herself to him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis voice was not convincing; the phrase did not sound natural on his\r\nlips. It was not thus that she had hoped to hear him speak. Whilst he\r\nexpressed himself thus conventionally he did not love her as she desired\r\nto be loved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t hold that view,\xe2\x80\x99 she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t surprise me. You are very reserved on all subjects, and we\r\nhave never spoken of this, but of course I know that your thought is\r\nnever commonplace. Hold what view you like of woman\xe2\x80\x99s position, that\r\ndoesn\xe2\x80\x99t affect mine.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is yours commonplace, then?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Desperately. Love is a very old and common thing, and I believe I love\r\nyou in the old and common way. I think you beautiful, you seem to me\r\nwomanly in the best sense, full of charm and sweetness. I know myself a\r\ncoarse being in comparison. All this has been felt and said in the same\r\nway by men infinite in variety. Must I find some new expression before\r\nyou can believe me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian kept silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I know what you are thinking,\xe2\x80\x99 he said. \xe2\x80\x98The thought is as inevitable\r\nas my consciousness of it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nFor an instant she looked at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, you look the thought. Why have I not spoken to you in this\r\nway before? Why have I waited until you are obliged to suspect my\r\nsincerity?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98My thought is not so easily read, then,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98To be sure it hasn\xe2\x80\x99t a gross form, but I know you wish--whatever your\r\nreal feeling towards me--that I had spoken a fortnight ago. You would\r\nwish that of any man in my position, merely because it is painful to you\r\nto see a possible insincerity. Well, I am not insincere. I have thought\r\nof you as of no other woman for some time. But--yes, you shall have the\r\nplain, coarse truth, which is good in its way, no doubt. I was afraid to\r\nsay that I loved you. You don\xe2\x80\x99t flinch; so far, so good. Now what harm\r\nis there in this confession? In the common course of things I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe in a position to marry for perhaps three or four years, and even then\r\nmarriage would mean difficulties, restraints, obstacles. I have always\r\ndreaded the thought of marriage with a poor income. You remember?\r\n\r\n     Love in a hut, with water and a crust,\r\n     Is--Love forgive us!--cinders, ashes, dust.\r\n\r\nYou know that is true.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not always, I dare say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But for the vast majority of mortals. There\xe2\x80\x99s the instance of the\r\nReardons. They were in love with each other, if ever two people were;\r\nbut poverty ruined everything. I am not in the confidence of either of\r\nthem, but I feel sure each has wished the other dead. What else was\r\nto be expected? Should I have dared to take a wife in my present\r\ncircumstances--a wife as poor as myself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will be in a much better position before long,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you loved me, why should you have been afraid to ask me to have\r\nconfidence in your future?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s all so uncertain. It may be another ten years before I can count\r\non an income of five or six hundred pounds--if I have to struggle on in\r\nthe common way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But tell me, what is your aim in life? What do you understand by\r\nsuccess?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I will tell you. My aim is to have easy command of all the\r\npleasures desired by a cultivated man. I want to live among beautiful\r\nthings, and never to be troubled by a thought of vulgar difficulties.\r\nI want to travel and enrich my mind in foreign countries. I want to\r\nassociate on equal terms with refined and interesting people. I want to\r\nbe known, to be familiarly referred to, to feel when I enter a room that\r\npeople regard me with some curiosity.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe looked steadily at her with bright eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And that\xe2\x80\x99s all?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Marian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is very much. Perhaps you don\xe2\x80\x99t know how I suffer in feeling\r\nmyself at a disadvantage. My instincts are strongly social, yet I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nbe at my ease in society, simply because I can\xe2\x80\x99t do justice to myself.\r\nWant of money makes me the inferior of the people I talk with, though\r\nI might be superior to them in most things. I am ignorant in many\r\nways, and merely because I am poor. Imagine my never having been out of\r\nEngland! It shames me when people talk familiarly of the Continent. So\r\nwith regard to all manner of amusements and pursuits at home. Impossible\r\nfor me to appear among my acquaintances at the theatre, at concerts.\r\nI am perpetually at a disadvantage; I haven\xe2\x80\x99t fair play. Suppose me\r\npossessed of money enough to live a full and active life for the next\r\nfive years; why, at the end of that time my position would be secure. To\r\nhim that hath shall be given--you know how universally true that is.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And yet,\xe2\x80\x99 came in a low voice from Marian, \xe2\x80\x98you say that you love me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mean that I speak as if no such thing as love existed. But you\r\nasked me what I understood by success. I am speaking of worldly things.\r\nNow suppose I had said to you:\r\n\r\nMy one aim and desire in life is to win your love. Could you have\r\nbelieved me? Such phrases are always untrue; I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how it\r\ncan give anyone pleasure to hear them. But if I say to you: All the\r\nsatisfactions I have described would be immensely heightened if they\r\nwere shared with a woman who loved me--there is the simple truth.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian\xe2\x80\x99s heart sank. She did not want truth such as this; she would have\r\npreferred that he should utter the poor, common falsehoods. Hungry for\r\npassionate love, she heard with a sense of desolation all this calm\r\nreasoning. That Jasper was of cold temperament she had often feared; yet\r\nthere was always the consoling thought that she did not see with perfect\r\nclearness into his nature. Now and then had come a flash, a hint of\r\npossibilities. She had looked forward with trembling eagerness to some\r\nsudden revelation; but it seemed as if he knew no word of the language\r\nwhich would have called such joyous response from her expectant soul.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We have talked for a long time,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, turning her head as if his\r\nlast words were of no significance. \xe2\x80\x98As Dora is not coming, I think I\r\nwill go now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe rose, and went towards the chair on which lay her out-of-door\r\nthings. At once Jasper stepped to her side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will go without giving me any answer?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Answer? To what?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you be my wife?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It is too soon to ask me that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Too soon? Haven\xe2\x80\x99t you known for months that I thought of you with far\r\nmore than friendliness?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How was it possible I should know that? You have explained to me why\r\nyou would not let your real feelings be understood.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe reproach was merited, and not easy to be outfaced. He turned away\r\nfor an instant, then with a sudden movement caught both her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Whatever I have done or said or thought in the past, that is of no\r\naccount now. I love you, Marian. I want you to be my wife. I have never\r\nseen any other girl who impressed me as you did from the first. If I had\r\nbeen weak enough to try to win anyone but you, I should have known that\r\nI had turned aside from the path of my true happiness. Let us forget for\r\na moment all our circumstances. I hold your hands, and look into your\r\nface, and say that I love you. Whatever answer you give, I love you!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nTill now her heart had only fluttered a little; it was a great part of\r\nher distress that the love she had so long nurtured seemed shrinking\r\ntogether into some far corner of her being whilst she listened to\r\nthe discourses which prefaced Jasper\xe2\x80\x99s declaration. She was nervous,\r\npainfully self-conscious, touched with maidenly shame, but could not\r\nabandon herself to that delicious emotion which ought to have been the\r\nfulfilment of all her secret imaginings. Now at length there began a\r\nthrobbing in her bosom. Keeping her face averted, her eyes cast down,\r\nshe waited for a repetition of the note that was in that last \xe2\x80\x98I love\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x99 She felt a change in the hands that held hers--a warmth, a moist\r\nsoftness; it caused a shock through her veins.\r\n\r\nHe was trying to draw her nearer, but she kept at full arm\xe2\x80\x99s length and\r\nlooked irresponsive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Marian?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe wished to answer, but a spirit of perversity held her tongue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Marian, don\xe2\x80\x99t you love me? Or have I offended you by my way of\r\nspeaking?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nPersisting, she at length withdrew her hands. Jasper\xe2\x80\x99s face expressed\r\nsomething like dismay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have not offended me,\xe2\x80\x99 she said. \xe2\x80\x98But I am not sure that you don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndeceive yourself in thinking, for the moment, that I am necessary to\r\nyour happiness.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe emotional current which had passed from her flesh to his whilst\r\ntheir hands were linked, made him incapable of standing aloof from her.\r\nHe saw that her face and neck were warmer hued, and her beauty became\r\nmore desirable to him than ever yet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are more to me than anything else in the compass of life!\xe2\x80\x99 he\r\nexclaimed, again pressing forward. \xe2\x80\x98I think of nothing but you--you\r\nyourself--my beautiful, gentle, thoughtful Marian!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHis arm captured her, and she did not resist. A sob, then a strange\r\nlittle laugh, betrayed the passion that was at length unfolded in her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You do love me, Marian?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I love you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAnd there followed the antiphony of ardour that finds its first\r\nutterance--a subdued music, often interrupted, ever returning upon the\r\nsame rich note.\r\n\r\nMarian closed her eyes and abandoned herself to the luxury of the dream.\r\nIt was her first complete escape from the world of intellectual routine,\r\nher first taste of life. All the pedantry of her daily toil slipped away\r\nlike a cumbrous garment; she was clad only in her womanhood. Once or\r\ntwice a shudder of strange self-consciousness went through her, and\r\nshe felt guilty, immodest; but upon that sensation followed a surge of\r\npassionate joy, obliterating memory and forethought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How shall I see you?\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper asked at length. \xe2\x80\x98Where can we meet?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was a difficulty. The season no longer allowed lingerings under\r\nthe open sky, but Marian could not go to his lodgings, and it seemed\r\nimpossible for him to visit her at her home.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will your father persist in unfriendliness to me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe was only just beginning to reflect on all that was involved in this\r\nnew relation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no hope that he will change,\xe2\x80\x99 she said sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98He will refuse to countenance your marriage?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall disappoint him and grieve him bitterly. He has asked me to use\r\nmy money in starting a new review.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which he is to edit?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. Do you think there would be any hope of its success?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nJasper shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your father is not the man for that, Marian. I don\xe2\x80\x99t say it\r\ndisrespectfully; I mean that he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to me to have that kind of\r\naptitude. It would be a disastrous speculation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I felt that. Of course I can\xe2\x80\x99t think of it now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe smiled, raising her face to his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t trouble,\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper. \xe2\x80\x98Wait a little, till I have made myself\r\nindependent of Fadge and a few other men, and your father shall see\r\nhow heartily I wish to be of use to him. He will miss your help, I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nafraid?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I shall feel it a cruelty when I have to leave him. He has only\r\njust told me that his sight is beginning to fail. Oh, why didn\xe2\x80\x99t his\r\nbrother leave him a little money? It was such unkindness! Surely he had\r\na much better right than Amy, or than myself either. But literature has\r\nbeen a curse to father all his life. My uncle hated it, and I suppose\r\nthat was why he left father nothing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But how am I to see you often? That\xe2\x80\x99s the first question. I know what I\r\nshall do. I must take new lodgings, for the girls and myself, all in\r\nthe same house. We must have two sitting-rooms; then you will come to my\r\nroom without any difficulty. These astonishing proprieties are so easily\r\nsatisfied after all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will really do that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I shall go and look for rooms to-morrow. Then when you come you\r\ncan always ask for Maud or Dora, you know. They will be very glad of a\r\nchange to more respectable quarters.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I won\xe2\x80\x99t stay to see them now, Jasper,\xe2\x80\x99 said Marian, her thoughts\r\nturning to the girls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well. You are safe for another hour, but to make certain you shall\r\ngo at a quarter to five. Your mother won\xe2\x80\x99t be against us?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Poor mother--no. But she won\xe2\x80\x99t dare to justify me before father.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I feel as if I should play a mean part in leaving it to you to tell\r\nyour father. Marian, I will brave it out and go and see him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, it would be better not to.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I will write to him--such a letter as he can\xe2\x80\x99t possibly take in\r\nill part.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMarian pondered this proposal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You shall do that, Jasper, if you are willing. But not yet; presently.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You don\xe2\x80\x99t wish him to know at once?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We had better wait a little. You know,\xe2\x80\x99 she added laughing, \xe2\x80\x98that my\r\nlegacy is only in name mine as yet. The will hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been proved. And\r\nthen the money will have to be realised.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe informed him of the details; Jasper listened with his eyes on the\r\nground.\r\n\r\nThey were now sitting on chairs drawn close to each other. It was with\r\na sense of relief that Jasper had passed from dithyrambs to conversation\r\non practical points; Marian\xe2\x80\x99s excited sensitiveness could not but\r\nobserve this, and she kept watching the motions of his countenance. At\r\nlength he even let go her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You would prefer,\xe2\x80\x99 he said reflectively, \xe2\x80\x98that nothing should be said\r\nto your father until that business is finished?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you consent to it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I have no doubt it\xe2\x80\x99s as well.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHer little phrase of self-subjection, and its tremulous tone, called for\r\nanother answer than this. Jasper fell again into thought, and clearly it\r\nwas thought of practical things.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think I must go now, Jasper,\xe2\x80\x99 she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Must you? Well, if you had rather.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe rose, though she was still seated. Marian moved a few steps away, but\r\nturned and approached him again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you really love me?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked, taking one of his hands and folding\r\nit between her own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I do indeed love you, Marian. Are you still doubtful?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99re not sorry that I must go?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I am, dearest. I wish we could sit here undisturbed all through the\r\nevening.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHer touch had the same effect as before. His blood warmed again, and he\r\npressed her to his side, stroking her hair and kissing her forehead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Are you sorry I wear my hair short?\xe2\x80\x99 she asked, longing for more praise\r\nthan he had bestowed on her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Sorry? It is perfect. Everything else seems vulgar compared with this\r\nway of yours. How strange you would look with plaits and that kind of\r\nthing!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am so glad it pleases you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There is nothing in you that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t please me, my thoughtful girl.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You called me that before. Do I seem so very thoughtful?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So grave, and sweetly reserved, and with eyes so full of meaning.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe quivered with delight, her face hidden against his breast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I seem to be new-born, Jasper. Everything in the world is new to me,\r\nand I am strange to myself. I have never known an hour of happiness till\r\nnow, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t believe yet that it has come to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe at length attired herself, and they left the house together, of\r\ncourse not unobserved by the landlady. Jasper walked about half the way\r\nto St Paul\xe2\x80\x99s Crescent. It was arranged that he should address a letter\r\nfor her to the care of his sisters; but in a day or two the change of\r\nlodgings would be effected.\r\n\r\nWhen they had parted, Marian looked back. But Jasper was walking quickly\r\naway, his head bent, in profound meditation.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXV. A FRUITLESS MEETING\r\n\r\nRefuge from despair is often found in the passion of self-pity and that\r\nspirit of obstinate resistance which it engenders. In certain natures\r\nthe extreme of self-pity is intolerable, and leads to self-destruction;\r\nbut there are less fortunate beings whom the vehemence of their revolt\r\nagainst fate strengthens to endure in suffering. These latter are rather\r\nimaginative than passionate; the stages of their woe impress them as\r\nthe acts of a drama, which they cannot bring themselves to cut short, so\r\nvarious are the possibilities of its dark motive. The intellectual man\r\nwho kills himself is most often brought to that decision by conviction\r\nof his insignificance; self-pity merges in self-scorn, and the\r\nhumiliated soul is intolerant of existence. He who survives under like\r\nconditions does so because misery magnifies him in his own estimate.\r\n\r\nIt was by force of commiserating his own lot that Edwin Reardon\r\ncontinued to live through the first month after his parting from Amy.\r\nOnce or twice a week, sometimes early in the evening, sometimes at\r\nmidnight or later, he haunted the street at Westbourne Park where his\r\nwife was dwelling, and on each occasion he returned to his garret with\r\na fortified sense of the injustice to which he was submitted, of revolt\r\nagainst the circumstances which had driven him into outer darkness, of\r\nbitterness against his wife for saving her own comfort rather than\r\nshare his downfall. At times he was not far from that state of sheer\r\ndistraction which Mrs Edmund Yule preferred to suppose that he had\r\nreached. An extraordinary arrogance now and then possessed him; he stood\r\namid his poor surroundings with the sensations of an outraged exile, and\r\nlaughed aloud in furious contempt of all who censured or pitied him.\r\n\r\nOn hearing from Jasper Milvain that Amy had fallen ill, or at all\r\nevents was suffering in health from what she had gone through, he felt\r\na momentary pang which all but determined him to hasten to her side.
