The\r\nreaction was a feeling of distinct pleasure that she had her share of\r\npain, and even a hope that her illness might become grave; he pictured\r\nhimself summoned to her sick chamber, imagined her begging his\r\nforgiveness. But it was not merely, nor in great part, a malicious\r\nsatisfaction; he succeeded in believing that Amy suffered because she\r\nstill had a remnant of love for him. As the days went by and he heard\r\nnothing, disappointment and resentment occupied him. At length he ceased\r\nto haunt the neighbourhood. His desires grew sullen; he became fixed in\r\nthe resolve to hold entirely apart and doggedly await the issue.\r\n\r\nAt the end of each month he sent half the money he had received from\r\nCarter, simply enclosing postal orders in an envelope addressed to his\r\nwife. The first two remittances were in no way acknowledged; the third\r\nbrought a short note from Amy:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As you continue to send these sums of money, I had perhaps better let\r\nyou know that I cannot use them for any purposes of my own. Perhaps a\r\nsense of duty leads you to make this sacrifice, but I am afraid it\r\nis more likely that you wish to remind me every month that you are\r\nundergoing privations, and to pain me in this way. What you have sent I\r\nhave deposited in the Post Office Savings\xe2\x80\x99 Bank in Willie\xe2\x80\x99s name, and I\r\nshall continue to do so.--A.R.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nFor a day or two Reardon persevered in an intention of not replying, but\r\nthe desire to utter his turbid feelings became in the end too strong. He\r\nwrote:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I regard it as quite natural that you should put the worst\r\ninterpretation on whatever I do. As for my privations, I think very\r\nlittle of them; they are a trifle in comparison with the thought that\r\nI am forsaken just because my pocket is empty. And I am far indeed from\r\nthinking that you can be pained by whatever I may undergo; that would\r\nsuppose some generosity in your nature.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis was no sooner posted than he would gladly have recalled it. He knew\r\nthat it was undignified, that it contained as many falsehoods as lines,\r\nand he was ashamed of himself for having written so. But he could not\r\npen a letter of retractation, and there remained with him a new cause of\r\nexasperated wretchedness.\r\n\r\nExcepting the people with whom he came in contact at the hospital, he\r\nhad no society but that of Biffen. The realist visited him once a\r\nweek, and this friendship grew closer than it had been in the time of\r\nReardon\xe2\x80\x99s prosperity. Biffen was a man of so much natural delicacy, that\r\nthere was a pleasure in imparting to him the details of private sorrow;\r\nthough profoundly sympathetic, he did his best to oppose Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nharsher judgments of Amy, and herein he gave his friend a satisfaction\r\nwhich might not be avowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really do not see,\xe2\x80\x99 he exclaimed, as they sat in the garret one night\r\nof midsummer, \xe2\x80\x98how your wife could have acted otherwise. Of course I\r\nam quite unable to judge the attitude of her mind, but I think, I can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhelp thinking, from what I knew of her, that there has been strictly a\r\nmisunderstanding between you.\r\n\r\nIt was a hard and miserable thing that she should have to leave you for\r\na time, and you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t face the necessity in a just spirit. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nthink there\xe2\x80\x99s some truth in this way of looking at it?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As a woman, it was her part to soften the hateful necessity; she made\r\nit worse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure that you don\xe2\x80\x99t demand too much of her. Unhappily, I know\r\nlittle or nothing of delicately-bred women, but I have a suspicion that\r\none oughtn\xe2\x80\x99t to expect heroism in them, any more than in the women of\r\nthe lower classes. I think of women as creatures to be protected. Is a\r\nman justified in asking them to be stronger than himself?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Reardon, \xe2\x80\x98there\xe2\x80\x99s no use in demanding more than\r\na character is capable of. But I believed her of finer stuff. My\r\nbitterness comes of the disappointment.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose there were faults of temper on both sides, and you saw at\r\nlast only each other\xe2\x80\x99s weaknesses.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I saw the truth, which had always been disguised from me.\xe2\x80\x99 Biffen\r\npersisted in looking doubtful, and in secret Reardon thanked him for it.\r\n\r\nAs the realist progressed with his novel, \xe2\x80\x98Mr Bailey, Grocer,\xe2\x80\x99 he read\r\nthe chapters to Reardon, not only for his own satisfaction, but in great\r\npart because he hoped that this example of productivity might in the end\r\nencourage the listener to resume his own literary tasks. Reardon found\r\nmuch to criticise in his friend\xe2\x80\x99s work; it was noteworthy that he\r\nobjected and condemned with much less hesitation than in his better\r\ndays, for sensitive reticence is one of the virtues wont to be assailed\r\nby suffering, at all events in the weaker natures. Biffen purposely\r\nurged these discussions as far as possible, and doubtless they benefited\r\nReardon for the time; but the defeated novelist could not be induced to\r\nundertake another practical illustration of his own views. Occasionally\r\nhe had an impulse to plan a story, but an hour\xe2\x80\x99s turning it over in his\r\nmind sufficed to disgust him. His ideas seemed barren, vapid; it would\r\nhave been impossible for him to write half a dozen pages, and the mere\r\nthought of a whole book overcame him with the dread of insurmountable\r\ndifficulties, immeasurable toil.\r\n\r\nIn time, however, he was able to read. He had a pleasure in\r\ncontemplating the little collection of sterling books that alone\r\nremained to him from his library; the sight of many volumes would have\r\nbeen a weariness, but these few--when he was again able to think\r\nof books at all--were as friendly countenances. He could not read\r\ncontinuously, but sometimes he opened his Shakespeare, for instance,\r\nand dreamed over a page or two. From such glimpses there remained in\r\nhis head a line or a short passage, which he kept repeating to himself\r\nwherever he went; generally some example of sweet or sonorous metre\r\nwhich had a soothing effect upon him.\r\n\r\nWith odd result on one occasion. He was walking in one of the back\r\nstreets of Islington, and stopped idly to gaze into the window of some\r\nsmall shop. Standing thus, he forgot himself and presently recited\r\naloud:\r\n\r\n     \xe2\x80\x98Caesar, \xe2\x80\x98tis his schoolmaster:\r\n     An argument that he is pluck\xe2\x80\x99d, when hither\r\n     He sends so poor a pinion of his wing,\r\n     Which had superfluous kings for messengers\r\n     Not many moons gone by.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThe last two lines he uttered a second time, enjoying their magnificent\r\nsound, and then was brought back to consciousness by the loud mocking\r\nlaugh of two men standing close by, who evidently looked upon him as a\r\nstrayed lunatic.\r\n\r\nHe kept one suit of clothes for his hours of attendance at the hospital;\r\nit was still decent, and with much care would remain so for a long time.\r\nThat which he wore at home and in his street wanderings declared poverty\r\nat every point; it had been discarded before he left the old abode. In\r\nhis present state of mind he cared nothing how disreputable he looked to\r\npassers-by. These seedy habiliments were the token of his degradation,\r\nand at times he regarded them (happening to see himself in a shop\r\nmirror) with pleasurable contempt. The same spirit often led him for a\r\nmeal to the poorest of eating-houses, places where he rubbed elbows with\r\nragged creatures who had somehow obtained the price of a cup of coffee\r\nand a slice of bread and butter. He liked to contrast himself with these\r\ncomrades in misfortune. \xe2\x80\x98This is the rate at which the world esteems\r\nme; I am worth no better provision than this.\xe2\x80\x99 Or else, instead of\r\nemphasising the contrast, he defiantly took a place among the miserables\r\nof the nether world, and nursed hatred of all who were well-to-do.\r\n\r\nOne of these he desired to regard with gratitude, but found it difficult\r\nto support that feeling. Carter, the vivacious, though at first\r\nperfectly unembarrassed in his relations with the City Road clerk,\r\ngradually exhibited a change of demeanour. Reardon occasionally found\r\nthe young man\xe2\x80\x99s eye fixed upon him with a singular expression, and the\r\nsecretary\xe2\x80\x99s talk, though still as a rule genial, was wont to suffer\r\ncurious interruptions, during which he seemed to be musing on something\r\nReardon had said, or on some point of his behaviour. The explanation of\r\nthis was that Carter had begun to think there might be a foundation for\r\nMrs Yule\xe2\x80\x99s hypothesis--that the novelist was not altogether in his sound\r\nsenses. At first he scouted the idea, but as time went on it seemed\r\nto him that Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s countenance certainly had a gaunt wildness which\r\nsuggested disagreeable things. Especially did he remark this after his\r\nreturn from an August holiday in Norway. On coming for the first time\r\nto the City Road branch he sat down and began to favour Reardon with\r\na lively description of how he had enjoyed himself abroad; it never\r\noccurred to him that such talk was not likely to inspirit the man\r\nwho had passed his August between the garret and the hospital, but he\r\nobserved before long that his listener was glancing hither and thither\r\nin rather a strange way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You haven\xe2\x80\x99t been ill since I saw you?\xe2\x80\x99 he inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh no!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you look as if you might have been. I say, we must manage for you\r\nto have a fortnight off, you know, this month.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no wish for it,\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll imagine I have been to\r\nNorway. It has done me good to hear of your holiday.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m glad of that; but it isn\xe2\x80\x99t quite the same thing, you know, as\r\nhaving a run somewhere yourself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, much better! To enjoy myself may be mere selfishness, but to enjoy\r\nanother\xe2\x80\x99s enjoyment is the purest satisfaction, good for body and soul.\r\nI am cultivating altruism.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A highly rarefied form of happiness. The curious thing about it is\r\nthat it won\xe2\x80\x99t grow unless you have just twice as much faith in it as is\r\nrequired for assent to the Athanasian Creed.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nCarter went away more than puzzled. He told his wife that evening that\r\nReardon had been talking to him in the most extraordinary fashion--no\r\nunderstanding a word he said.\r\n\r\nAll this time he was on the look-out for employment that would be more\r\nsuitable to his unfortunate clerk. Whether slightly demented or not,\r\nReardon gave no sign of inability to discharge his duties; he was\r\nconscientious as ever, and might, unless he changed greatly, be relied\r\nupon in positions of more responsibility than his present one. And at\r\nlength, early in October, there came to the secretary\xe2\x80\x99s knowledge an\r\nopportunity with which he lost no time in acquainting Reardon. The\r\nlatter repaired that evening to Clipstone Street, and climbed to\r\nBiffen\xe2\x80\x99s chamber. He entered with a cheerful look, and exclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have just invented a riddle; see if you can guess it. Why is a London\r\nlodging-house like the human body?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBiffen looked with some concern at his friend, so unwonted was a sally\r\nof this kind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why is a London lodging-house--? Haven\xe2\x80\x99t the least idea.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because the brains are always at the top. Not bad, I think, eh?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, no; it\xe2\x80\x99ll pass. Distinctly professional though. The general\r\npublic would fail to see the point, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid. But what has come to\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Good tidings. Carter has offered me a place which will be a decided\r\nimprovement. A house found--or rooms, at all events--and salary a\r\nhundred and fifty a year.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By Plutus! That\xe2\x80\x99s good hearing. Some duties attached, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid that was inevitable, as things go. It\xe2\x80\x99s the secretaryship of\r\na home for destitute boys at Croydon. The post is far from a sinecure,\r\nCarter assures me. There\xe2\x80\x99s a great deal of purely secretarial work,\r\nand there\xe2\x80\x99s a great deal of practical work, some of it rather rough,\r\nI fancy. It seems doubtful whether I am exactly the man. The present\r\nholder is a burly fellow over six feet high, delighting in gymnastics,\r\nand rather fond of a fight now and then when opportunity offers. But he\r\nis departing at Christmas--going somewhere as a missionary; and I can\r\nhave the place if I choose.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As I suppose you do?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I shall try it, decidedly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBiffen waited a little, then asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose your wife will go with you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no saying.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon tried to answer indifferently, but it could be seen that he was\r\nagitated between hopes and fears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You\xe2\x80\x99ll ask her, at all events?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh yes,\xe2\x80\x99 was the half-absent reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But surely there can be no doubt that she\xe2\x80\x99ll come. A hundred and fifty\r\na year, without rent to pay. Why, that\xe2\x80\x99s affluence!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The rooms I might occupy are in the home itself. Amy won\xe2\x80\x99t take very\r\nreadily to a dwelling of that kind. And Croydon isn\xe2\x80\x99t the most inviting\r\nlocality.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Close to delightful country.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes; but Amy doesn\xe2\x80\x99t care about that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You misjudge her, Reardon. You are too harsh. I implore you not to lose\r\nthe chance of setting all right again! If only you could be put into my\r\nposition for a moment, and then be offered the companionship of such a\r\nwife as yours!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon listened with a face of lowering excitement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should be perfectly within my rights,\xe2\x80\x99 he said sternly, \xe2\x80\x98if I merely\r\ntold her when I have taken the position, and let her ask me to take her\r\nback--if she wishes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have changed a great deal this last year,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Biffen, shaking\r\nhis head, \xe2\x80\x98a great deal. I hope to see you your old self again before\r\nlong. I should have declared it impossible for you to become so rugged.\r\nGo and see your wife, there\xe2\x80\x99s a good fellow.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No; I shall write to her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Go and see her, I beg you! No good ever came of letter-writing between\r\ntwo people who have misunderstood each other. Go to Westbourne Park\r\nto-morrow. And be reasonable; be more than reasonable. The happiness\r\nof your life depends on what you do now. Be content to forget whatever\r\nwrong has been done you. To think that a man should need persuading to\r\nwin back such a wife!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn truth, there needed little persuasion. Perverseness, one of the forms\r\nor issues of self-pity, made him strive against his desire, and caused\r\nhim to adopt a tone of acerbity in excess of what he felt; but already\r\nhe had made up his mind to see Amy. Even if this excuse had not\r\npresented itself he must very soon have yielded to the longing for\r\na sight of his wife\xe2\x80\x99s face which day by day increased among all the\r\nconflicting passions of which he was the victim. A month or two ago,\r\nwhen the summer sunshine made his confinement to the streets a daily\r\ntorture, he convinced himself that there remained in him no trace of his\r\nlove for Amy; there were moments when he thought of her with repugnance,\r\nas a cold, selfish woman, who had feigned affection when it seemed her\r\ninterest to do so, but brutally declared her true self when there was\r\nno longer anything to be hoped from him. That was the self-deception of\r\nmisery. Love, even passion, was still alive in the depths of his being;\r\nthe animation with which he sped to his friend as soon as a new hope had\r\nrisen was the best proof of his feeling.\r\n\r\nHe went home and wrote to Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have a reason for wishing to see you. Will you have the kindness to\r\nappoint an hour on Sunday morning when I can speak with you in private?\r\nIt must be understood that I shall see no one else.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe would receive this by the first post to-morrow, Saturday, and\r\ndoubtless would let him hear in reply some time in the afternoon.\r\nImpatience allowed him little sleep, and the next day was a long\r\nweariness of waiting. The evening he would have to spend at the\r\nhospital; if there came no reply before the time of his leaving home, he\r\nknew not how he should compel himself to the ordinary routine of work.\r\nYet the hour came, and he had heard nothing. He was tempted to go at\r\nonce to Westbourne Park, but reason prevailed with him. When he again\r\nentered the house, having walked at his utmost speed from the City Road,\r\nthe letter lay waiting for him; it had been pushed beneath his door, and\r\nwhen he struck a match he found that one of his feet was upon the white\r\nenvelope.\r\n\r\nAmy wrote that she would be at home at eleven to-morrow morning. Not\r\nanother word.\r\n\r\nIn all probability she knew of the offer that had been made to him; Mrs\r\nCarter would have told her. Was it of good or of ill omen that she wrote\r\nonly these half-dozen words? Half through the night he plagued himself\r\nwith suppositions, now thinking that her brevity promised a welcome,\r\nnow that she wished to warn him against expecting anything but a cold,\r\noffended demeanour. At seven he was dressed; two hours and a half had\r\nto be killed before he could start on his walk westward. He would have\r\nwandered about the streets, but it rained.\r\n\r\nHe had made himself as decent as possible in appearance, but he must\r\nnecessarily seem an odd Sunday visitor at a house such as Mrs Yule\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nHis soft felt hat, never brushed for months, was a greyish green, and\r\nstained round the band with perspiration. His necktie was discoloured\r\nand worn. Coat and waistcoat might pass muster, but of the trousers the\r\nless said the better. One of his boots was patched, and both were all\r\nbut heelless.\r\n\r\nVery well; let her see him thus. Let her understand what it meant to\r\nlive on twelve and sixpence a week.\r\n\r\nThough it was cold and wet he could not put on his overcoat. Three\r\nyears ago it had been a fairly good ulster; at present, the edges of the\r\nsleeves were frayed, two buttons were missing, and the original hue of\r\nthe cloth was indeterminable.\r\n\r\nAt half-past nine he set out and struggled with his shabby umbrella\r\nagainst wind and rain. Down Pentonville Hill, up Euston Road, all\r\nalong Marylebone Road, then north-westwards towards the point of his\r\ndestination. It was a good six miles from the one house to the other,\r\nbut he arrived before the appointed time, and had to stray about until\r\nthe cessation of bell-clanging and the striking of clocks told him it\r\nwas eleven. Then he presented himself at the familiar door.\r\n\r\nOn his asking for Mrs Reardon, he was at once admitted and led up to the\r\ndrawing-room; the servant did not ask his name.\r\n\r\nThen he waited for a minute or two, feeling himself a squalid wretch\r\namid the dainty furniture. The door opened. Amy, in a simple but very\r\nbecoming dress, approached to within a yard of him; after the first\r\nglance she had averted her eyes, and she did not offer to shake hands.\r\nHe saw that his muddy and shapeless boots drew her attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you know why I have come?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked.\r\n\r\nHe meant the tone to be conciliatory, but he could not command his\r\nvoice, and it sounded rough, hostile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think so,\xe2\x80\x99 Amy answered, seating herself gracefully. She would have\r\nspoken with less dignity but for that accent of his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The Carters have told you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; I have heard about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere was no promise in her manner. She kept her face turned away, and\r\nReardon saw its beautiful profile, hard and cold as though in marble.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t interest you at all?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am glad to hear that a better prospect offers for you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe did not sit down, and was holding his rusty hat behind his back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You speak as if it in no way concerned yourself. Is that what you wish\r\nme to understand?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Won\xe2\x80\x99t it be better if you tell me why you have come here? As you are\r\nresolved to find offence in whatever I say, I prefer to keep silence.\r\nPlease to let me know why you have asked to see me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon turned abruptly as if to leave her, but checked himself at a\r\nlittle distance.\r\n\r\nBoth had come to this meeting prepared for a renewal of amity, but in\r\nthese first few moments each was so disagreeably impressed by the look\r\nand language of the other that a revulsion of feeling undid all the more\r\nhopeful effects of their long severance. On entering, Amy had meant to\r\noffer her hand, but the unexpected meanness of Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s aspect shocked\r\nand restrained her. All but every woman would have experienced that\r\nshrinking from the livery of poverty. Amy had but to reflect, and she\r\nunderstood that her husband could in no wise help this shabbiness;\r\nwhen he parted from her his wardrobe was already in a long-suffering\r\ncondition, and how was he to have purchased new garments since then?\r\nNone the less such attire degraded him in her eyes; it symbolised the\r\nmelancholy decline which he had suffered intellectually. On Reardon his\r\nwife\xe2\x80\x99s elegance had the same repellent effect, though this would not\r\nhave been the case but for the expression of her countenance. Had it\r\nbeen possible for them to remain together during the first five minutes\r\nwithout exchange of words, sympathies might have prevailed on both\r\nsides; the first speech uttered would most likely have harmonised with\r\ntheir gentler thoughts. But the mischief was done so speedily.\r\n\r\nA man must indeed be graciously endowed if his personal appearance can\r\ndefy the disadvantage of cheap modern clothing worn into shapelessness.\r\nReardon had no such remarkable physique, and it was not wonderful that\r\nhis wife felt ashamed of him. Strictly ashamed; he seemed to her a\r\nsocial inferior; the impression was so strong that it resisted all\r\nmemory of his spiritual qualities. She might have anticipated this state\r\nof things, and have armed herself to encounter it, but somehow she had\r\nnot done so. For more than five months she had been living among people\r\nwho dressed well; the contrast was too suddenly forced upon her. She was\r\nespecially susceptible in such matters, and had become none the less\r\nso under the demoralising influence of her misfortunes. True, she soon\r\nbegan to feel ashamed of her shame, but that could not annihilate the\r\nnatural feeling and its results.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t love him. I can\xe2\x80\x99t love him.\xe2\x80\x99 Thus she spoke to herself, with\r\nimmutable decision. She had been doubtful till now, but all doubt was at\r\nan end. Had Reardon been practical man enough to procure by hook or\r\nby crook a decent suit of clothes for this interview, that ridiculous\r\ntrifle might have made all the difference in what was to result.\r\n\r\nHe turned again, and spoke with the harshness of a man who feels that he\r\nis despised, and is determined to show an equal contempt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I came to ask you what you propose to do in case I go to Croydon.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have no proposal to make whatever.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That means, then, that you are content to go on living here?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If I have no choice, I must make myself content.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you have a choice.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98None has yet been offered me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I offer it now,\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon, speaking less aggressively. \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nshall have a dwelling rent free, and a hundred and fifty pounds a\r\nyear--perhaps it would be more in keeping with my station if I say that\r\nI shall have something less than three pounds a week. You can either\r\naccept from me half this money, as up to now, or come and take your\r\nplace again as my wife. Please to decide what you will do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will let you know by letter in a few days.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt seemed impossible to her to say she would return, yet a refusal to\r\ndo so involved nothing less than separation for the rest of their lives.\r\nPostponement of decision was her only resource.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I must know at once,\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t answer at once.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you don\xe2\x80\x99t, I shall understand you to mean that you refuse to come\r\nto me. You know the circumstances; there is no reason why you should\r\nconsult with anyone else. You can answer me immediately if you will.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t wish to answer you immediately,\xe2\x80\x99 Amy replied, paling slightly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then that decides it. When I leave you we are strangers to each other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy made a rapid study of his countenance. She had never entertained for\r\na moment the supposition that his wits were unsettled, but none the less\r\nthe constant recurrence of that idea in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s talk had subtly\r\ninfluenced her against her husband. It had confirmed her in thinking\r\nthat his behaviour was inexcusable. And now it seemed to her that\r\nanyone might be justified in holding him demented, so reckless was his\r\nutterance.\r\n\r\nIt was difficult to know him as the man who had loved her so devotedly,\r\nwho was incapable of an unkind word or look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If that is what you prefer,\xe2\x80\x99 she said, \xe2\x80\x98there must be a formal\r\nseparation. I can\xe2\x80\x99t trust my future to your caprice.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You mean it must be put into the hands of a lawyer?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, I do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That will be the best, no doubt.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well; I will speak with my friends about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your friends!\xe2\x80\x99 he exclaimed bitterly. \xe2\x80\x98But for those friends of yours,\r\nthis would never have happened. I wish you had been alone in the world\r\nand penniless.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A kind wish, all things considered.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, it is a kind wish. Then your marriage with me would have been\r\nbinding; you would have known that my lot was yours, and the knowledge\r\nwould have helped your weakness. I begin to see how much right there is\r\non the side of those people who would keep women in subjection. You have\r\nbeen allowed to act with independence, and the result is that you have\r\nruined my life and debased your own. If I had been strong enough to\r\ntreat you as a child, and bid you follow me wherever my own fortunes\r\nled, it would have been as much better for you as for me. I was weak,\r\nand I suffer as all weak people do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You think it was my duty to share such a home as you have at present?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You know it was. And if the choice had lain between that and earning\r\nyour own livelihood you would have thought that even such a poor home\r\nmight be made tolerable. There were possibilities in you of better\r\nthings than will ever come out now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere followed a silence. Amy sat with her eyes gloomily fixed on the\r\ncarpet; Reardon looked about the room, but saw nothing. He had thrown\r\nhis hat into a chair, and his fingers worked nervously together behind\r\nhis back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Will you tell me,\xe2\x80\x99 he said at length, \xe2\x80\x98how your position is regarded\r\nby these friends of yours? I don\xe2\x80\x99t mean your mother and brother, but the\r\npeople who come to this house.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have not asked such people for their opinion.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Still, I suppose some sort of explanation has been necessary in your\r\nintercourse with them. How have you represented your relations with me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t see that that concerns you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In a manner it does. Certainly it matters very little to me how I am\r\nthought of by people of this kind, but one doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like to be reviled\r\nwithout cause. Have you allowed it to be supposed that I have made life\r\nwith me intolerable for you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No, I have not. You insult me by asking the question, but as you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t seem to understand feelings of that kind I may as well answer you\r\nsimply.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then have you told them the truth? That I became so poor you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlive with me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have never said that in so many words, but no doubt it is understood.\r\nIt must be known also that you refused to take the step which might have\r\nhelped you out of your difficulties.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What step?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe reminded him of his intention to spend half a year in working at the\r\nseaside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I had utterly forgotten it,\xe2\x80\x99 he returned with a mocking laugh. \xe2\x80\x98That\r\nshows how ridiculous such a thing would have been.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are doing no literary work at all?\xe2\x80\x99 Amy asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you imagine that I have the peace of mind necessary for anything of\r\nthat sort?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis was in a changed voice. It reminded her so strongly of her husband\r\nbefore his disasters that she could not frame a reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think I am able to occupy myself with the affairs of imaginary\r\npeople?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I didn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily mean fiction.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That I can forget myself, then, in the study of literature?--I wonder\r\nwhether you really think of me like that. How, in Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s name, do you\r\nsuppose I spend my leisure time?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe made no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think I take this calamity as light-heartedly as you do, Amy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am far from taking it light-heartedly.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yet you are in good health. I see no sign that you have suffered.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe kept silence. Her suffering had been slight enough, and chiefly due\r\nto considerations of social propriety; but she would not avow this, and\r\ndid not like to make admission of it to herself. Before her friends she\r\nfrequently affected to conceal a profound sorrow; but so long as her\r\nchild was left to her she was in no danger of falling a victim to\r\nsentimental troubles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And certainly I can\xe2\x80\x99t believe it,\xe2\x80\x99 he continued, \xe2\x80\x98now you declare your\r\nwish to be formally separated from me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have declared no such wish.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed you have. If you can hesitate a moment about returning to me\r\nwhen difficulties are at an end, that tells me you would prefer final\r\nseparation.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I hesitate for this reason,\xe2\x80\x99 Amy said after reflecting. \xe2\x80\x98You are so\r\nvery greatly changed from what you used to be, that I think it doubtful\r\nif I could live with you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Changed?--Yes, that is true, I am afraid. But how do you think this\r\nchange will affect my behaviour to you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Remember how you have been speaking to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And you think I should treat you brutally if you came into my power?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not brutally, in the ordinary sense of the word. But with faults of\r\ntemper which I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t bear. I have my own faults. I can\xe2\x80\x99t behave as\r\nmeekly as some women can.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was a small concession, but Reardon made much of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Did my faults of temper give you any trouble during the first year of\r\nour married life?\xe2\x80\x99 he asked gently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 she admitted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They began to afflict you when I was so hard driven by difficulties\r\nthat I needed all your sympathy, all your forbearance. Did I receive\r\nmuch of either from you, Amy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think you did--until you demanded impossible things of me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It was always in your power to rule me. What pained me worst, and\r\nhardened me against you, was that I saw you didn\xe2\x80\x99t care to exert your\r\ninfluence. There was never a time when I could have resisted a word of\r\nyours spoken out of your love for me. But even then, I am afraid, you no\r\nlonger loved me, and now--\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe broke off, and stood watching her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Have you any love for me left?\xe2\x80\x99 burst from his lips, as if the words\r\nall but choked him in the utterance.\r\n\r\nAmy tried to shape some evasive answer, but could say nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Is there ever so small a hope that I might win some love from you\r\nagain?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If you wish me to come and live with you when you go to Croydon I will\r\ndo so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But that is not answering me, Amy.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s all I can say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you mean that you would sacrifice yourself out of--what? Out of\r\npity for me, let us say.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you wish to see Willie?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Amy, instead of replying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. It is you I have come to see. The child is nothing to me, compared\r\nwith you. It is you, who loved me, who became my wife--you only I care\r\nabout. Tell me you will try to be as you used to be. Give me only that\r\nhope, Amy; I will ask nothing except that, now.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t say anything except that I will come to Croydon if you wish\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And reproach me always because you have to live in such a place, away\r\nfrom your friends, without a hope of the social success which was your\r\ndearest ambition?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHer practical denial that she loved him wrung this taunt from his\r\nanguished heart. He repented the words as soon as they were spoken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What is the good?\xe2\x80\x99 exclaimed Amy in irritation, rising and moving away\r\nfrom him. \xe2\x80\x98How can I pretend that I look forward to such a life with any\r\nhope?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe stood in mute misery, inwardly cursing himself and his fate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have said I will come,\xe2\x80\x99 she continued, her voice shaken with nervous\r\ntension. \xe2\x80\x98Ask me or not, as you please, when you are ready to go there.\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t talk about it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall not ask you,\xe2\x80\x99 he replied. \xe2\x80\x98I will have no woman slave dragging\r\nout a weary life with me. Either you are my willing wife, or you are\r\nnothing to me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am married to you, and that can\xe2\x80\x99t be undone. I repeat that I shan\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nrefuse to obey you. I shall say no more.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe moved to a distance, and there seated herself, half turned from him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall never ask you to come,\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon, breaking a short silence.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If our married life is ever to begin again it must be of your seeking.\r\nCome to me of your own will, and I shall never reject you. But I will\r\ndie in utter loneliness rather than ask you again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe lingered a few moments, watching her; she did not move. Then he took\r\nhis hat, went in silence from the room, and left the house.\r\n\r\nIt rained harder than before. As no trains were running at this hour,\r\nhe walked in the direction where he would be likely to meet with an\r\nomnibus. But it was a long time before one passed which was any use to\r\nhim. When he reached home he was in cheerless plight enough; to make\r\nthings pleasanter, one of his boots had let in water abundantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The first sore throat of the season, no doubt,\xe2\x80\x99 he muttered to himself.\r\n\r\nNor was he disappointed. By Tuesday the cold had firm grip of him. A\r\nday or two of influenza or sore throat always made him so weak that with\r\ndifficulty he supported the least physical exertion; but at present he\r\nmust go to his work at the hospital. Why stay at home? To what purpose\r\nspare himself? It was not as if life had any promise for him. He was\r\na machine for earning so much money a week, and would at least give\r\nfaithful work for his wages until the day of final breakdown.\r\n\r\nBut, midway in the week, Carter discovered how ill his clerk was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You ought to be in bed, my dear fellow, with gruel and mustard plasters\r\nand all the rest of it. Go home and take care of yourself--I insist upon\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nBefore leaving the office, Reardon wrote a few lines to Biffen, whom he\r\nhad visited on the Monday. \xe2\x80\x98Come and see me if you can. I am down with a\r\nbad cold, and have to keep in for the rest of the week. All the same,\r\nI feel far more cheerful. Bring a new chapter of your exhilarating\r\nromance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVI. MARRIED WOMAN\xe2\x80\x99S PROPERTY\r\n\r\nOn her return from church that Sunday Mrs Edmund Yule was anxious to\r\nlearn the result of the meeting between Amy and her husband. She hoped\r\nfervently that Amy\xe2\x80\x99s anomalous position would come to an end now that\r\nReardon had the offer of something better than a mere clerkship. John\r\nYule never ceased to grumble at his sister\xe2\x80\x99s permanence in the house,\r\nespecially since he had learnt that the money sent by Reardon each month\r\nwas not made use of; why it should not be applied for household expenses\r\npassed his understanding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It seems to me,\xe2\x80\x99 he remarked several times, \xe2\x80\x98that the fellow only does\r\nhis bare duty in sending it. What is it to anyone else whether he\r\nlives on twelve shillings a week or twelve pence? It is his business\r\nto support his wife; if he can\xe2\x80\x99t do that, to contribute as much to her\r\nsupport as possible. Amy\xe2\x80\x99s scruples are all very fine, if she could\r\nafford them; it\xe2\x80\x99s very nice to pay for your delicacies of feeling out of\r\nother people\xe2\x80\x99s pockets.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99ll have to be a formal separation,\xe2\x80\x99 was the startling\r\nannouncement with which Amy answered her mother\xe2\x80\x99s inquiry as to what had\r\npassed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A separation? But, my dear--!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Yule could not express her disappointment and dismay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98We couldn\xe2\x80\x99t live together; it\xe2\x80\x99s no use trying.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But at your age, Amy! How can you think of anything so shocking? And\r\nthen, you know it will be impossible for him to make you a sufficient\r\nallowance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall have to live as well as I can on the seventy-five pounds a\r\nyear. If you can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to let me stay with you for that, I must go\r\ninto cheap lodgings in the country, like poor Mrs Butcher did.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis was wild talking for Amy. The interview had upset her, and for the\r\nrest of the day she kept apart in her own room. On the morrow Mrs Yule\r\nsucceeded in eliciting a clear account of the conversation which had\r\nended so hopelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I would rather spend the rest of my days in the workhouse than beg him\r\nto take me back,\xe2\x80\x99 was Amy\xe2\x80\x99s final comment, uttered with the earnestness\r\nwhich her mother understood but too well.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But you are willing to go back, dear?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I told him so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you must leave this to me. The Carters will let us know how things\r\ngo on, and when it seems to be time I must see Edwin myself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I can\xe2\x80\x99t allow that. Anything you could say on your own account would be\r\nuseless, and there is nothing to say from me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Yule kept her own counsel. She had a full month before her during\r\nwhich to consider the situation, but it was clear to her that these\r\nyoung people must be brought together again. Her estimate of Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmental condition had undergone a sudden change from the moment when she\r\nheard that a respectable post was within his reach; she decided that\r\nhe was \xe2\x80\x98strange,\xe2\x80\x99 but then all men of literary talent had marked\r\nsingularities, and doubtless she had been too hasty in interpreting the\r\npeculiar features natural to a character such as his.\r\n\r\nA few days later arrived the news of their relative\xe2\x80\x99s death at\r\nWattleborough.\r\n\r\nThis threw Mrs Yule into a commotion. At first she decided to accompany\r\nher son and be present at the funeral; after changing her mind twenty\r\ntimes, she determined not to go. John must send or bring back the news\r\nas soon as possible. That it would be of a nature sensibly to affect\r\nher own position, if not that of her children, she had little doubt;\r\nher husband had been the favourite brother of the deceased, and on that\r\naccount there was no saying how handsome a legacy she might receive. She\r\ndreamt of houses in South Kensington, of social ambitions gratified even\r\nthus late.\r\n\r\nOn the morning after the funeral came a postcard announcing John\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreturn by a certain train, but no scrap of news was added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Just like that irritating boy! We must go to the station to meet him.\r\nYou\xe2\x80\x99ll come, won\xe2\x80\x99t you, Amy?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy readily consented, for she too had hopes, though circumstances\r\nblurred them. Mother and daughter were walking about the platform\r\nhalf an hour before the train was due; their agitation would have been\r\nmanifest to anyone observing them. When at length the train rolled in\r\nand John was discovered, they pressed eagerly upon him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t you excite yourself,\xe2\x80\x99 he said gruffly to his mother. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no\r\nreason whatever.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nMrs Yule glanced in dismay at Amy. They followed John to a cab, and took\r\nplaces with him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Now don\xe2\x80\x99t be provoking, Jack. Just tell us at once.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98By all means. You haven\xe2\x80\x99t a penny.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I haven\xe2\x80\x99t? You are joking, ridiculous boy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never felt less disposed to, I assure you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAfter staring out of the window for a minute or two, he at length\r\ninformed Amy of the extent to which she profited by her uncle\xe2\x80\x99s decease,\r\nthen made known what was bequeathed to himself. His temper grew worse\r\nevery moment, and he replied savagely to each successive question\r\nconcerning the other items of the will.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have you to grumble about?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Amy, whose face was exultant\r\nnotwithstanding the drawbacks attaching to her good fortune. \xe2\x80\x98If Uncle\r\nAlfred receives nothing at all, and mother has nothing, you ought to\r\nthink yourself very lucky.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s very easy for you to say that, with your ten thousand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But is it her own?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Mrs Yule. \xe2\x80\x98Is it for her separate use?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course it is. She gets the benefit of last year\xe2\x80\x99s Married Woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nProperty Act. The will was executed in January this year, and I dare say\r\nthe old curmudgeon destroyed a former one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a splendid Act of Parliament that is!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Amy. \xe2\x80\x98The only one\r\nworth anything that I ever heard of.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But my dear--\xe2\x80\x99 began her mother, in a tone of protest. However, she\r\nreserved her comment for a more fitting time and place, and merely said:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I wonder whether he had heard what has been going on?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think he would have altered his will if he had?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Amy with\r\na smile of security.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why the deuce he should have left you so much in any case is more\r\nthan I can understand,\xe2\x80\x99 growled her brother. \xe2\x80\x98What\xe2\x80\x99s the use to me of\r\na paltry thousand or two? It isn\xe2\x80\x99t enough to invest; isn\xe2\x80\x99t enough to do\r\nanything with.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You may depend upon it your cousin Marian thinks her five thousand\r\ngood for something,\xe2\x80\x99 said Mrs Yule. \xe2\x80\x98Who was at the funeral? Don\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nso surly, Jack; tell us all about it. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure if anyone has cause to be\r\nill-tempered it\xe2\x80\x99s poor me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThus they talked, amid the rattle of the cab-wheels. By when they\r\nreached home silence had fallen upon them, and each one was sufficiently\r\noccupied with private thoughts.\r\n\r\nMrs Yule\xe2\x80\x99s servants had a terrible time of it for the next few days. Too\r\naffectionate to turn her ill-temper against John and Amy, she relieved\r\nherself by severity to the domestic slaves, as an English matron is of\r\ncourse justified in doing. Her daughter\xe2\x80\x99s position caused her even more\r\nconcern than before; she constantly lamented to herself: \xe2\x80\x98Oh, why didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nhe die before she was married!\xe2\x80\x99--in which case Amy would never have\r\ndreamt of wedding a penniless author. Amy declined to discuss the new\r\naspect of things until twenty-four hours after John\xe2\x80\x99s return; then she\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall do nothing whatever until the money is paid to me. And what I\r\nshall do then I don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are sure to hear from Edwin,\xe2\x80\x99 opined Mrs Yule.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I think not. He isn\xe2\x80\x99t the kind of man to behave in that way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then I suppose you are bound to take the first step?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That I shall never do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nShe said so, but the sudden happiness of finding herself wealthy was\r\nnot without its softening effect on Amy\xe2\x80\x99s feelings. Generous impulses\r\nalternated with moods of discontent. The thought of her husband in his\r\nsqualid lodgings tempted her to forget injuries and disillusions, and to\r\nplay the part of a generous wife. It would be possible now for them to\r\ngo abroad and spend a year or two in healthful travel; the result in\r\nReardon\xe2\x80\x99s case might be wonderful. He might recover all the energy of\r\nhis imagination, and resume his literary career from the point he had\r\nreached at the time of his marriage.\r\n\r\nOn the other hand, was it not more likely that he would lapse into a\r\nlife of scholarly self-indulgence, such as he had often told her was\r\nhis ideal? In that event, what tedium and regret lay before her! Ten\r\nthousand pounds sounded well, but what did it represent in reality? A\r\npoor four hundred a year, perhaps; mere decency of obscure existence,\r\nunless her husband could glorify it by winning fame. If he did nothing,\r\nshe would be the wife of a man who had failed in literature. She would\r\nnot be able to take a place in society. Life would be supported without\r\nstruggle; nothing more to be hoped.\r\n\r\nThis view of the future possessed her strongly when, on the second day,\r\nshe went to communicate her news to Mrs Carter. This amiable lady had\r\nnow become what she always desired to be, Amy\xe2\x80\x99s intimate friend; they\r\nsaw each other very frequently, and conversed of most things with much\r\nfrankness. It was between eleven and twelve in the morning when Amy paid\r\nher visit, and she found Mrs Carter on the point of going out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I was coming to see you,\xe2\x80\x99 cried Edith. \xe2\x80\x98Why haven\xe2\x80\x99t you let me know of\r\nwhat has happened?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You have heard, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Albert heard from your brother.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I supposed he would. And I haven\xe2\x80\x99t felt in the mood for talking about\r\nit, even with you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey went into Mrs Carter\xe2\x80\x99s boudoir, a tiny room full of such pretty\r\nthings as can be purchased nowadays by anyone who has a few shillings\r\nto spare, and tolerable taste either of their own or at second-hand. Had\r\nshe been left to her instincts, Edith would have surrounded herself with\r\nobjects representing a much earlier stage of artistic development; but\r\nshe was quick to imitate what fashion declared becoming. Her husband\r\nregarded her as a remarkable authority in all matters of personal or\r\ndomestic ornamentation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And what are you going to do?\xe2\x80\x99 she inquired, examining Amy from head\r\nto foot, as if she thought that the inheritance of so substantial a sum\r\nmust have produced visible changes in her friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am going to do nothing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But surely you\xe2\x80\x99re not in low spirits?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What have I to rejoice about?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey talked for a while before Amy brought herself to utter what she was\r\nthinking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it a most ridiculous thing that married people who both wish to\r\nseparate can\xe2\x80\x99t do so and be quite free again?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose it would lead to all sorts of troubles--don\xe2\x80\x99t you think?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98So people say about every new step in civilisation. What would have\r\nbeen thought twenty years ago of a proposal to make all married women\r\nindependent of their husbands in money matters? All sorts of absurd\r\ndangers were foreseen, no doubt. And it\xe2\x80\x99s the same now about divorce.\r\nIn America people can get divorced if they don\xe2\x80\x99t suit each other--at\r\nall events in some of the States--and does any harm come of it? Just the\r\nopposite I should think.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEdith mused. Such speculations were daring, but she had grown accustomed\r\nto think of Amy as an \xe2\x80\x98advanced\xe2\x80\x99 woman, and liked to imitate her in this\r\nrespect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It does seem reasonable,\xe2\x80\x99 she murmured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The law ought to encourage such separations, instead of forbidding\r\nthem,\xe2\x80\x99 Amy pursued. \xe2\x80\x98If a husband and wife find that they have made\r\na mistake, what useless cruelty it is to condemn them to suffer the\r\nconsequences for the whole of their lives!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I suppose it\xe2\x80\x99s to make people careful,\xe2\x80\x99 said Edith, with a laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98If so, we know that it has always failed, and always will fail; so the\r\nsooner such a profitless law is altered the better. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t there some\r\nsociety for getting that kind of reform? I would subscribe fifty pounds\r\na year to help it. Wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, if I had it to spare,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the other.\r\n\r\nThen they both laughed, but Edith the more naturally.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not on my own account, you know,\xe2\x80\x99 she added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It\xe2\x80\x99s because women who are happily married can\xe2\x80\x99t and won\xe2\x80\x99t understand\r\nthe position of those who are not that there\xe2\x80\x99s so much difficulty in\r\nreforming marriage laws.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I understand you, Amy, and I grieve about you. What you are to do I\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t think.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to see what I shall do. Of course I have no choice\r\nreally. And I ought to have a choice; that\xe2\x80\x99s the hardship and the wrong\r\nof it. Perhaps if I had, I should find a sort of pleasure in sacrificing\r\nmyself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThere were some new novels on the table; Amy took up a volume presently,\r\nand glanced over a page or two.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how you can go on reading that sort of stuff, book after\r\nbook,\xe2\x80\x99 she exclaimed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, but people say this last novel of Markland\xe2\x80\x99s is one of his best.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Best or worst, novels are all the same. Nothing but love, love, love;\r\nwhat silly nonsense it is! Why don\xe2\x80\x99t people write about the really\r\nimportant things of life? Some of the French novelists do; several of\r\nBalzac\xe2\x80\x99s, for instance. I have just been reading his \xe2\x80\x9cCousin Pons,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\nterrible book, but I enjoyed it ever so much because it was nothing like\r\na love story. What rubbish is printed about love!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I get rather tired of it sometimes,\xe2\x80\x99 admitted Edith with amusement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should hope you do, indeed. What downright lies are accepted as\r\nindisputable! That about love being a woman\xe2\x80\x99s whole life; who believes\r\nit really? Love is the most insignificant thing in most women\xe2\x80\x99s lives.\r\nIt occupies a few months, possibly a year or two, and even then I doubt\r\nif it is often the first consideration.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nEdith held her head aside, and pondered smilingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99m sure there\xe2\x80\x99s a great opportunity for some clever novelist who will\r\nnever write about love at all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But then it does come into life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes, for a month or two, as I say. Think of the biographies of men and\r\nwomen; how many pages are devoted to their love affairs? Compare those\r\nbooks with novels which profess to be biographies, and you see how false\r\nsuch pictures are. Think of the very words \xe2\x80\x9cnovel,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cromance\xe2\x80\x9d--what do\r\nthey mean but exaggeration of one bit of life?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That may be true. But why do people find the subject so interesting?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because there is so little love in real life. That\xe2\x80\x99s the truth of\r\nit. Why do poor people care only for stories about the rich? The same\r\nprinciple.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How clever you are, Amy!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Am I? It\xe2\x80\x99s very nice to be told so. Perhaps I have some cleverness of a\r\nkind; but what use is it to me? My life is being wasted. I ought to\r\nhave a place in the society of clever people. I was never meant to live\r\nquietly in the background. Oh, if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been in such a hurry, and so\r\ninexperienced!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, I wanted to ask you,\xe2\x80\x99 said Edith, soon after this. \xe2\x80\x98Do you wish\r\nAlbert to say anything about you--at the hospital?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no reason why he shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You won\xe2\x80\x99t even write to say--?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I shall do nothing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nSince the parting from her husband, there had proceeded in Amy\r\na noticeable maturing of intellect. Probably the one thing was a\r\nconsequence of the other. During that last year in the flat her mind\r\nwas held captive by material cares, and this arrest of her natural\r\ndevelopment doubtless had much to do with the appearance of acerbity\r\nin a character which had displayed so much sweetness, so much womanly\r\ngrace. Moreover, it was arrest at a critical point. When she fell in\r\nlove with Edwin Reardon her mind had still to undergo the culture of\r\ncircumstances; though a woman in years she had seen nothing of life but\r\na few phases of artificial society, and her education had not progressed\r\nbeyond the final schoolgirl stage. Submitting herself to Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninfluence, she passed through what was a highly useful training of the\r\nintellect; but with the result that she became clearly conscious of the\r\ndivergence between herself and her husband. In endeavouring to imbue her\r\nwith his own literary tastes, Reardon instructed Amy as to the natural\r\ntendencies of her mind, which till then she had not clearly understood.\r\nWhen she ceased to read with the eyes of passion, most of the things\r\nwhich were Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s supreme interests lost their value for her. A sound\r\nintelligence enabled her to think and feel in many directions, but the\r\nspecial line of her growth lay apart from that in which the novelist and\r\nclassical scholar had directed her.\r\n\r\nWhen she found herself alone and independent, her mind acted like a\r\nspring when pressure is removed. After a few weeks of desoeuvrement she\r\nobeyed the impulse to occupy herself with a kind of reading alien\r\nto Reardon\xe2\x80\x99s sympathies. The solid periodicals attracted her, and\r\nespecially those articles which dealt with themes of social science.\r\nAnything that savoured of newness and boldness in philosophic thought\r\nhad a charm for her palate. She read a good deal of that kind of\r\nliterature which may be defined as specialism popularised; writing which\r\naddresses itself to educated, but not strictly studious, persons, and\r\nwhich forms the reservoir of conversation for society above the sphere\r\nof turf and west-endism. Thus, for instance, though she could not\r\nundertake the volumes of Herbert Spencer, she was intelligently\r\nacquainted with the tenor of their contents; and though she had never\r\nopened one of Darwin\xe2\x80\x99s books, her knowledge of his main theories and\r\nillustrations was respectable. She was becoming a typical woman of the\r\nnew time, the woman who has developed concurrently with journalistic\r\nenterprise.\r\n\r\nNot many days after that conversation with Edith Carter, she had\r\noccasion to visit Mudie\xe2\x80\x99s, for the new number of some periodical which\r\ncontained an appetising title. As it was a sunny and warm day she walked\r\nto New Oxford Street from the nearest Metropolitan station. Whilst\r\nwaiting at the library counter, she heard a familiar voice in her\r\nproximity; it was that of Jasper Milvain, who stood talking with a\r\nmiddle-aged lady. As Amy turned to look at him his eye met hers; clearly\r\nhe had been aware of her. The review she desired was handed to her; she\r\nmoved aside, and turned over the pages. Then Milvain walked up.\r\n\r\nHe was armed cap-a-pie in the fashions of suave society; no Bohemianism\r\nof garb or person, for Jasper knew he could not afford that kind of\r\neconomy. On her part, Amy was much better dressed than usual, a costume\r\nsuited to her position of bereaved heiress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a time since we met!\xe2\x80\x99 said Jasper, taking her delicately gloved\r\nhand and looking into her face with his most effective smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And why?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed, I hardly know. I hope Mrs Yule is well?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Quite, thank you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt seemed as if he would draw back to let her pass, and so make an end\r\nof the colloquy. But Amy, though she moved forward, added a remark:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t see your name in any of this month\xe2\x80\x99s magazines.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have nothing signed this month. A short review in The Current, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nall.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But I suppose you write as much as ever?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; but chiefly in weekly papers just now. You don\xe2\x80\x99t see the\r\nWill-o\xe2\x80\x99-the-Wisp?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh yes. And I think I can generally recognise your hand.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey issued from the library.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Which way are you going?\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper inquired, with something more of the\r\nold freedom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I walked from Gower Street station, and I think, as it\xe2\x80\x99s so fine, I\r\nshall walk back again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe accompanied her. They turned up Museum Street, and Amy, after a short\r\nsilence, made inquiry concerning his sisters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sorry I saw them only once, but no doubt you thought it better to\r\nlet the acquaintance end there.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really didn\xe2\x80\x99t think of it in that way at all,\xe2\x80\x99 Jasper replied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x99We naturally understood it so, when you even ceased to call, yourself.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But don\xe2\x80\x99t you feel that there would have been a good deal of\r\nawkwardness in my coming to Mrs Yule\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Seeing that you looked at things from my husband\xe2\x80\x99s point of view?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, that\xe2\x80\x99s a mistake! I have only seen your husband once since he went\r\nto Islington.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy gave him a look of surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are not on friendly terms with him?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, we have drifted apart. For some reason he seemed to think that my\r\ncompanionship was not very profitable. So it was better, on the whole,\r\nthat I should see neither you nor him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy was wondering whether he had heard of her legacy. He might have been\r\ninformed by a Wattleborough correspondent, even if no one in London had\r\ntold him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do your sisters keep up their friendship with my cousin Marian?\xe2\x80\x99 she\r\nasked, quitting the previous difficult topic.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh yes!\xe2\x80\x99 He smiled. \xe2\x80\x98They see a great deal of each other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then of course you have heard of my uncle\xe2\x80\x99s death?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes. I hope all your difficulties are now at an end.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy delayed a moment, then said: \xe2\x80\x98I hope so,\xe2\x80\x99 without any emphasis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do you think of spending this winter abroad?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIt was the nearest he could come to a question concerning the future of\r\nAmy and her husband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Everything is still quite uncertain. But tell me something about our\r\nold acquaintances. How does Mr Biffen get on?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I scarcely ever see him, but I think he pegs away at an interminable\r\nnovel, which no one will publish when it\xe2\x80\x99s done. Whelpdale I meet\r\noccasionally.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe talked of the latter\xe2\x80\x99s projects and achievements in a lively strain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your own prospects continue to brighten, no doubt,\xe2\x80\x99 said Amy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I really think they do. Things go fairly well. And I have lately\r\nreceived a promise of very valuable help.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98From whom?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A relative of yours.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nAmy turned to interrogate him with a look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A relative? You mean--?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Yes; Marian.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThey were passing Bedford Square. Amy glanced at the trees, now\r\nalmost bare of foliage; then her eyes met Jasper\xe2\x80\x99s, and she smiled\r\nsignificantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I should have thought your aim would have been far more ambitious,\xe2\x80\x99 she\r\nsaid, with distinct utterance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Marian and I have been engaged for some time--practically.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Indeed? I remember now how you once spoke of her. And you will be\r\nmarried soon?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Probably before the end of the year. I see that you are criticising my\r\nmotives. I am quite prepared for that in everyone who knows me and the\r\ncircumstances. But you must remember that I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t foresee anything of\r\nthis kind. It enables us to marry sooner, that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am sure your motives are unassailable,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Amy, still with a\r\nsmile. \xe2\x80\x98I imagined that you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t marry for years, and then some\r\ndistinguished person. This throws new light upon your character.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You thought me so desperately scheming and cold-blooded?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh dear no! But--well, to be sure, I can\xe2\x80\x99t say that I know Marian. I\r\nhaven\xe2\x80\x99t seen her for years and years. She may be admirably suited to\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Depend upon it, I think so.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98She\xe2\x80\x99s likely to shine in society? She is a brilliant girl, full of tact\r\nand insight?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Scarcely all that, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe looked dubiously at his companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Then you have abandoned your old ambitions?\xe2\x80\x99 Amy pursued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not a bit of it. I am on the way to achieve them.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And Marian is the ideal wife to assist you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98From one point of view, yes. Pray, why all this ironic questioning?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Not ironic at all.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It sounded very much like it, and I know from of old that you have a\r\ntendency that way.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98The news surprised me a little, I confess. But I see that I am in\r\ndanger of offending you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Let us wait another five years, and then I will ask your opinion as\r\nto the success of my marriage. I don\xe2\x80\x99t take a step of this kind without\r\nmaturely considering it. Have I made many blunders as yet?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As yet, not that I know of.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Do I impress you as one likely to commit follies?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I had rather wait a little before answering that.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98That is to say, you prefer to prophesy after the event. Very well, we\r\nshall see.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nIn the length of Gower Street they talked of several other things less\r\npersonal. By degrees the tone of their conversation had become what it\r\nwas used to be, now and then almost confidential.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are still at the same lodgings?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Amy, as they drew near to\r\nthe railway station.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I moved yesterday, so that the girls and I could be under the same\r\nroof--until the next change.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You will let us know when that takes place?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nHe promised, and with exchange of smiles which were something like a\r\nchallenge they took leave of each other.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVII. THE LONELY MAN\r\n\r\nA touch of congestion in the right lung was a warning to Reardon that\r\nhis half-year of insufficient food and general waste of strength would\r\nmake the coming winter a hard time for him, worse probably than the\r\nlast. Biffen, responding in person to the summons, found him in bed,\r\nwaited upon by a gaunt, dry, sententious woman of sixty--not the\r\nlandlady, but a lodger who was glad to earn one meal a day by any means\r\nthat offered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98It wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be very nice to die here, would it?\xe2\x80\x99 said the sufferer,\r\nwith a laugh which was cut short by a cough. \xe2\x80\x98One would like a\r\ncomfortable room, at least. Why, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. I dreamt last night that\r\nI was in a ship that had struck something and was going down; and it\r\nwasn\xe2\x80\x99t the thought of death that most disturbed me, but a horror of\r\nbeing plunged in the icy water. In fact, I have had just the same\r\nfeeling on shipboard. I remember waking up midway between Corfu and\r\nBrindisi, on that shaky tub of a Greek boat; we were rolling a good\r\ndeal, and I heard a sort of alarmed rush and shouting up on deck. It\r\nwas so warm and comfortable in the berth, and I thought with intolerable\r\nhorror of the possibility of sousing into the black depths.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Don\xe2\x80\x99t talk, my boy,\xe2\x80\x99 advised Biffen. \xe2\x80\x98Let me read you the new chapter\r\nof \xe2\x80\x9cMr Bailey.\xe2\x80\x9d It may induce a refreshing slumber.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon was away from his duties for a week; he returned to them with a\r\nfeeling of extreme shakiness, an indisposition to exert himself, and\r\na complete disregard of the course that events were taking. It was\r\nfortunate that he had kept aside that small store of money designed\r\nfor emergencies; he was able to draw on it now to pay his doctor, and\r\nprovide himself with better nourishment than usual. He purchased new\r\nboots, too, and some articles of warm clothing of which he stood in\r\nneed--an alarming outlay.\r\n\r\nA change had come over him; he was no longer rendered miserable by\r\nthoughts of Amy--seldom, indeed, turned his mind to her at all.\r\nHis secretaryship at Croydon was a haven within view; the income of\r\nseventy-five pounds (the other half to go to his wife) would support him\r\nluxuriously, and for anything beyond that he seemed to care little. Next\r\nSunday he was to go over to Croydon and see the institution.\r\n\r\nOne evening of calm weather he made his way to Clipstone Street and\r\ngreeted his friend with more show of light-heartedness than he had been\r\ncapable of for at least two years.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I have been as nearly as possible a happy man all to-day,\xe2\x80\x99 he said,\r\nwhen his pipe was well lit. \xe2\x80\x98Partly the sunshine, I suppose. There\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nno saying if the mood will last, but if it does all is well with me. I\r\nregret nothing and wish for nothing.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98A morbid state of mind,\xe2\x80\x99 was Biffen\xe2\x80\x99s opinion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No doubt of that, but I am content to be indebted to morbidness. One\r\nmust have a rest from misery somehow. Another kind of man would have\r\ntaken to drinking; that has tempted me now and then, I assure you. But\r\nI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford it. Did you ever feel tempted to drink merely for the\r\nsake of forgetting trouble?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Often enough. I have done it. I have deliberately spent a certain\r\nproportion of the money that ought to have gone for food in the cheapest\r\nkind of strong liquor.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ha! that\xe2\x80\x99s interesting. But it never got the force of a habit you had\r\nto break?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98No. Partly, I dare say, because I had the warning of poor Sykes before\r\nmy eyes.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You never see that poor fellow?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Never. He must be dead, I think. He would die either in the hospital or\r\nthe workhouse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 said Reardon, musing cheerfully, \xe2\x80\x98I shall never become a\r\ndrunkard; I haven\xe2\x80\x99t that diathesis, to use your expression. Doesn\xe2\x80\x99t it\r\nstrike you that you and I are very respectable persons? We really have\r\nno vices. Put us on a social pedestal, and we should be shining lights\r\nof morality. I sometimes wonder at our inoffensiveness. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t we run\r\namuck against law and order? Why, at the least, don\xe2\x80\x99t we become savage\r\nrevolutionists, and harangue in Regent\xe2\x80\x99s Park of a Sunday?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because we are passive beings, and were meant to enjoy life very\r\nquietly. As we can\xe2\x80\x99t enjoy, we just suffer quietly, that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\r\nBy-the-bye, I want to talk about a difficulty in one of the Fragments of\r\nEuripides. Did you ever go through the Fragments?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nThis made a diversion for half an hour. Then Reardon returned to his\r\nformer line of thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98As I was entering patients yesterday, there came up to the table a\r\ntall, good-looking, very quiet girl, poorly dressed, but as neat as\r\ncould be. She gave me her name, then I asked \xe2\x80\x9cOccupation?\xe2\x80\x9d She said\r\nat once, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m unfortunate, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help looking up at her in\r\nsurprise; I had taken it for granted she was a dressmaker or something\r\nof the kind. And, do you know, I never felt so strong an impulse to\r\nshake hands, to show sympathy, and even respect, in some way. I should\r\nhave liked to say, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I am unfortunate, too!\xe2\x80\x9d such a good, patient\r\nface she had.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I distrust such appearances,\xe2\x80\x99 said Biffen in his quality of realist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, so do I, as a rule. But in this case they were convincing. And\r\nthere was no need whatever for her to make such a declaration; she might\r\njust as well have said anything else; it\xe2\x80\x99s the merest form. I shall\r\nalways hear her voice saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m unfortunate, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d She made me feel\r\nwhat a mistake it was for me to marry such a girl as Amy. I ought to\r\nhave looked about for some simple, kind-hearted work-girl; that was\r\nthe kind of wife indicated for me by circumstances. If I had earned a\r\nhundred a year she would have thought we were well-to-do. I should have\r\nbeen an authority to her on everything under the sun--and above it. No\r\nambition would have unsettled her. We should have lived in a couple of\r\npoor rooms somewhere, and--we should have loved each other.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What a shameless idealist you are!\xe2\x80\x99 said Biffen, shaking his head. \xe2\x80\x98Let\r\nme sketch the true issue of such a marriage. To begin with, the girl\r\nwould have married you in firm persuasion that you were a \xe2\x80\x9cgentleman\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n in temporary difficulties, and that before long you would have plenty\r\nof money to dispose of. Disappointed in this hope, she would have grown\r\nsharp-tempered, querulous, selfish. All your endeavours to make her\r\nunderstand you would only have resulted in widening the impassable\r\ngulf. She would have misconstrued your every sentence, found food for\r\nsuspicion in every harmless joke, tormented you with the vulgarest forms\r\nof jealousy. The effect upon your nature would have been degrading. In\r\nthe end, you must have abandoned every effort to raise her to your own\r\nlevel, and either have sunk to hers or made a rupture. Who doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nthe story of such attempts? I myself ten years ago, was on the point of\r\ncommitting such a folly, but, Heaven be praised! an accident saved me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You never told me that story.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And don\xe2\x80\x99t care to now. I prefer to forget it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Well, you can judge for yourself but not for me. Of course I might have\r\nchosen the wrong girl, but I am supposing that I had been fortunate. In\r\nany case there would have been a much better chance than in the marriage\r\nthat I made.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Your marriage was sensible enough, and a few years hence you will be a\r\nhappy man again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You seriously think Amy will come back to me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Of course I do.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Upon my word, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that I desire it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Because you are in a strangely unhealthy state.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I rather think I regard the matter more sanely than ever yet. I\r\nam quite free from sexual bias. I can see that Amy was not my fit\r\nintellectual companion, and all emotion at the thought of her has gone\r\nfrom me. The word \xe2\x80\x9clove\xe2\x80\x9d is a weariness to me. If only our idiotic laws\r\npermitted us to break the legal bond, how glad both of us would be!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98You are depressed and anaemic. Get yourself in flesh, and view things\r\nlike a man of this world.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98But don\xe2\x80\x99t you think it the best thing that can happen to a man if he\r\noutgrows passion?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In certain circumstances, no doubt.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In all and any. The best moments of life are those when we contemplate\r\nbeauty in the purely artistic spirit--objectively. I have had such\r\nmoments in Greece and Italy; times when I was a free spirit, utterly\r\nremote from the temptations and harassings of sexual emotion. What we\r\ncall love is mere turmoil. Who wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t release himself from it for\r\never, if the possibility offered?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Oh, there\xe2\x80\x99s a good deal to be said for that, of course.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nReardon\xe2\x80\x99s face was illumined with the glow of an exquisite memory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Haven\xe2\x80\x99t I told you,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98of that marvellous sunset at Athens? I\r\nwas on the Pnyx; had been rambling about there the whole afternoon. For\r\nI dare say a couple of hours I had noticed a growing rift of light in\r\nthe clouds to the west; it looked as if the dull day might have a rich\r\nending. That rift grew broader and brighter--the only bit of light in\r\nthe sky. On Parnes there were white strips of ragged mist, hanging very\r\nlow; the same on Hymettus, and even the peak of Lycabettus was just\r\nhidden. Of a sudden, the sun\xe2\x80\x99s rays broke out. They showed themselves\r\nfirst in a strangely beautiful way, striking from behind the seaward\r\nhills through the pass that leads to Eleusis, and so gleaming on the\r\nnearer slopes of Aigaleos, making the clefts black and the rounded parts\r\nof the mountain wonderfully brilliant with golden colour. All the rest\r\nof the landscape, remember, was untouched with a ray of light.
